revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = 826LA |image = Echo Park Time Travel Mart.jpg |size = 220 |caption = Echo Park Time Travel Mart |motto = Whenever You Are, We're Already Then |founders = Nínive Calegari and [[Dave Eggers]] |formation = 2005 |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |purpose = Education |headquarters = The Echo Park Time Travel Mart
1714 W. Sunset Blvd.
Los Angeles, CA 90026

The Mar Vista Time Travel Mart
12515 Venice Blvd.
Los Angeles, CA 90066 |location = |region_served = Los Angeles |membership = |language = |leader_title = Executive Director |leader_name = Joel Arquillos |main_organ = Advisory board: J.J. Abrams Judd Apatow Fiona Apple Miguel Arteta Mac Barnett Steve Barr Joshuah Bearman Father Greg Boyle, SJ Stefan G. Bucher Mark Flanagan Naomi Foner Mitchell Frank Ben Goldhirsh Ellen Goldsmith-Vein Nicole Holofcener Spike Jonze Miranda July Catherine Keener Al Madrigal Melissa Mathison Tara Roth Katie McGrath R. Scott Mitchell Lani Monos B.J. Novak Jane Patterson Keri Putnam Sonja Rasula Luis J. Rodriguez J. Ryan Stradal Sarah Vowell Sally Willcox |affiliations = 826 National |num_staff = 20 |num_volunteers = 4,000+ |budget = |website = http://www.826la.org/ |remarks = }} '''826LA''' is a [[Los Angeles]]-based [[nonprofit]] organization dedicated to supporting students ages 6–18 with their creative and expository writing skills and helping teachers inspire their students to write. Programs are structured around the beliefs that great leaps in learning can happen with one-on-one attention and that strong writing skills are fundamental to future success. 826LA was founded in 2005 and is one of several chapters of 826 National. To serve students across Los Angeles' various regions, there are two locations: 826LA in [[Mar Vista, Los Angeles|Mar Vista]] and 826LA in [[Echo Park, Los Angeles|Echo Park]]. A satellite site at Manual Arts Senior High School in South L.A. opened in 2013. The 826LA Board of Directors consists of [[Grant DeVaul]], [[Dave Eggers]], [[Terena Thyne Eisner]], [[Jodie Evans]], [[DeAnna Gravillis]], Keith Knight, [[Louis Lucido]], [[Krystyn Madrigal]], [[Sylvie Rabineau]], and Brad Simpson. There are seven other [[826 National]] chapters; [[San Francisco]] ([[826 Valencia]]), NYC ([[826NYC]]), Chicago ([[826CHI]]), Ann Arbor/Ypsilanti/Detroit ([[826michigan]]), Boston ([[826 Boston]]), New Orleans ([[826 New Orleans]]) and Washington, D.C. ([[826DC]]). ==The Time Travel Mart== The Time Travel Mart exists at both 826LA in Mar Vista and 826LA in Echo Park, specializing in products imported from the past and future, such as Viking odorant, robot milk, robot toupees, robot emotions, mammoth chunks, and other time travel-themed oddities. The store and its initial line of products were conceived by writers Mac Barnett and Jon Korn, and graphic designer [[Stefan G. Bucher]]. The store also sells anthologies of work by 826LA writing students, new and back issues of ''[[Timothy McSweeney's Quarterly Concern]]'', ''[[The Believer (magazine)|The Believer]]'', ''[[Wholphin (DVD)|Wholphin]]'', and other McSweeney's publications. The store also sells a special series of [[Poketo]] wallets, celebrating the work of artists and students alike. The short stories written by 826LA students line the inside of Poketo's artist wallets, and then illustrated with a Poketo artist's interpretations of the stories.[http://poketo.com/shop/projects/826-la-collaboration/ ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016041815/http://poketo.com/shop/projects/826-la-collaboration/ |date=October 16, 2008 }} ==Programs== [[File:After School Tutoring.jpg|thumb|After School Tutoring]] '''After-School Tutoring''' 826LA offers free tutoring Monday through Thursday. Tutoring is offered with a focus on personalized instruction, offering local students individualized help with their homework. Students come to the writing labs, where they work with tutors to complete their daily assignments, and often to embark on ambitious writing projects: poems, stories, comic books, and self-initiated research. Student writing is compiled and published in chapbook form by two in-house publishing outfits: Dogtown Books (Mar Vista) and Echo Park Press (Echo Park). '''Workshops''' 826LA offers writing workshops that cover a wide spectrum of subjects, all designed to strengthen students’ skills, foster their creativity, and give them an opportunity to execute projects that showcase their work. Working professionals teach all the offered workshops, and class sizes are kept small to ensure individualized attention. These workshops focus on a variety of topics. Recent classes have covered crafting college-application essays, designing imaginary countries, preparing for the [[SAT]], reviewing runway fashion, and writing love poetry from the perspective of leopards. In 2012, two workshops encouraged students to examine their daily lives and share their thoughts and experiences with students in Rwanda and India. Among its many collaborative workshops is Sunday Afternoon For Kids, held at the [[Hammer Museum]] in which artists, writers and performers teach their craft.[http://hammer.ucla.edu/programs/programs/cat/12 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081217184825/http://hammer.ucla.edu/programs/programs/cat/12 |date=December 17, 2008 }} A popular songwriting workshop brings together local musicians to collaborate with students in the songwriting process. In 2010, an edition of the workshop featured the band [[The Submarines]], and was titled "Songwriting With The Submarines." The students' songs were then recorded by professional musicians and released as an album called ''[[Chickens in Love]]'', featuring musicians such as [[The Submarines]], [[Fiona Apple]], [[Edward Sharpe and the Magnetic Zeros]], [[Tim and Eric]], [[Crystal Antlers]], [[Cold War Kids]], [[Dum Dum Girls]], and more.{{cite journal |url=http://filtermagazine.com/index.php/news/entry/826la_to_release_chickens_in_love_compilation/ |title=News - 826LA To Release ‘Chickens In Love’ Compilation |publisher=FILTER Magazine |date=2010-02-10 |accessdate=2014-06-29 |journal= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213044514/http://filtermagazine.com/index.php/news/entry/826la_to_release_chickens_in_love_compilation |archive-date=2010-02-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}{{cite web|author=the BEAT |url=http://thebeatofyounglosangeles.blogspot.com/2010/03/do-it-pledge-to-826las-chickens-in-love.html |title=the BEAT: Do It. Pledge to 826LA's 'Chickens in Love.' |publisher=Thebeatofyounglosangeles.blogspot.com |date=2010-03-02 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} '''In-Schools''' 826LA also sends volunteers into school throughout Los Angeles. Tutors support Los Angeles teachers in their classrooms, providing students with one-on-one attention and feedback as they work on various writing assignments: sonnets, biographies, [[University of California]] application essays, narrative essays, and more. In Spring 2006, [[Community Photoworks]] was created, an annual collaboration between 826LA and the [[J. Paul Getty Museum]]. Seventh-graders students were taught the basics of photographic composition, explored Los Angeles with cameras, and wrote and polished artist statements. Their photographs and statements were displayed in a gallery exhibition in Venice.{{cite web|url=http://www.getty.edu/news/press/center/community_photoworks06.html |title=Community Photoworks (Press Release) |publisher=Getty.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-06-29}} '''Field Trips''' In the mornings, classes from around Los Angeles visit the 826LA writing labs to participate in engaging and spirited field trips. Teachers can choose from various field-trip plans, such as workshops in screenwriting and journalism, or request a custom-designed program. Field trips are tailored to complement any teacher’s curriculum. The most popular field trip is "Storytelling & Bookmaking," in which classes collaborate to write stories for Mr. Barnacle, the never-seen, always-cranky publisher behind Barnacle & Barnacle Books. With the help of several storytellers, an illustrator, and a typist, a class works together to create characters, a setting, and a plot for an original story. (A recent book chronicled the friendship between an injured mouse and a sandwich-making robot policeman. Others have featured time traveling tea-cup pigs, spaghetti monsters, and sentient planets). The action builds to a thrilling cliffhanger, and then each student has an opportunity to write an ending, create an illustration, bind his or her book, and walk away with the finished product. Barnacle is notoriously hard to please, but the students’ work manages to earn his enthusiastic approval every time. ==Events== '''Dead Author Readings''' Since 2008, 826LA has presented a series of Dead Author Readings, in which deceased wordsmiths such as [[Mary Shelley]] and [[Edgar Allan Poe]] have read from their works and answered questions from the audience. The first iteration took place at the Echo Park location and featured comedian Patton Oswalt, who impersonated William Fryer Harvey and read from the works "The Clock" and "August Heat."{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2008/07/24/dead-author-readings-patton-oswalt-is-william-fryer-harvey/ |title=Dead Author Readings: Patton Oswalt is William Fryer Harvey |publisher=826LA |date=2008-07-24 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} The series then morphed into a collaboration with [[Paul F. Tompkins]] and the [[Upright Citizen's Brigade]].{{cite web|url=http://losangeles.ucbtheatre.com/shows/view/2243 |title=UCB Theatre • Dead Authors |publisher=Losangeles.ucbtheatre.com |date= |accessdate=2014-06-29}} More recent readings have impersonated [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]] and [[James Joyce]],{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2010/04/28/dead-author-reading-moderated-by-hg-wells-f-scott-fitzgerald-and-james-joyce/ |title=Dead Author Reading, moderated by H.G. Wells: F. Scott Fitzgerald and James Joyce |publisher=826LA |date=2010-04-28 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} [[Mary Shelley]],{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/oct/03/entertainment/et-authors3 |title='Frankenstein' writer back, sort of - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2008-10-03 |accessdate=2014-06-29 |first=Mindy |last=Farabee}} [[O. Henry]],{{cite web|author=GOOD |url=http://www.good.is/post/good-december-dead-author-reading-tonight/ |title=GOOD December: Dead Author Reading Tonight |publisher=Good.is |date=2008-12-05 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} [[J.R.R. Tolkien]],{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2012/02/02/dead-author-reading-with-j-r-r-tolkien/ |title=Dead Author Reading with J.R.R. Tolkien |publisher=826LA |date=2012-02-02 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} and the [[Brothers Grimm]].{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2012/05/01/dead-author-reading-with-the-brothers-grimm/ |title=Dead Author Reading with The Brothers Grimm |publisher=826LA |date=2012-05-01 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} '''Writer's Panels''' Starting in 2009, 826LA began running the Adult Writing Seminar Series, which was meant to provide insight for aspiring adult writers into the world of professional writing.{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2009/03/30/our-first-adult-seminar-a-huge-success/ |title=Our first adult seminar a huge success! |publisher=826LA |date=2009-03-30 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} Each workshop focused on a different genre and featured experienced writers at a panel discussion.http://events.ocregister.com/los_angeles_ca/events/show/172145785-826la-adult-writing-seminar-series Early topics included music writing, food writing, comedy writing, and memoir writing.http://826la.org/WP/?s=adult+seminar After appearing as a panelist for the Comedy Writing seminar,{{cite web|last=Gray |first=Alysia |url=http://www.nbclosangeles.com/the-scene/events/Putting-the-Comedy-in-Comedy-Writing-92685429.html |title=Putting the Comedy in Comedy Writing | NBC Southern California |publisher=Nbclosangeles.com |date=2010-05-03 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} Ben Blacker returned to moderate the TV Writing seminar,{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2009/10/05/adult-writing-seminar-series-tv-writing/ |title=Adult Writing Seminar Series: TV Writing |publisher=826LA |date=2009-10-05 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} and the series has since become a collaboration with [[Nerdist Industries|Nerdist]]{{cite web|url=https://www.nerdist.com/2011/04/nerdist-theater-at-meltdown-roundup/ |title=Nerdist Theater at Meltdown Roundup « Nerdist |publisher=Nerdist.com |date=2011-04-08 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} entitled the Nerdist Writer’s Panel, with Blacker as the sole moderator.{{cite web|url=http://www.nerdist.com/2011/05/hot-shows-happening-at-nerdist-theater-at-meltdown-this-week/ |title=Hot Shows Happening at Nerdist Theater at Meltdown This Week! « Nerdist |publisher=Nerdist.com |date=2011-05-16 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} '''Fundraisers''' 826LA has become well known for hosting creative and entertaining fundraisers. In August 2008, 826LA hosted the Echo Park Lake Paddle Boat Regatta.{{cite news|last=Mikulan |first=Steven |url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/informer/2009/07/echo_park_paddle_boat_regatta.php |title=Echo Park Paddle Boat Regatta | The Informer | Los Angeles | Los Angeles News and Events | LA Weekly |publisher=Blogs.laweekly.com |date=2013-10-03 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} In 2009, they hosted the first annual Craft Beer Fest at the Echoplex in Echo Park.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090417055148/http://www.attheecho.com/2009/03/27/saturday-050909-la-cabal-826la-echo-present-the-first-annual-craft-beer-fest-la-echoplex]{{cite web|author=Pat Saperstein |url=http://eatingla.blogspot.com/2009/03/craft-beer-fest-la-debuts-by-and-for.html |title=Eating L.A.: Craft Beer Fest L.A. debuts: by and for local beer geeks |publisher=Eatingla.blogspot.com |date=2009-03-23 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} In 2010, [[Judd Apatow]] and [[Dave Eggers]] hosted an event called "I Found This Funny: An Evening of Music and Comedy." The event featured [[Lindsay Buckingham]], [[Randy Newman]], [[Garry Shandling]], [[Aziz Ansari]], [[Maria Bamford]], and [[Ryan Adams]].{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/gossip/2010/10/judd-apatow-fundraiser-826la-aziz-ansari-garry-shandling.html | work=Los Angeles Times | title=Ministry of Gossip | date=2010-10-30}} 826LA also hosted a celebrity spelling bee in 2010 called "Spelling Bee for Cheaters," which featured [[John Krasinski]], [[Dave Eggers]], [[Spike Jonze]], and [[Jimmy Kimmel]].{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/08/13/celebs-compete-in-spellin_n_681661.html |title=Celebs Compete In 'Spelling Bee For Cheaters' To Benefit 826LA |publisher=Huffingtonpost.com |date= 2010-08-13|accessdate=2014-06-29}}{{cite news|author=  |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/jacketcopy/2010/07/826las-spelling-bee-for-cheaters.html |title=826LA's Spelling Bee for Cheaters | Jacket Copy | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2010-07-09 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} In 2011, director and photographer [[Spike Jonze]] and actress [[Miranda July]] competed in a ping-pong tournament to raise funds for 826LA, raising around $30,000.{{Cite web |url=http://www.whatgives.com/2011/07/26/spike-jonze-plays-ping-pong-with-purpose/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2012-05-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120613063154/http://www.whatgives.com/2011/07/26/spike-jonze-plays-ping-pong-with-purpose/ |archive-date=2012-06-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} In 2012, 826LA hosted the Judd and Jon Music and Comedy Hour(s), a music and comedy fundraiser featuring headliners [[Jon Brion]] and [[Judd Apatow]], along with [[Pee Wee Herman]], [[The RZA]], [[Bob Newhart]], [[Peter Frampton]], [[Colin Quinn]], and [[Ray Romano]]. The event raised over $250,000.{{cite web|url=http://826la.org/WP/2012/06/19/thank-you-judd-apatow-2/ |title=Thank you, Judd Apatow! |publisher=826LA |date=2012-06-19 |accessdate=2014-06-29}} '''Roar Shack Reading Series''' In 2012, 826LA became host to the Roar Shack Reading Series founded by David Rocklin, a Los Angeles-based community of writers who come together on the second Sunday of every month. The event consists of featured readers and a live write. Featured readers in the past have included Natashia Deón (author of ''Grace: A Novel''), [[Martin Pousson]] (author of ''Black Sheep Boy''), and [[Brian Sonia-Wallace]] (poet). For each live write, an audience suggested prompt is assigned and two writers are chosen to write and perform. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.826la.org/ 826LA] *[http://www.826national.org/ 826 National] *[https://www.facebook.com/roarshackpac/ Roar Shack Reading Series] {{DEFAULTSORT:826la}} [[Category:826 National]] [[Category:Education in Los Angeles]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Los Angeles]]

page.title: Academic dress in the United States

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10)
revision.text:
[[File:Smith College Hood.jpg|thumb|right|Contemporary bachelor gown and hood for [[Smith College]].]] '''Academic regalia in the United States''' has a history going back to the [[colonial colleges]] era. It has been most influenced by the [[academic dress]] traditions of Europe. There is an Inter-Collegiate Code that sets out a detailed uniform scheme of academic regalia that is voluntarily followed by many, though not all institutions entirely adhere to it.
==Gowns and robes== [[File:Jacob1207b.JPG|thumb|American academic dress is typically closed at the front and is properly worn with the prescribed cap and hood. On the baccalaureate dress shown, other items, such as scarves, stoles or cords may be seen.]]
[[Bachelor's degree|Bachelor's]] and [[Master's degree|master's]] gowns in the United States are similar to some of their counterparts in the United Kingdom, particularly [[Oxford]]. The main differences are that the bachelor's gown is designed to be worn closed and that the sleeves of the modern gown are square at the end instead of pointed<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 122.</ref> as the Code calls for. The master's gown sleeve is [[rectangle|oblong]] and, though the base of the sleeve hangs down, it is square-cut at the rear part of the oblong shape. The front part has an arc cut away, and there is a slit for the wrist opening (which before 1960 was located at the elbow as on British gowns), but the rest of the arc is closed. The shape is evocative of the square-cut [[liripipe]] incorporated into many academic hoods (''see'', below). The master's gown is designed to be worn open or closed.<ref name="Eugene Sullivan 2001"/>
[[Doctorate|Doctoral]] gowns are typically black, although some schools use gowns in the [[school colors|school's colors]].<ref name="Eugene Sullivan 2001"/> The Code calls for the outside shell of the hood to remain black in that case. Doctoral gowns have bell sleeves with three velvet bands on them and velvet facing on the front of the gown. The Code calls for the gown trim to be either black or the color designated for the field of study in which the doctorate is earned, with the proviso that the degree of [[Doctor of Philosophy]] (Ph.D.) uses the dark blue velvet of philosophy regardless of the particular field studied. (For example, a Ph.D. in theology would wear velvet gown trim in dark blue, a [[Doctor of Theology]] (Th.D.) would wear scarlet trim, or either might choose black.) The robes have full sleeves instead of the bell sleeves of the bachelor's gown. Some gowns expose a [[necktie]] or [[cravat]] when closed. They are designed to be worn open or closed in the front.<ref name="Eugene Sullivan 2001"/>
Members of the Board of Trustees or other governing body officers of a college or university, regardless of their degrees, are entitled to wear doctor's gowns, faced only with black velvet and black velvet bars on the sleeves. However, their hoods (''see'', below) may be only those of the degree actually held by the wearer (or one specially prescribed by the institution).<ref>Eugene Sullivan, ‘Academic Costume Code and Ceremony Guide,’ American Colleges and Universities, 16 ed., New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2001, p. 1860, ''Some Permissible Exceptions.''</ref> The color standardization for the outside shell of the hood as black provides flexibility of use and helps facilitate this practice.
==Hoods== [[File:Caltech hood.jpg|thumb|The doctoral hood of the [[California Institute of Technology]]. Note the blue velvet ''trim'' indicating philosophy; for degrees other than the Ph.D., the trim's color corresponds to the subject of the degree being awarded. The ''interior lining'' shows the [[school colors]], in this case orange and white.]]
The hood's coloring and size represents the type and subject of degree earned, as well as the institution from which it was awarded. Though no shape is specified in the Code, American bachelors and masters usually wear the Wales simple shape ([s5] in the [[Groves classification system]]) with a split salmon cut; doctors wear the same shape but with "panels" attached to the sides.<ref name="Stephen Wolgast 2009 pp. 16-17"/>
* '''Shell''' - The Code calls for the shell material of the hood to match the robe, and for the color to be black regardless of the color of the robe being worn.<ref name=SullivanHoods>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Hoods''</ref> * '''Interior lining''' - The interior lining, generally satin, is worn so as to display the colors of the institution from which the wearer received the degree; if more than one color is used, they are usually in the pattern of [[chevron (insignia)|chevrons]] or equal divisions.<ref name=SullivanTrimmingsGowns>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Hoods'';''Linings''</ref> * '''Trim''' - The outer edge of the cowl (around the opening if one would put it over one's head if wearing it as an actual hood) is [[trim (sewing)|trimmed]] in [[velvet]] or [[velveteen]].<ref name=SullivanTrimmingsHoods/> The width of the trim is 2 inches, 3 inches, and 5 inches for the bachelor's, master's and doctorate degrees, respectively.<ref name=SullivanTrimmingsHoods/> In most American colleges and universities, the color of the velvet hood trimming is distinctive of the academic field, or as closely related as possible, to which the degree earned pertains (see ''[[Academic regalia in the United States#Intercollegiate colors|Inter-Collegiate colors]]'', below).<ref>Eugene Sullivan, ‘Academic Costume Code and Ceremony Guide,’ American Colleges and Universities, 16 ed., New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2001, p. 1860, ''Additional Guidance on Costume.''</ref> For instance, one who has earned a [[Master of Arts]] in Journalism would wear velvet trim of crimson to signify "journalism", rather than white to represent "[[liberal arts|arts]]." Trim colors should not be combined or displayed together in any way to attempt to indicate more than one academic field.<ref>Eugene Sullivan, ‘Academic Costume Code and Ceremony Guide,’ American Colleges and Universities, 16 ed., New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2001, p. 1861.</ref> * '''Length''' - The length of the hood will vary with the level of academic achievement as well: bachelors wear a 3 foot length, masters a 3.5 foot length, and doctors a 4 foot length.<ref>Eugene Sullivan, ‘Academic Costume Code and Ceremony Guide,’ American Colleges and Universities, 16 ed., New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2001, p. 1860, ''Hoods'';''Length.''</ref> Only the doctoral hood will have "panels" at the sides of the hood that lie [[cape]]-like across the back.
Candidates may have the hood ceremoniously placed upon them, as is done at some British universities, or a college or school may 'self-hood' ''en masse'' at the appropriate time during the ceremony.<ref>[http://www.fordham.edu/download/downloads/id/1463/information_for_masters_and_doctoral_candidates.pdf|University Commencement Guide for master’s and doctoral candidates | May 2015]. Accessed 05/26/2015</ref> Additionally, the Code allows for the wearing of the hood into the commencement ceremony as part of the academic procession, but only if neither of the two procedures above are being employed.<ref name=SullivanWearing>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Wearing the Costume''</ref> The Code also states: "It is quite appropriate for the bachelor's gown to be worn without a hood."<ref name="Eugene Sullivan 2001"/> Many institutions, particularly larger ones, have therefore dispensed with the bachelor's hood at commencement ceremonies altogether, though a graduate is still entitled to wear one once the degree is conferred.<ref name="Eugene Sullivan 2001"/> Both honorary and earned doctoral degrees are very often conferred by the highest academic officer of an institution bestowing the appropriate hood at the [[podium]], regardless of the procedure being followed for other candidates at the ceremony.
Only one hood should be worn at any given time.<ref name=SullivanWearing/> The regalia indicating the highest degree attained is usually worn, though the Code seems to allow for a graduate to revert for some occasion to the entire academic costume of a lesser degree earned. Those who hold multiple degrees of the same level (i.e. more than one master's or doctorate degree) may wear at any given time the regalia, in its entirety, of any one degree earned.<ref name=SullivanWearing /> The Code does not allow for 'mixing-and-matching.' The one exception is for officers of the academic institution who, while wearing a doctoral gown of the University being served, may display one hood from any degree earned from any institution.(see ''[[#Academic robes (gowns)|Academic robes]]'', above).<ref name=SullivanExceptions>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Some Permissible Exceptions''</ref>
==Headwear== [[File:DrKing.jpg|thumb|right|[[William Lyon Mackenzie King]] in his Harvard doctoral robes in 1919, holding his mortarboard cap in his lap]] Headwear is an important component of cap-and-gown, and the academic costume is not complete without it. The headwear may vary with the level of academic achievement and, to some extent, on the individual academic institution's specifications.
*'''Caps''' - The [[mortarboard]] cap is recommended in the Code, and the material required to match the gown, with the exception that doctoral regalia can instead use a velvet four-, six-, or eight-sided [[tam (cap)|tam]], but the four-sided mortarboard-shaped tam in velvet is what the Code seems to recommend here; the only color called for is black, in all cases<ref name=SullivanCaps>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Caps''</ref> During graduation ceremonies in the United States, both women and men wear caps, and both women and men wear their caps indoors throughout most of the ceremony, except for men during a [[baccalaureate service]], the [[national anthem]] ("[[The Star-Spangled Banner]]"), any [[benediction]] that may be offered by a [[chaplain]] or other authority, and sometimes the singing of the [[alma mater]] if the local custom requires it.<ref name=SullivanWearing /> Although military and civil uniform, national costume, and clerical garb etc. are worn beneath the academic robe, traditionally only the [[biretta]] in conjunction with clerical garb will replace the academic cap. All other costumes forgo the normal headwear in favor of the appropriate academic version. *'''Tassel''' - The tassel worn on the mortarboard or a tam seems to provide, by tradition, the greatest opportunity for latitude in American academic dress. It has been black, or represented the university's colors, or the colors of the specific college, or the discipline. The tassel has also been used to indicate membership in national [[honor society|honor societies]] or other awards. However, strictly speaking, the Code states that "The tassel should be black or the color appropriate to the subject," and only makes an exception for the gold tassel, which is reserved for those entitled to wear the doctoral gown. Only one tassel is worn at a time.<ref name=SullivanCaps />
There is at some colleges and universities a practice of moving the tassel from one side to the other on graduating, but this is a modern innovation that would be impractical out of doors due to the vagaries of the wind. However, this mark of transition to graduate status has the benefit of taking less time than more traditional indicators such as the individual conferring of the hood or a complete change of dress part-way through the ceremony (as at Oxford in the United Kingdom). In such universities it is common for undergraduates to begin the commencement ceremony with their tassels on the right. Switching the tassel to the left may be done individually or as a group. For doctoral and masters students, the tassel commonly begins and remains on the left.<ref name=SullivanWearing />
==Other adornments==
A number of other items such as [[honor cords|cords]], [[academic stole|stoles]], [[aiguillette]]s, representing various academic achievements or other honors are also worn at the discretion of some degree-granting institutions. The Code disapproves of their use on or over academic regalia, saying that "shoes and other articles of visible apparel worn by graduates should be of dark colors that harmonize with the academic costume. Nothing else should be worn on the academic gown."<ref name=SullivanWearing />
Apparel and tokens representing awards and honors are not considered a component of academic dress, not only because the Code suggests avoiding them, but also because (a) they are often worn without the defining cap and gown, and (b) they are usually not worn by a graduate with academic robes after the Commencement year in which the honor was awarded. Nevertheless, they are often seen with academic regalia in the United States, and are therefore mentioned here.
*'''Medals/medallions''' - When worn about the neck, [[medals]]/medallions may not be in conflict with the Code if worn beneath the hood and visible only with the gown open. The Code's exception is only for special regalia for a chief [[Marshal#Ceremonial|marshal]], the university or college president, etc. which may include medallions or other devices symbolic of the office.<ref name="SullivanExceptions"/> As a medallion in this case is symbolic of the office and not academic achievement, once the wearer leaves the office they are no longer entitled to wear it. Therefore, it is not a component of an individual's academic regalia, but a component of the regalia for the office. *'''Honor cord''' - [[Honor cords]] usually consist of twisted cords with tassels on either end. They are sometimes awarded for various academic achievements, or to members of [[honor society|honor societies]]. Often, cords come in pairs with a knot in the middle to hold them together. Sashes, stoles, or medallions are also awarded in place of cords. Any of these items are customarily worn with non-academic attire, as well. With cap and gown, and hood when utilized, some educational institutions have permitted these cords to complement the regalia of a [[high school]] or [[university]] candidate, ignoring the ACE Code to the contrary. Unlike hoods, tassels and stoles, custom allows more than one cord to be worn at the same time.
== Intercollegiate colors == The colors allocated to the various fields of learning have been largely standardized in the United States by the Intercollegiate Bureau of Academic Costume,<ref>The History of Academic Costume in America. Cotrell & Leonard, Albany, N.Y., Intercollegiate bureau of academic costume. Printed and distributed for the Intercollegiate bureau of academic costume, by Cotrell & Leonard, 1936</ref> and accepted by the American Council on Education in its ''Academic Costume Code.''<ref name=SullivanTrimmingsGowns /> The color assigned to a given hood trim and/or tassels and—where appropriate—gown facings, should be as closely related as possible to the field studied.<ref name="ReferenceA">Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Additional Guidance on Costume''</ref> For example, one who has earned a degree in [[animal husbandry]] would wear the maize of agriculture, as no color is specific to the subject of animal husbandry, and it is generally included within the broader field of agriculture. Less simply, [[mathematics]] is traditionally among the liberal arts, which are represented by white, but can also be considered a [[formal science]], represented by golden yellow for science.
The codified colors associated with the different [[List of academic disciplines|academic disciplines]] are as shown below:
<!-- Some of the links for the color names are different than the color names given by the ACE. This is because the links take the reader to the color closest to that actually used by the ACE and academic hood manufacturers. So, when reading the article, one will see a close representation of the color and the ACE name for the color, and can click on the name to be taken to the article on the actual color used. --> {| class="wikitable" |- ! Faculty ! Color ! Sample |- | [[Agriculture]] | [[Maize (color)|Maize]] | style="background:#FBEC5D;"| |- | [[Liberal arts|Arts]] (''Liberal Arts''), [[literature|Letters]] (''Literature''), [[Humanities]] | [[White]] | style="background:white;"| |- | [[Commerce]], [[Accountancy]], [[Business_education#Undergraduate_education|Business]] | [[Drab (color)|Drab]] | style="background:#bc987e;"| |- | [[Dentistry]] | [[Lilac (color)|Lilac]] | style="background:#c8a2c8;"| |- | [[Economics]] | [[Copper (color)|Copper]] | style="background:#da8a67;"| |- | [[Education]] | [[Light blue (color)|Light Blue]] | style="background:#66ccff;"| |- | [[Engineering]] | [[Orange (color)|Orange]] | style="background:#ff7f00;"| |- | [[Fine art|Fine Arts]], [[Architecture]] | [[Brown]] | style="background:#654321;"| |- | [[Forestry]], [[Environmental studies|Environmental Studies]], [[Sustainability studies|Sustainability]] | [[Auburn (color)|Russet]] | style="background:#932724;"| |- | [[Journalism]] | [[Crimson]] | style="background:crimson;"| |- | [[Law]] | [[Purple]] | style="background:purple;"| |- | [[Library science|Library Science]], [[Information Management]] | [[Lemon (color)|Lemon]] | style="background:#ff0;"| |- | [[Medicine]] | [[Kelly green|Green]] | style="background:#00a550;"|<!-- While "Pharmacy", "Nursing", "Manual therapy", etc. are indeed included in the broader field of health care, they are here differentiated from "Medicine". A rule of thumb for these purposes is that any field that primarily requires the identification of an ailment and prescribes treatment is included in "Medicine", while the disciplines that provide that treatment (such as the aforementioned "Pharmacy", "Nursing", etc.) may be logically covered under other fields of learning, represented by a different academic color. "Dentistry" identifies ailments and treatment but is assigned its own color, perhaps owing to its unique development from the barber profession. --> |- | [[Musicology|Music]] | [[Pink]] | style="background:#ffb6c1;"| |- | [[Nursing]] | [[Apricot (color)|Apricot]] | style="background:#f0a900;"| |- | [[Public speaking|Oratory]], [[Communications studies]], [[Broadcasting]]<!-- This is beyond the field of television or radio journalism, which would be covered by "journalism", above - but broadcasting for any and all purposes --> | [[Silver (color)|Silver Gray]] | style="background:silver;"| |- | [[Pharmacy]] | [[Myrtle (color)|Olive Green]] | style="background:#21421e;"| |- | [[Philosophy]] | [[Dark Blue (color)|Dark Blue]] | style="background:darkblue;"| |- | [[Physical education|Physical Education]], [[Manual Therapy]], [[Physical Therapy]] | [[Olive (color)|Sage Green]] | style="background:#6b8e23;"| |- | [[Public administration|Public Administration]], [[Public policy|Public Policy]], [[Diplomacy|Foreign Service]] | [[Blue-green|Peacock Blue]] | style="background:#0D98BA;"| |- | [[Public health|Public Health]] | [[Salmon (color)|Salmon Pink]] | style="background:salmon;"| |- | [[Science]] ([[Social sciences|''Social'']], [[Natural science|''Natural'']] and [[Formal science|''Formal'']]) | [[Gold_(color)#Golden_Yellow|Golden yellow]] | style="background:#ffdf00;"| |- | [[Social work|Social Work]] | [[Shades of brown#Sandy brown|Citron]] | style="background:#f4a460;"| |- | [[Theology]], [[Divinity (academic discipline)|Divinity]] | [[Scarlet (color)|Scarlet]] | style="background:#f00;"| |- | [[Veterinary medicine|Veterinary Science]] | [[Grey]] | style="background:gray;"| |}
The code calls for a graduate to display the color of the subject of the degree obtained, not the degree itself.<ref name=SullivanTrimmingsHoods>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, Hoods, ''Trimmings''</ref> For example, if a graduate is awarded a [[Bachelor of Arts]] (BA) degree in business, the trimming should be drab, representing commerce/accountancy/business, rather than white, representing the broader arts/letters/humanities; if the BA were in economics, the trim would be copper; if in environmental studies, it would be russet, and so on. If the BA were in a language, a subject within the humanities and not otherwise assigned a unique color, the velvet would indeed be white. Similarly, if a [[Bachelor of Science]] (BS) degree is awarded for physics, the velvet trim should be golden yellow, representing physics as one of the [[natural science]]s; however, if the BS were in engineering, the trim would be orange, or if in education, the trim would be light blue. The same method is true of master's degrees and doctorates: a [[Master of Public Administration]] in Science and Technology should show trim of golden yellow for science, not peacock blue for public administration; conversely a [[Master of Science]] in Public Administration should display peacock blue trim for public administration and not golden yellow for science.
Additionally, it is problematic when a field of study that does not have its own color assigned to it has been considered to be included in more than one discipline, which are represented by different colors. For example, history has traditionally been considered as among the humanities, represented by white, but is also considered a [[social science]], which can be represented by golden yellow. This is often addressed by an academic institution allowing the degree earned to influence - but not ''determine'' - color assignment. For instance, a Bachelor of Arts graduate in history might display white, while a Bachelor of Science graduate in history at the same institution could properly display golden yellow, and ''vice versa''. This then can create confusion in the first instance by appearing to display colors based on the degree earned rather than, as stipulated in the Code, the academic field studied.
In 1986, the American Council on Education updated the Code and added the following sentence clarifying the use of the color dark blue for the [[Doctor of Philosophy]] degree, which is awarded in any number of fields: <blockquote>"In the case of the Doctor of Philosophy (Ph.D.) degree, the dark blue color is used to represent the mastery of the discipline of learning and scholarship in any field that is attested to by the awarding of the degree, and it is not intended to represent the field of philosophy."<ref name=SullivanTrimmingsHoods/></blockquote> The [[doctorate]] other than the Ph.D. will be represented by the colors indicated above. For example, the [[Doctor of Education]] (Ed.D.) in Public Health should display salmon pink for public health, not light blue for education, and the [[Doctor of Public Health]] (DrPH) in Public Administration should display peacock blue for public administration, not salmon pink for public health. The [[Doctor of Engineering]] (D.Eng.) degree, if no further specialization was made, should be represented by orange, and the [[Doctor of Ministry]] (D.Min.) by scarlet if no further specialization, etc.
==History== [[File:James McCulloch in undergraduate robes.JPG|thumb|An American student in undergraduate academic dress during the colonial period.]]
===Colonial period=== The practice of wearing academic regalia in what is now the United States dates to the [[Colonial Colleges]] period, and was heavily influenced by European practices and styles.<ref name=overview>Sullivan. The Academic Costume Code, ''Historical Overview''</ref> Students at the College of New Jersey (now [[Princeton University]]) and at King's College (now [[Columbia University|Columbia]]) were required to wear their "college habits" at all times starting in 1755 at Princeton<ref>Donald Drakeman, "'Peculiar Habits': Academic Costumes at Princeton University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 59.</ref> and in 1763 at Columbia.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 82.</ref> Shortly after the beginning of the nineteenth century, however, academic dress was rarely worn on a daily basis, according to contemporary sources.<ref>Nicholas Hoffmann, "Crow's Feet and Crimson: Academic Dress at Harvard," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 43-4; Donald Drakeman, "'Peculiar Habits': Academic Costumes at Princeton University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 60; Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 89.</ref>
===Nineteenth century=== After the [[American Civil War]], academic dress was generally only worn at ceremonies or when representing the institution,<ref name='Princeton Regalia 5-6'>{{cite book | last = Smagorinsky| first = Margaret |title=The Regalia of Princeton University: Pomp, Circumstance, and Accountrements of Academia (sic)|publisher=Princeton University Office of Printing and Mailing |location=[[Princeton, New Jersey]] |year=1994|isbn= |pages=5–6 |doi= }} [http://tigernet.princeton.edu/~ptoniana/regalia.pdf Online Edition] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521175636/http://tigernet.princeton.edu/~ptoniana/regalia.pdf |date=May 21, 2011 }}. Retrieved: 2011-04-05</ref> although in some instances the practice has persisted, such as at [[Sewanee: The University of the South|Sewanee]], where members of one student society continue to wear the gown to class.<ref name='Sewanee Gownsmen'>{{cite web|url=http://www.sewanee.edu/og/about |title=About - Sewanee: The University of the South |accessdate=2011-04-05 |last= |first= |date=n.d. |publisher=Sewanee: The University of the South |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100529201410/http://www.sewanee.edu/og/about |archivedate=2010-05-29 }}</ref>
Although universities that adopted academic dress assigned specific meanings to them, there was no consistency among the various sets of rules. For example, when the [[University of Pennsylvania]] adopted its academic dress statute in April 1887 it abolished hoods. Instead, it assigned eight faculty colors<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 36 and Chart 1.</ref> that were shown on the gowns’ yokes (the portion over the shoulders).<ref>Stephen Wolgast, compiler, "Timeline of Developments in Academic Dress in North America," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 215.</ref>
Columbia adopted an academic dress statute in December of that year.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 94.</ref> It included the first known American inclusion of the three velvet stripes on the sleeves. Both doctors and masters wore black gowns with sleeve stripes and facing; for masters the velvet was always black, and for doctors the velvet was always purple. Columbia also approved a scarlet gown for doctors’ use on “festal” occasions.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 96 and Fig. 2, p. 97.</ref> Earlier, three stripes adorned the sleeve of a gown depicted in an invitation to Class Day ceremonies at Columbia in 1865.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 96.</ref>
When New York University adopted its own academic dress in 1891, like Columbia it added the three sleeve stripes but permitted them to be worn in the university’s faculty colors. It also adopted the Edinburgh shape in the ([s4] in the [[Groves classification system]]) for its hoods.<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 10-11, 37.</ref> Although NYU gave up this shape when the Code was adopted, Harvard adopted it for all its graduates in 1902.<ref>Nicholas Hoffmann, "Crow's Feet and Crimson: Academic Dress at Harvard," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 48-49</ref>
Also starting in 1891, Princeton graduates wore a black gown with an orange stripe between the shoulders, making it perhaps the first American gown in a university’s corporate colors.<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 11.</ref>
These weren’t the only pre-Code gowns in America that departed from black. Hampden-Sydney started using gray gowns in 1893,<ref>Stephen Wolgast, compiler, “Timeline of Developments in Academic Dress in North America,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 215.</ref> and the University of the South approved gowns for its higher degrees in the same shapes and colors of Oxford. However, since the university at the time conferred only honorary master’s and doctoral degrees, it’s unknown if anyone ever wore the Oxford-style gowns.<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 11 and Chart 2, p. 36.</ref>
====Intercollegiate Code on Academic Costume==== [[File:ICC Master Gown and Hood.JPG|thumb|right|An American master's gown from 1911 with the slit located at the elbow rather than at the crescent arc and hood in [[Groves classification system|''[s1] simple'' shape]].]]
In June 1893, the trustees of Princeton appointed one of their members, John J. McCook, to look into creating an academic costume that showed the wearer’s degree, faculty, and alma mater, and to discuss the concept with Columbia, Yale, Harvard and other universities with the goal being “the adoption of a uniform academic costume.”<ref>Donald Drakeman, "'Peculiar Habits': Academic Costumes at Princeton University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 14.</ref>
Columbia hosted the meeting with delegates from Princeton (McCook), Yale and New York University attending, and as a “technical adviser” Gardner Cotrell Leonard, whose Albany, N.Y., firm manufactured academic dress. (Harvard waited until 1902 to adopt its academic dress statute, which is recognizable for its inclusion of the university’s nineteenth-century crows’ feet and the use of the Edinburgh simple shape hood [s4]).<ref>Nicholas Hoffmann, "Crow's Feet and Crimson: Academic Dress at Harvard," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 44 ff.</ref> The meeting took place in either 1894 or 1895 and adopted the Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume on March 16, 1895.<ref>Robert Armagost, “University Uniforms: The Standardization of Academic Dress in the United States,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 140.</ref> The Code was based on Columbia’s existing statute,<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 16.</ref> and prescribed the cut and style and materials of the gowns, as well as eight colors representing fields of learning.<ref>New York Times. "Gowns for College Men; Academic Costumes in American Universities (1896): Plan to Secure a Uniform Practice in the Use of the Caps and Gowns in This Country So that the Degree of the Wearer, the Faculty Under Whom It Was Obtained, and the Institution Conferring It May Be Readily Seen." Sunday, April 26, 1896.</ref> The descriptions, however, are vague compared to the descriptions of academic costume in Europe.<ref>William Gibson, “The Regulation of Undergraduate Dress at Oxford and Cambridge, 1660-1832,” [[Burgon Society]] Annual 2004, and W. N. Hargreaves-Mawdsley, A History of Academical Dress in Europe until the End of the Eighteenth Century (Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1963; reprinted Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, 1978); best read with Alex Kerr, “Hargreaves-Mawdsley's History of Academical Dress and the Pictorial Evidence for Great Britain and Ireland: Notes and Corrections,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 8 (2008), pp. 106-50.</ref> For example, no particular shape of hood was specified in the Code (nor has one ever been). The version Americans typically wear is the Wales simple shape [s5] with a split-salmon cut. In the late nineteenth century it was the shape worn by Oxford bachelors; today it is worn by graduates of the University of Wales.<ref name="Stephen Wolgast 2009 pp. 16-17">Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 16-17.</ref>
Since 1895, several changes have been made to the Code.
===Twentieth century===
====1932====
In 1932 the [[American Council on Education]] (ACE) authorized the appointment of a committee "to determine whether revision and completion of the academic code adopted by the conference of the colleges and universities in 1895 is desirable at this time, and, if so, to draft a revised code and present a plan for submitting the code to the consideration of the institutional members of the Council." The committee essentially adopted the Code in whole<ref name="Stephen Wolgast 2009 p. 23">Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 23.</ref> and changed it in two ways:
*The master’s hood shrank from four feet to three-and-one-half feet; and *The chevron was added to the Code to be used in the hood lining when more than one color appeared.
====1959====
A Committee on Academic Costumes and Ceremonies, appointed by the American Council on Education in 1959, again reviewed the academic dress code and made several changes. They took effect as of 1960. The significant alterations included:<ref name="Stephen Wolgast 2009 p. 23"/>
*Moving the arm slit on the master’s gown sleeve from above the elbow to the wrist; *Specifying that the arc cut from the master’s gown sleeve was in the front; *Permitting masters’ and doctors’ gowns to be worn either closed or opened; *The first connection of color to discipline instead of faculty (i.e. a Master of Science in Agriculture wears maize, not golden yellow); *Adding soft, square caps for women as an alternative to the mortarboard; *Tassels in colors other than black; and *The suggestion that hoods be worn by candidates for the degrees they were about to receive (so that they would not have to be hooded individually).<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 25-28.</ref> These changes were approved in March 1959. In April, the Committee approved the use of maroon for home economy. The color has never been included in any edition of the ACE book.<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 28.</ref>
As part of the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|socio-political upheaval of the 1960s]] in many [[Western cultures]], eschewing academic regalia became a popular means of demonstrating [[anti-establishment]] views, particularly in response to the [[Vietnam War]] and the [[Civil Rights Movement]] in the United States. [[Protests against the Vietnam War|Student protests]], which had the effect of cancelling graduation ceremonies at some American universities, led to a general relaxing of protocols on academic attire and ceremonial pageantry.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} After the war, academic regalia continued to be shunned by some who considered it a symbol of [[elitism]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}} However, since the 1980s, academic regalia has been in resurgence. Some colleges or academic departments allow graduating students to vote on whether or not to wear academic regalia at graduation ceremonies.{{Citation needed|date=December 2011}}
====1973==== More changes were approved by the Committee in 1973, following the “large numbers of requests for advice about academic dress” received by the Committee.<ref name="Stephen Wolgast 2009 p. 29">Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 29.</ref> The important changes, which first appeared in the 11th edition of the ACE book (published in 1973), include: *Permitting for associates’ degrees a “flat shield hood,” which properly speaking is a cape, and which was first used by Columbia for its bachelors and doctors in 1963; *Permitting for six-year specialist degrees, such as the Master of Arts in Teaching, a hood whose length was 3 feet 9 inches (which is halfway between the master’s 3-foot, 6-inch hood and the doctor’s 4-foot hood), and whose edging was 4 inches wide (which is halfway between the three inches for masters and five inches for doctors); and *The addition of an “alternate color” for Business, Accountancy and Commerce: Sapphire blue. Its use was recommended against in the description, and no explanation for its addition was mentioned.<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 29-30.</ref>
The 11th edition also included a contradiction in selecting a faculty color. Since 1960 the color was to be connected not to the title of the degree but to the discipline studied (e.g. a Bachelor of Arts in Music would wear pink, for music, instead of white etc.). That suggestion remained in the 11th edition, but in another paragraph was the opposite direction: “For the hood, the border [i.e. the edging of the cowl] should be white if the degree is awarded in arts (B.A. or M.A.), golden yellow if in science (B.S. or M.S.).”<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 30.</ref>
Doctors had similarly confusing advice. Interdisciplinary doctorates could wear the faculty color of any of a number of fields. “Thus,” the 1973 Code states, “urban affairs may be distinguished by copper (economics), peacock blue (public administration), or another field already assigned ...”<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 30-31.</ref>
====1987====
Doctoral degrees were clarified in 1987 when all Ph.D. graduates were to wear dark blue as their faculty color. While this was the most visible of changes that took effect that year, it was hardly the only one, and it wasn’t the only change that involved color. Some of the other changes included:<ref>Stephen Wolgast et al., "The Intercollegiate Code of Academic Costume: An Introduction," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 32.</ref> *Dropping the specification of material for the gown and hood (it had been cotton, silk or rayon); *Eliminating sapphire blue as an alternative color for Commerce, Accountancy and Business; *Removing the women’s soft, square cap as an alternative to the mortarboard; *Pointing out that “[n]othing else should be worn on the academic gown” aside from the prescribed costume; *Omitting the light blue gown for the Associate of Arts in teacher education, while leaving grey gowns as the suggestion for all associates’ degrees.
====Rules vs guide====
Although readers of the Code may believe it to be an enforceable edict, the current version of the Code points out its permissive nature: “… it is impossible (and probably undesirable) to lay down enforceable rules with respect to academic costume. The governing force is tradition and the continuity of academic symbols from the Middle Ages. The tradition should be departed from as little as possible … ”<ref name="Eugene Sullivan 2001">Eugene Sullivan, ‘Academic Costume Code and Ceremony Guide,’ American Colleges and Universities, 16 ed., New York: Walter de Gruyter, 2001, p. 1860.</ref> In addition, the Committee wrote a memo in 1967 that makes the point directly, pointing out that “the general guidelines are as stated and should not be interpreted as supported by highly detailed and hard-and-fast regulations on file in some central place.”<ref name="Stephen Wolgast 2009 p. 29"/>
===Twenty-first century===
Although today in the U.S. academic dress is rarely worn outside [[Graduation|commencement]] ceremonies or other academic rituals such as [[encaenia]] and [[baccalaureate service]]s, those graduation ceremonies have gained in popularity and have expanded to high school graduations, middle school, elementary school and even kindergarten graduation ceremonies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rhymeuniversity.com |title=Kindergarten graduation in the United States |publisher=Rhymeuniversity.com |date= |accessdate=2010-04-28| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100510095619/http://rhymeuniversity.com/| archivedate= 10 May 2010 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Special academic regalia of United States universities== More than 400 universities in the U.S. grant the doctoral degree.<ref>[http://www.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ous/international/usnei/us/edlite-institutions-us.html] U.S. Department of Education, U.S. Network for Education Information, Institutions and Programs.</ref> Of them, more than 125 use academic dress for their doctors that varies from the guidelines found in the code.<ref>David T. Boven, “American Universities’ Departure from the Academic Costume Code,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 159.</ref> Some universities limit their unique costumes for doctors only; others provide it for doctors and masters; some provide it for the upper degrees and bachelors too.
Unique academic dress typically separates itself from the Code’s standards through color. While the Code sanctions black for gowns at the bachelor’s level and above (and grey gowns for the associate’s degree), several American colleges in the late nineteenth century had adopted colored academic dress (see ''History'', above). When the Code was approved in 1895, black became the only approved color for gowns, caps, and hood shells.
As early as 1912, however, uniformity was challenged. Brown adopted mortarboards for its trustees and fellows in the university color, seal brown.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 100.</ref> In 1938 Yale began using Yale blue gowns for its masters’ and doctors’ academic dress.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 105.</ref>
In 1950 Syracuse began using orange gowns for its academic officers, but not for graduates.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 112.</ref> Rochester created a red gown for its president and a black gown with gold trim for some of its officers in 1954.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, compiler, “Timeline of Developments in Academic Dress in North America,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 217.</ref> In the next year, Harvard adopted crimson for the gowns of its Ph.D. holders. (Later, all Harvard doctors but the J.D. would wear the crimson gown.)<ref>Nicholas Hoffmann, "Crow's Feet and Crimson: Academic Dress at Harvard," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 51.</ref>
Other Ivy League universities soon followed suit. Princeton adopted a doctoral gown in 1960 whose shape differed slightly from the Code’s standard. The sleeves were somewhat shorter and they were lined in orange; the gown was black with orange trim.<ref>Donald Drakeman, "'Peculiar Habits': Academic Costumes at Princeton University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 70.</ref> The standard shape was recently authorized by Princeton; both are permitted today.<ref>Donald Drakeman, "'Peculiar Habits': Academic Costumes at Princeton University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 71.</ref> Columbia debuted its light blue gowns for all graduates in 1963, following failed attempts in 1948 and 1958 to adopt colored gowns.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 116.</ref> The gowns Columbia has used since 1963, designed by [[Jacques Barzun]], have a pair of crowns below the yoke; on the bachelor’s and master’s gown they are embroidered onto a tab while they are embroidered directly into the velvet facing of the doctoral gown.<ref>Stephen Wolgast, "King's Crowns: The History of Academic Dress at King's College and Columbia University," Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 117.</ref> Pennsylvania’s distinctive doctoral gown was first used in 1964. It is red but the lower ends of the sleeves are blue.<ref>David T. Boven, “American Universities’ Departure from the Academic Costume Code,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), p. 163.</ref>
Deviations from the Code generally fall into one of five categories.<ref>David T. Boven, “American Universities’ Departure from the Academic Costume Code,” Transactions of the [[Burgon Society]] 9 (2009), pp. 160-68.</ref> Referring to doctoral gowns, these are: *Adding piping, usually in the university color, around the velvet trim on a black gown; *Changing the velvet trim to the university color; *Changing the gown to the university color; *Changing both the color of the gown and the color of the velvet trim to other than black or faculty color; or *Changing the shape of the gown and/or its trim (e.g. [[Academic dress of Stanford University|Stanford]] and [[Stony Brook University]]).

Doctoral gowns purchased are dark green and come with an eight sided tam. | | |- | [[University of Michigan]] | Maize with blue chevrons | Black with velvet lining in color that varies based on subject of degree conferred | Black tam with tassel in color that varies based on subject of degree conferred | | | |{{Citation needed|date=June 2012}} |- | [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln]] | Scarlet and cream | Black | | | | |,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://commencement.unl.edu/academic-attire |title=University of Nebraska Commencement |publisher=unl.edu |accessdate=2013-12-03 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20131204024656/http://commencement.unl.edu/academic-attire |archive-date=2013-12-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://wdn.unl.edu/resources/colors/ |title=UNL Colors |publisher=unl.edu |accessdate=2013-12-03}}</ref> |- | [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]] | [[Carolina Blue]] with two white chevrons | [[Carolina Blue]] with Royal Blue velvet and white piping | Royal Blue 6 sided tam | Seal of the University of North Carolina | Bachelor's gowns are light blue with white velvet facings. Master's gowns are black. | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://store107.collegestoreonline.com/ePOS/form=cat.html&cat=294&store=107 |title=University of North Carolina Doctoral Robe from Student Store |publisher=UNC Student Stores |date= |accessdate=2011-11-28}}</ref> |- |[[University of North Texas]] |Green and White with green shell |Green gown, Black velvet |Black velvet six-pointed tam, gold bullion tassel | |[https://tsgs.unt.edu/ Robert B. Toulouse School of Graduate Studies] medallion given to doctoral graduates. Baccalaureates wear a green gown. Masters graduates wear a black gown with green panels and hood lined in green and white. |[[File:UNT-regalia.jpg|180x180px]] |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://commencement.unt.edu/regalia-overview|title=Regalia Overview {{!}} Commencement|website=commencement.unt.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-05-06}}</ref> |- | [[University of Notre Dame]] | Gold | Royal and navy blue with gold trim | Royal blue octagonal tam | University shield in gold | |[[File:President Barack Obama at Notre Dame University 05-17-09.jpg|130px]] |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://commencement.nd.edu/commencement-traditions/academic-attire |title=University of Notre Dame Commencement - Academic Attire |publisher=nd.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-05-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110813213253/http://commencement.nd.edu/commencement-traditions/academic-attire/ |archive-date=2011-08-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> |- | [[University of Oklahoma]] |Crimson and cream |Black with crimson velvet |Black hexagonal tam |none |The bachelor's and master's gowns include the OU Seal on the left chest. | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://graduate.ouhsc.edu/CurrentStudents/Graduation.aspx#231731132-caps-and-gowns-how-to-guide |title=OUHSC Graduate College Caps and Gowns: How-To Guide |publisher=graduate.ouhsc.edu |accessdate=2017-05-04}}</ref> |- | [[University of Pennsylvania]] | Red with blue chevron | Red and blue | Blue hexagonal tam | none | |[[File:Jodie Foster at University of Pennsylvania's 250th Commencement (cropped).jpg|150x150px]] |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.upenn.edu/commencement/hist/costume.html |title=University of Pennsylvania - Academic Regalia |publisher=Upenn.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-04-04}}</ref> |- | [[University of Rochester]] | Yellow | Blue Black and Yellow Velvet Trim | Blue Hexagonal Tam |Dandelion emblem on left | | | |- | [[The University of Texas at Austin]] | Traditional orange and white | [[Burnt orange]] | Six-cornered velvet tam | UT Tower in gold | | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.utexas.edu/commencement/2011/regalia.html |title=Custom Doctor's Regalia |publisher=utexas.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-09-05}}</ref> |- | [[University of Virginia]] | Varies by school or college | Navy with navy velvet panels and orange trim | Navy hexagonal tam | Stylized [[The Rotunda (University of Virginia)|Rotunda]] logo | | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uvabookstores.com/site_graduation_regalia.asp |title=Graduation Regalia |publisher=The UVa Bookstore |date= |accessdate=2012-01-15}}</ref> |- | [[University of Washington]] | Purple | Purple with purple velvet panels and gold trim | Purple hexagonal tam | none | All doctoral robes and hoods are purple and gold, regardless of degree specifics. | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washington.edu/graduation/cap-gown/|title=Student Academic Attire|access-date=2016-09-09|publisher=[[University of Washington]]}}</ref> |- | [[University of Wisconsin–Madison]] | Cardinal red | Black with red velvet panels and facings. | Black octagonal tam | University logo | | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uwbookstore.com/SiteText.aspx?id=1763 |title= Doctoral Academic Attire Purchase Information |publisher=University of Wisconsin-Madison |accessdate=2018-05-02}}</ref> |- |[[Vanderbilt University]] |Antique Gold with black chevron |Antique Gold with black facings |Black tam |Vanderbilt "V" mark |PhD graduates only wear the gold and black gown; professional doctorates wear a black gown with Vanderbilt "V" mark facing in gold.
From 2005 through 2014, Vanderbilt's PhD gowns were in a modified form of the Cambridge doctor gown [d1], in black with gold facings. | |<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vanderbilt.edu/commencement/archives/regalia.php/|title=Commencement at Vanderbilt University|website=Commencement at Vanderbilt University|access-date=2016-05-28}}</ref> |- | [[Villanova University]] | Blue and white | | Blue hexagonal tam | none | | | {{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} |- | [[Virginia Tech]] | Maroon with orange chevron | Black with maroon velvet lined with orange | Maroon hexagonal tam | University seal in light maroon | Bachelor and master gowns are black and has two flaps on each breast of the gown depicting the university shield and motto in maroon and orange. Traditional black doctoral gowns with black velvet facings and stripes are accepted and are available at a cheaper price. |[[File:Virginia Tech PhD regalia.jpg|frameless|167x167px]] |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oakhalli.com/schools.php |title=Academic Regalia - Oak Hall Cap and Gown |publisher=oakhalli.com |date= |accessdate=2011-11-28 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110408081136/http://oakhalli.com/schools.php |archive-date=2011-04-08 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bookstore.vt.edu/ePOS?this_category=1221&store=109&form=shared3%2fgm%2fmain.html&design=109 |title=Virginia Tech Bookstore - Cap and Gowns |publisher=vt.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-11-28}}</ref> |- | [[Washington and Lee University]] | Purple with blue and white lining | Black | Black hexagonal tam | none | | | |<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wlu.edu/x28990.xml#dress |title=General Commencement Dress |publisher=wlu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-12-21 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317010345/http://www.wlu.edu/x28990.xml#dress#dress |archive-date=2013-03-17 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> |- | [[Washington University in St. Louis]] | Green with red chevron | Green with black velvet trim | Black hexagonal tam | none | University shield (shape 1) on sleeves at shoulder; undergraduate gowns also green with shield | |<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commencement.wustl.edu/regalia/ |title=Regalia - The Washington University Commencement Gown |publisher=wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-04-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://productgraphics.wustl.edu/graphics.html |title=Washington University in St. Louis - Product Graphics |publisher=wustl.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-04-26}}</ref> |- | [[Wellesley College]] | Dark blue | | | | | |<ref name="harvmag" /> |- | [[Yale University]] | Blue | [[Yale blue]] and black | Black mortarboard | none | |[[File:Levin and salovey.jpg|frameless|151x151px]] |<ref name="harvmag" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yale.edu/commencement/html/Guide_to_Regalia_07.pdf |title=A Guide to Yale University Academic Regalia |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-04-04}}</ref> |}

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category iOS (Apple) to [[:Category:iOS]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 11]].
revision.text:
'''After School'''<ref>{{Cite web|title=AfterSchool |url=http://afterschoolapp.com/app/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125091852/http://afterschoolapp.com/app/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2014-11-25 |website=afterschoolapp.com |accessdate=2015-10-23 }}</ref> is an [[iOS]] and [[Android (operating system)|Android]] [[Social networking service|social network]] mobile application that allows users in a defined network, currently high schools, to share anonymous text-based posts and images with others.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wagner|first1=Kurt|title=Who Is Behind After School, the Anonymous App Taking Over American High Schools?|url=http://recode.net/2014/12/04/who-is-behind-after-school-the-anonymous-app-taking-over-american-high-schools/|website=recode.com|publisher=re/code|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref> As of July 2016, After School had users at more than 20,000 american high schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.the74million.org/article/crisis-text-line-brings-help-to-troubled-teens-where-they-live-their-phones|title=Crisis Text Line Brings Help to Troubled Teens Where They Live — Their Phones|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref>
According to CEO Michael Callahan, the app was created as a network “that teens could use to express themselves, to reach out to others and to ask for and offer help to fellow teens in distress.”<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/larry-magid/after-school-app-designed_b_9146944.html|title=After School App Designed to Promote Kindness Say Founders {{!}} Huffington Post|last=journalist|first=Larry Magid Technology|date=2016-02-03|website=The Huffington Post|access-date=2016-09-22}}</ref>
The app, created by [[Michael J. Callahan (Entrepreneur)|Michael Callahan]] and [[Cory Levy]] of ONE, Inc., debuted in mid-November 2014. In the re-release of the app in April 2015,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Larson|first1=Selena|title=After School attempts a comeback with bans on bullying|url=http://www.dailydot.com/technology/after-school-comeback/|website=Dailydot.com|publisher=The Daily Dot|accessdate=22 October 2015}}</ref> After School implemented “mature content” filters, age verification, 24/7 live anonymous support, and FIRST (Fastest Internet Response System for Threats).<ref>{{cite web|title=First |url=http://afterschoolapp.com/first/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150112005818/http://afterschoolapp.com/first/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=12 January 2015 |website=AfterSchoolApp.com |publisher=After School |accessdate=22 October 2015 }}</ref> In February 2016, After School announced raising a $16.4 million Series A round.<ref name=":0" /> The app also detects threatening or harmful messages using "language algorithms"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/business/article/Anonymous-app-for-teens-tries-to-keep-bullying-at-12531220.php|title=Anonymous app for teens tries to keep bullying at bay|last=Thadani|first=Trisha|date=2018-01-29|website=San Francisco Chronicle|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> and "enforces a single-report immediate user removal for violations."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://myfox8.com/2018/02/28/after-school-app-raises-concerns-of-bullying-inappropriate-activity/|title=After School app raises concerns of bullying, inappropriate activity|last=Polarchy|first=Michael|date=2018-02-28|website=Fox 8|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
