revision.text:
{{Infobox Union |name = Alliance Israélite Universelle |native_name = KOL ISRAEL HAVERIM |founded= {{start date and age|1860}} |people = Mark Ayzenberg, President |image = Kol israel haverim.jpg |website = [http://www.aiu.org/fr/www.aiu.org/fr] }} [[File:Siège de la Société d'histoire des Juifs de Tunisie.jpg|thumb|Entrance to the seat of the [[History of the Jews in Tunisia|Société d'histoire des Juifs de Tunisie]] and the ''Alliance israélite universelle'' in [[Paris]].]]
The '''''Alliance israélite universelle''''' ({{lang-he-n|כל ישראל חברים}}) is a [[Paris]]-based international [[Jew]]ish organization founded in 1860 by the French statesman [[Adolphe Crémieux]] to safeguard the [[human rights]] of [[Jew]]s around the world. The organization promotes the ideals of Jewish [[self-defense]] and [[self-sufficiency]] through [[education]] and [[professional development]]. It is noted for establishing French-language schools for Jewish children throughout the Mediterranean in the 19th and early 20th century.
The motto of the organization is the Jewish [[rabbi]]nic injunction ''Kol yisrael arevim ze laze'' ({{Hebrew|כל ישראל ערבים זה לזה}}), translated into [[French language|French]] as ''Tous les israélites sont solidaires les uns des autres'' ("All Jews bear responsibility for one another").<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=G9MeXaTrjEQC&pg=PA171&lpg=PA171 ''Sacred Bonds of Solidarity: The Rise of Jewish Internationalism in Nineteenth-Century France,'' Lisa Moses Leff ]</ref>
==History== [[Image:Adolphe Crémieux by Lecomte du Nouy.jpg|thumb|left|<center>[[Adolphe Crémieux]], founder of the Alliance</center>]]
In 1860, Alliance Israelite Universelle embarked on a "[[civilizing mission|mission civilisatrice]]" to advance the Jews of the [[Middle East]] through French education and culture.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ENfjCk1IZBcC&pg=PA49 ''The Dispersion of Egyptian Jewry'', Joel Beinin]</ref> It was founded in [[Paris]],<ref name=nie>{{NIE|wstitle=Alliance Israelite Universelle|year=1905|inline=1}}</ref> and opened its first school in [[Tetouan]], [[Morocco]] in 1862.<ref name="books.google.com">[https://books.google.com/books?id=3kbU4BIAcrQC&pg=PA29 ''A History of the Israeli-Palestinian Conflict'', Mark A. Tessler]</ref> The original members of the society were Jews, and by far the largest number of its members belong to that faith, but the association has enjoyed at all times the sympathy and cooperation of many prominent Christians. As outlined in its prospectus, the program of the society included the emancipation of the Jews from oppressive and discriminating laws, political disabilities, and defense of them in those countries where they were subjected to persecution.<ref name=nie/>
For the attainment of its objectives, the society proposed to carry on a campaign of education through the press and by the publication of works on the history and life of the Jews. In the beginning, however, the course of action adopted by the society for bringing relief to their oppressed brethren in other countries was to secure the intercession of friendly governments in their behalf. Thus, as early as 1867 the governments of [[France]], [[Italy]], [[Belgium]], and the [[Netherlands]] made the renewal of existing treaties with [[Switzerland]] conditional upon that country's granting full civil and political rights to the Jews. In 1878, representatives of the Alliance laid the condition of the Jews in the Balkan Peninsula before the [[Congress of Berlin]], as a result of which the [[Treaty of Berlin (1878)|Treaty of Berlin]] stipulated that in [[Romania]], [[Serbia]], and [[Bulgaria]] no discrimination should be made against any religion in the distribution of [[civil rights]].<ref name=nie/>
===Schools=== [[File:Portail AIU.JPG|thumb|Gate of the school of Alliance israélite universelle (1882), on [[Jaffa Road]] in [[Jerusalem]]]] Over time, the activity of the Alliance became more focused on education and especially improving the welfare of Jews.<ref name=nie/> In 1864, an Alliance school opened in [[Baghdad]].<ref>[https://www.academia.edu/4926183/The_Elite_the_Effendiyya_and_the_Growth_of_Nationalism_and_Pan-Arabism_in_Hashemite_Iraq_1921_1958 The Elite, the Effendiyya, and the Growth of Nationalism and Pan-Arabism in Hashemite Iraq, 1921-1958 ]</ref> In 1870, [[Charles Netter]], a founding member of ''Alliance israélite universelle'', received a tract of land from the [[Ottoman Empire]] as a gift and opened the [[Mikveh Israel Settlement|Mikveh Israel]] agricultural school, the first of a network of Jewish schools in [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]] before the establishment of the [[State of Israel]]. Over 60 Alliance schools operated in the Ottoman Middle East, Iran and North Africa, providing Jewish children from poor families with formal elementary school and vocational training. Many of the teachers were educated at Alliance teacher training schools in Turkey and France.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=aT84Jn7zjU0C&pg=PA158 The Jews of Islam, Bernard Lewis]</ref>
By 1900, Alliance Israelite Universelle was operating 100 schools with a combined student population of 26,000. Its greatest efforts were concentrated in Morocco, Tunisia and Turkey.<ref name="books.google.com"/> French was the third most popular foreign language spoken in Palestine by 1914. Many French speakers came from North Africa but the eleventh Zionist Congress insisted that Hebrew, a holy language should be adopted in preference to German. The AIU agreed that it would be taught on their curriculum.<ref>Gilbert, Israel: A History, (2008), p.29</ref>
==Schools in Israel== [[File:PikiWiki Israel 134 Girls School in Jerusalem 1935 תמונת מחזור בית ספר אליאנס 1935.jpg|thumb|<center>Alliance girls schools in Jerusalem, 1935</center>]]
''Alliance israélite universelle'' continues to operate dozens of schools and educational programs in [[Israel]] today. Historic schools include the Alliance High School in [[Tel Aviv]], ''Alliance israélite universelle'' High School in [[Haifa]], René Cassin High School and the Braunshweig Conservative High School in [[Jerusalem]]. The network also includes the School for the Deaf in Jerusalem, in which deaf students, Jews and Arabs, with various mental and physical disabilities study together. The Mikve Israel Youth Village operates a state high school, a state-religious high school specializing in life and natural sciences, environmental sciences, and biotechnology; and a French-Israeli high school established in 2007 as a joint initiative of the Israeli and French governments.<ref>[http://www.kiah.org.il/eng/about/history/Kol Israel Haverim history]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Impact on Girls and Women == The Alliance Israelite Universelle (AIU) changed and shaped the roles and opportunities for women in North Africa. Prior to the establishment of the AIU, primarily girls from wealthy or rabbinical families received an education.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/morocco-nineteenth-and-twentieth-centuries|title=Morocco: Nineteenth and Twentieth Centuries {{!}} Jewish Women's Archive|website=jwa.org|language=en|access-date=2018-04-14}}</ref> Literacy and skilled training provided an opportunity for upward social mobility, especially to Jewish girls of underprivileged backgrounds who could not attain an education previously. Curricula featured foundational mathematics, such as arithmetic, exposure to European subjects such as European geography and the French language.<ref name=":0" /> Additionally, girls also received vocational training in fields from needlework and sewing, to bookkeeping, secretarial work, laboratory assistance, and industrial chemistry.<ref name=":0" /> Many North African women were also educated and trained AIU teachers in France, returning to their home countries to extend the mission of the AIU. Providing vocational training promoted the economic independence of Jewish women in the region.
Along with economic change, the AIU changed cultural norms for Jewish girls in the Maghreb as well. Primarily, the AIU lobbied to extend the typical marriage age from twelve to fifteen by 1948.<ref name=":0" /> This changing role of women led to controversy regarding the secularization of Jewish society through western-style education.
== The AIU and Secularization == Prior to colonization, rabbis and religious figures provided education. The AIU, and more generally, French colonization, challenged this model. Education shifted from the hands of religious leaders to secular, European instructors. In Algeria, this shift resulted in a legal mandate: in 1845, a law required Jews of Algeria to be registered in a French school, and to only attend a religious school as a supplement.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9txi3xuuENcC&pg=PA125&lpg=PA125&dq=jewish+schools+after+french+colonization+maghreb&source=bl&ots=oGu0MoHqmf&sig=H5EWm2_Z6oJKpw1liheNGK2s8GQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjL3qSjzKPZAhWC3YMKHVs4BvwQ6AEISDAG#v=onepage&q=jewish%20schools%20after%20french%20colonization%20maghreb&f=false|title=The Jews of North Africa: From Dido to De Gaulle|last=Taieb-Carlen|first=Sarah|date=2010-02-23|publisher=University Press of America|isbn=9780761850441|language=en}}</ref> Although the AIU did teach both secular and religious subjects, such as Hebrew and Biblical History, religious leaders still questioned and bemoaned the secular shift the AIU promoted.<ref name=":0" />
Similarly, the AIU attempted to secularize the experiences of Jews and the legal systems in North Africa. In 1913 in Morocco, the AIU attempted to appeal to the French protectorate government to try "indigenous [Jewish] inhabitants" in French courts instead of rabbinical tribunals.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laskier|first=Michael M.|date=1983|title=Aspects of the Activities of the Alliance Israélite Universelle in the Jewish Communities of the Middle East and North Africa: 1860-1918|jstor=1396078|journal=Modern Judaism|volume=3|issue=2|pages=147–171}}</ref>
==== Analysis ==== Prior to the AIU, religious systems intersected with cultural and political systems. The AIU sought to secularize not only education, but also the related institutions influenced by religion. Attempting to secularize many aspects of Jewish life, institutions, and cultural norms demonstrates the AIU's extension of the French colonial mission––the school system was not a Jewish educational system, but rather a French colonial system focused on the emancipation and westernization of Jews.
== Political Influence == Along with secularization, the AIU wielded much political power for the political assimilation of North African Jews into French society. AIU instructors were instrumental in the movement of naturalization for educated, Moroccan Jews.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=n4ztCQAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=+++Michael+M.+Laskier,+%E2%80%9CNorth++African++Jewry++in++the++Twentieth+Century:+A+Sociopolitical++Analysis,%E2%80%9D+in+North+African+Jewry+in+the+Twentieth+Century:+The+Jews+of+Morocco,+Tunisia,+and+Algeria+(New+York:+New+York+University+Press,+1994),+23%E2%80%9354.&ots=pt6ZJm6fYC&sig=Svf0znbU3Ndw-Z2oX9k40HarWzo#v=onepage&q&f=false|title=North African Jewry in the Twentieth Century: The Jews of Morocco, Tunisia, and Algeria|last=Laskier|first=Michael M.|date=1997-06-01|publisher=NYU Press|isbn=9780814752654|language=en}}</ref> These teachers met with French officials, convincing them to expand their Jewish allies by granting naturalization rights to French-educated, intellectual Jewry from Morocco. Only the most educated were considered the "liberated", and thus the most qualified to merit French citizenship.<ref name=":1" />
==== Analysis ==== These conditions represent the AIU's civilizing mission in action: in order to be accepted as French citizens, North Africans must have demonstrated the status of an assimilated Jew who has learned language, culture, and intellectual thought all from the French perspective. Although the AIU provided education and the promise of upward social mobility, these benefits were to be realized within a European context. The French AIU advocated of naturalization attempted to convince both North African Jews and French officials that granting citizenship would create "Jewish allies," suggesting that assimilating Jews through education would build more partners perpetuating the French colonial mission in North Africa.<ref name=":1" />
==Presidents== * [[Louis-Jean Koenigswarter]] (1860-1863) * [[Adolphe Crémieux]] (1863-1867) * [[Salomon Munk]] (1867-1867) * Adolphe Crémieux (1868-1880) * [[Salomon Hayum Goldschmidt]] (1882-1898) * [[Narcisse Leven]] (1898-1915) * [[Arnold Netter]] (1915-1920, ''interim'') * [[Sylvain Lévi]] (1920-1935) * Arnold Netter (1936-1936) * [[Georges Leven]] (1936-1941) * [[René Cassin]] (1943-1976) * [[Jules Braunschvig]] (1976-1985) * [[Adolphe Steg]] (1985-2011) * [[Marc Eisenberg]] (2011-)
==Notable alumni== [[File:Gal mekel.JPG|thumb|170px|<center>[[Gal Mekel]]</center>]]
*[[Din Din Aviv]], Israeli pop and folk singer *[[Gal Mekel]] (born 1988), Israeli NBA basketball player<ref>[http://www.goshockers.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=7500&ATCLID=654216]</ref> *[[Ori Yogev]], Israeli businessman

Fonds Avi Haï. * André Kaspi, ''Histoire de l'Alliance israélite universelle - De 1860 à nos jours'', Ed. Institut Yad Ben-Zvi, 1991. * Sciarcon, Jonathan. ''Educational Oases in the Desert: The Alliance Israélite Universelle's Girls' Schools in Ottoman Iraq, 1895-1915.'' The International Convention on Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping for Seafarers ([[STCW]]), requires that seafarers be provided with "familiarization training" and "'''basic safety training'''" which includes basic [[fire fighting]], elementary [[first aid]], personal [[survival techniques]], and personal safety and [[social responsibility]]. This training is intended to ensure that seafarers are aware of the hazards of working on a vessel and can respond appropriately in an emergency.
According to STCW, The STCW 95 Code requires that you take this 5-day course of instruction. This course has to be renewed every 5 years, or under certain conditions, you have to show that you have at least 1 year of service on board vessels of 200 grt or more within the last 5 years. The components generally includes a Fire Prevention and Fire Fighting (Basic Fire fighting) course of 2 days, a Personal Survival Techniques (PST) course of 1.5 days, a Personal Safety and Social Responsibility (PSSR) course of half a day, and, First Aid / CPR (Basic First Aid) course of 1 day.<ref>[https://www.edumaritime.net/stcw-courses/basic-safety-training-bst Basic Safety Training Components]</ref>
Basic Safety Training or BST is the starting point for persons seeking employment in the maritime industry.<ref>[http://www.edumaritime.net/washington/fremont-maritime-services-seattle Maritime Employment Requirement]</ref>
Basic Offshore Safety Induction and Emergency Training or BOSIET is designed for marine personnel intending to work on an offshore installation in the UK maritime sector and forms part of a Common Offshore Safety Induction process.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130725164849/http://www.stcw.org/ STCW Website] * [https://www.southwestmaritimeacademy.com/courses/stcw/basic-safety-training-week-course/ STCW - South West Maritime Academy]
[[Category:International Maritime Organization]] [[Category:Law of the sea]] [[Category:Maritime education]] [[Category:Safety]]

The '''Catalyst Conference''' (or simply '''Catalyst''') is a series of [[leadership]] conferences focused on a new generation of church leaders.{{Cite web|url = http://catalystconference.com/about-us/|title = Catalyst Conference: About Us|date = |accessdate = May 7, 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} {{Infobox recurring event | name = | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | date = | begins = | ends = | prev = | next = | frequency = Annual | location = [[Atlanta, Georgia]]
[[Dallas, Texas]]
[[Irvine, California]]
[[Washington D.C.]], etc. | years_active =17 | first = | last = | participants = | attendance = 13,000 | genre = | budget = | patron = | organized = Catalyst Leader, LLC | people = [[Andy Stanley]]
[[Craig Groeschel]]
[[Malcolm Gladwell]]
[[John Piper (theologian)|John Piper]]
[[Francis Chan]]
[[Patrick Lencioni]]
[[Hillsong United]] | member = | website = http://catalystconference.com/ | footnotes = }} == About Catalyst == Catalyst was conceived as a next-generation leaders conference in 1999 by [[Andy Stanley]], Reggie Joiner, John Maxwell, Lanny Donoho and other young leaders. The Catalyst Conference takes place annually in [[Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], [[United States]] at the [[Infinite Energy Arena]].{{Cite book|page=8|title=Primal: A Quest for the Lost Soul of Christianity|author=Mark Batterson|publisher=[[Random House]]|year=2010|isbn=1601423578}} It is 2–3 days long.{{Cite news|work=[[The Christian Post]]|title=Catalyst Powers Up Next Generation Leaders for Christ|author=Lillian Kwon|date=October 5, 2007|url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/catalyst-powers-up-next-generation-leaders-for-christ-29597/print.html|accessdate=July 4, 2013}} Every year Catalyst hosts groups and individuals from nearly all denominations and more than 5,000 churches and faith-based organizations. [[Andy Stanley]], [[Christine Caine]], Robert Madu, [[Craig Groeschel]], [[Matt Redman]] spoke at Catalyst in 2014.{{Cite news|url = http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/2014/sep/29/catalyst-conference-brings-thousands-of-church/|title = Gwinnett Daily Post|last = Morris|first = Katie|date = September 29, 2014|work = |access-date = |via = }} The conference is a [[Nondenominational Christianity|nondenominational Christian]] event.{{Cite journal|author=[[Ed Stetzer]]|page=36|title=Denominationalism: Is There a Future?|journal=Southern Baptists, Evangelicals, and the Future of Denominationalism|editors=David S. Dockery, Ray Van Neste, Jerry N. Tidwell|publisher=[[B&H Publishing Group]]|year=2011|isbn=1433671204}} More than 13,000 people attended Catalyst at the Infinite Energy Arena in 2013.{{Cite news|url = http://www.gwinnettdailypost.com/news/2013/sep/30/conference-at-arena-expected-to-draw-13000-church/|title = Gwinnett Daily Post|last = Allen|first = Deanna|date = September 30, 2013|work = |access-date = |via = }} == Catalyst Conferences == '''Catalyst Conferences''' are now held annually in major cities across the [[United States]].{{Cite web|url = http://catalystconference.com/events/|title = Catalyst Conference|date = |accessdate = May 7, 2015|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }} The focus of the events is around [[Christian worship|worship]] and [[leadership development]].{{Cite book|page=199|title=Simply Strategic Volunteers: Empowering People For Ministry|author=Tony Morgan|author2=Tim Stevens|publisher=Group Publishing|year=2004|isbn=0764427563}} The conference theme usually kicks off in [[Atlanta, Georgia]], [[United States]] at the [[Infinite Energy Arena]]. Each year the event focuses on a key leadership theme with opening and closing [[worship music]] and main session events during the day. The conference sessions cover various [[lectures]] and [[interview]] formats. The Catalyst Conference goal is to provide individuals with applicable leadership content and memorable experiences that impact their home, church, and work. == Conference Speakers == === Past Speakers include === {| class="wikitable" !Theme !Speaker !Credits !Event |- |Known |[[Craig Groeschel]] |Lead Pastor, Life.Church | Author, Fight |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |Eric Mason |Found and Lead Pastor, Epiphany Fellowship | Author, Manhood Restored |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |[[Francis Chan]] |Best-selling Author, [[Crazy Love: Overwhelmed by a Relentless God|Crazy Love]] and Forgotten God |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |Dr. [[Henry Cloud]] |Clinical Psychologist | Leadership Consulting | Best-selling Author, Boundaries for Leaders |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |[[Jen Hatmaker]] |Bible Teacher | Author, Seven |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |[[Mark Batterson]] |Lead Pastor, National Community Church | Best-selling Author, All In |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |[[Patrick Lencioni]] |Found and President, The Table Group | Best-selling Author, The Advantage |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |Rachel Cruze |Daughter of Dave Ramsey | Author, The Graduate's Survival Guide |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |[[Tullian Tchividjian]] |Lead Pastor, Coral Ridge Presbyterian Church | Author, One Way Love |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |John Gray |Teaching Pastor, Lakewood Church | Actor, Singer, Comedian |Catalyst Dallas |- |Known |[[Jesus Culture]] |Renowned Worship Artists |Catalyst Dallas |- |Change Makers |[[Andy Stanley]] |Senior Pastor, North Point Ministries | Author, How to Be Rich |Catalyst Atlanta |- |Change Makers |[[Christine Caine]] |Founder, the A21 Campaign | Author, Unstoppable |Catalyst Atlanta |- |Change Makers |[[Tim Keller (pastor)|Tim Keller]] |Founding Pastor, Redeemer Presbyterian Church | Author, Encounters with Jesus |Catalyst Atlanta |- |Change Makers |Dr. John Perkins |Founder, John M. revision.text:
[[Image:Langdell.jpg|frame|Christopher C. Langdell]] '''Christopher Columbus Langdell''' (May 22, 1826 – July 6, 1906) was an [[United States|American]] [[jurist]] and legal academic who was Dean of [[Harvard Law School]] from 1870 to 1895.
Dean Langdell's legacy lies in the educational and administrative reforms he made to [[Harvard Law School]], a task he was entrusted with by President [[Charles William Eliot|Charles Eliot]]. Before Langdell's tenure the study of law was a rather technical pursuit in which students were simply told what the law is. Langdell applied the principles of [[pragmatism]] to the teaching of law as a result of which students were compelled to use their own reasoning powers to understand how the law might apply in a given case. This [[Socratic method|dialectical process]] came to be called the [[Casebook method|case method]] and has been the primary method of pedagogy at American law schools ever since. The case method has since been adopted and improved upon by schools in other disciplines, such as business, public policy, and education. This innovation, coupled with Langdell's introduction of strictly meritocratic principles into the evaluation of candidates, has led him to be considered 'arguably the most influential teacher in the history of professional education in the United States'.<ref>''Christopher Langdell: The Case of an 'Abomination' in Teaching Practice'' by Bruce A. Kimball [http://www.nea.org/assets/img/PubThoughtAndAction/TAA_04Sum_03.pdf]</ref> ==Life==
Christopher Langdell was born in the town of [[New Boston, New Hampshire]], of English and [[Scotch-Irish American|Scots-Irish]] ancestry. He studied at [[Phillips Exeter Academy]] in 1845–48, at [[Harvard College]] in 1848–50 and at [[Harvard Law School]] in 1851–54. As a student, he served as one of the Harvard Law School's first librarians. From 1854 to 1870 he practiced law in [[New York City]], but was almost unknown when, in January 1870, he was appointed Dane Professor of Law at Harvard Law School by [[Charles W. Eliot]]. Soon after, he became [[Dean (education)|Dean]] of the Law Faculty, succeeding [[Theophilus Parsons (professor)|Theophilus Parsons]], to whose ''[[Treatise on the Law of Contracts]]'' (1853) he had contributed as a student.{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1870<ref name=AAAS>{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter L|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterL.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=September 11, 2016}}</ref> and received the degree of [[Legum Doctor|LL.D.]] in 1875.
Langdell resigned the deanship in 1895, in 1900 became Dane Professor Emeritus, and on July 6, 1906 died in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]]. In 1903 a chair in the law school was named in his honor and after his death the school's primary academic building, housing both the world's largest academic law library and classrooms, was named [[Langdell Hall]].{{sfn|Chisholm|1911}}
Langdell made the Harvard Law School a success by remodeling its administration. In a private correspondence of April 13, 1915, [[Charles W. Eliot]] wrote: "the putting of Langdell in charge of the Law School was the best piece of work I did for Harvard University, except the reconstruction of the Medical school in [18]70 and [18]71, and the long fight for the development of the elective system."<ref>Letter to Henry S. Pritchett, ''Correspondence of Charles W. Eliot'', Small Manuscript Collection, Harvard Law School Library. Cited by [http://www.historycooperative.org/journals/lhr/17.1/kimball.html Kimball (1999)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080709014609/http://www.historycooperative.org/journals/lhr/17.1/kimball.html |date=2008-07-09 }}.</ref>
==Influence on legal teaching==
Dean Langdell's greatest innovation was his introduction of the [[casebook method|case method]] of instruction. {{sfn|Chisholm|1911}} Until 1890, no other U.S. law school used this method, which is now standard. Moreover, the standard first-year curriculum at all American law schools — [[Contracts]], [[Property]], [[Torts]], [[Criminal Law]], and [[Civil Procedure]] — stands, mostly unchanged, from the curriculum Langdell instituted.
Langdell, who came from a relatively unknown family, was conscious of the fact that students from more privileged backgrounds often received higher grades in their coursework purely because of their family's wealth and social status. Dean Langdell instituted the process of [[blind grading]], now common at U.S. law schools, so that students already known by professors or from esteemed families would have no advantage over others.
==Works== {{Wikisource author}} *''Selection of Cases on the Law of Contracts'' (1871, the first book used in the case system; enlarged, 1879)<ref>{{cite book |last=Langdell |first=C.C. |title=A Selection of Cases on the Law of Contracts: With References and Citations; Prepared for Use as a Text-Book in Harvard Law School |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |place=Boston |year= 1871 |accessdate= February 7, 2018 |url= https://books.google.bg/books?id=bYczAQAAMAAJ&dq=editions%3AOMHXe17F3WkC&pg=PR3#v=onepage&q&f=false|via= Google Books}}; {{cite book |last=Langdell |first=C.C. |title=A Selection of Cases on the Law of Contracts: With References and Citations; Prepared for Use as a Text-Book in Harvard Law School |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |place=Boston |year= 1879 |edition= 2nd |accessdate= February 7, 2018 |url= https://archive.org/stream/cu31924018826713#page/n3/mode/2up|via= Internet Archive}}</ref> *''A Selection of Cases on Sales of Personal Property'' (1872)<ref>{{cite book |last=Langdell |first= C.C. |title= A Selection of Cases on Sales on Personal Property with References and Citations; Prepared for Use as a Text-Book in Harvard Law School |publisher= Little, Brown and Company|place= Boston |year=1872 |url=https://archive.org/details/selectionofcase00lang |volume= I |accessdate= February 7, 2018 |via= Internet Archive}}</ref> *''A Summary of Equity Pleading'' (1877, 2nd ed., 1883)<ref>{{cite book |last=Langdell |first=C.C. |title=A Summary of Equity Pleading |publisher=Charles W. Sever |place=Cambridge|year= 1877 |accessdate= February 7, 2018 |url= https://books.google.bg/books?id=5wA-AAAAIAAJ&dq=inauthor%3A%22Christopher%20Columbus%20Langdell%22&pg=PP11#v=onepage&q&f=false|via= Google Books}}</ref> *''Cases in Equity Pleading'' (1883) *''Brief Survey of Equity Jurisdiction'' (1905)
==Further reading== * Chase, Anthony. "The Birth of the Modern Law School," ''American Journal of Legal History'' (1979) 23#4 pp 329-348 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/844687 in JSTOR] *{{cite book |title=Making Elite Lawyers: Visions of Law at Harvard and Beyond |last=Granfield |first=Robert |year=1992 |publisher=Routledge |location=New York |isbn= |pages= |url= }} * Kimball, Bruce A. ''The Inception of Modern Professional Education: C. C. Langdell, 1826–1906'' (Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2009) 429 pp. {{ISBN|978-0-8078-3257-8}} * Kimball, Bruce A. "The Proliferation of Case Method Teaching in American Law Schools: Mr. Langdell's Emblematic 'Abomination,' 1890-1915," ''History of Education Quarterly'' (2006) 46#2 pp 192-240 [https://www.jstor.org/stable/20462057 in JSTOR] * Kimball, Bruce A. '"Warn Students That I Entertain Heretical Opinions, Which They Are Not To Take as Law': The Inception of Case Method Teaching in the Classrooms of the Early C.C. Langdell, 1870-1883," ''Law and History Review'' 17 (Spring 1999): 57-140. * LaPiana, William P. ''Logic and Experience: The Origin of Modern American Legal Education'' (1994) [https://www.amazon.com/Logic-Experience-Origin-American-Education/dp/0195079353/ excerpt and text search] *{{cite journal|last1=Wells|first1=Catharine P.|title=Langdell and the Invention of Legal Doctrine|journal=Buffalo Law Review|date=2010|volume=58|issue=3|page=551-618}}
==References== <references/> ;Attribution *{{Cite EB1911| wstitle=Langdell, Christopher Columbus}}
==External links== *{{cite web | url = http://oasis.lib.harvard.edu/oasis/deliver/findingAidDisplay?_collection=oasis&inoid=4926 | title = Finding aid for Christopher Columbus Langdell, Research notes and correspondences, 1852-1902. | publisher = Harvard Law School Library}} *[http://www.law.harvard.edu/news/spotlight/classroom/related/hls-deans.html "Harvard Law School Deans throughout history"], ''Harvard Law School''
{{s-start}} {{s-aca}} {{succession box| before=New title| title=[[Dean of Harvard Law School]]| after=[[James Barr Ames]]| years=1870–1895}} {{s-end}}

revision.text:
{{Cleanup rewrite|date=October 2010}} '''Basketball coaching''' is the act of directing and strategizing the behavior of a [[basketball]] team or individual basketball player. Basketball coaching typically encompasses the improvement of individual and team offensive and defensive skills, as well as overall physical conditioning. Coaches also have the responsibility to improve their team by player development, strategy, and in-game management. Coaches also teach and inspire their team to be their best.
Coaching is usually performed by a single person, often with the help of one or more assistants.
== Coaching tools == A sketch or a hyperdrive board is often used mid-game to describe plays and provide an overview of the strategy of the opposing team. Coaches strategize and scout opposing teams and find ways to defeat them as easily as possible. At the same time, they overlook their own personal team to start the best five players (only five players can be on floor at one time). Coaches, also, have to be aware of subs to put in throughout the game so they can be fresh.
College basketball coach [[John Wooden]] would spend two hours each morning with assistants planning out a day's practice minute-by-minute on three-by-five cards. He kept each card year over year to adjust and improve. He would train his players with "mental and emotional" conditioning by always making practice more intense than the game. Players would run faster than what a game would require so that they could be prepared to dominate in the game.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Coyle|first1=Daniel|title=The Talent Code|publisher=Bantam Books|isbn=9780553906493|pages=169}}</ref>
==Coaching awards== * [[NBA Coach of the Year Award]] * [[EuroLeague Coach of the Year Award]] * [[ABA Coach of the Year Award]] (''defunct'')
==Coaching websites== [https://bballtools.com Basketball Coaching Tools]<ref>BBallTools.com</ref>
==See also== *[[Head coach]] *[[Coach (sport)]]

/* Deculturalization in the United States */ "Changed naturalization act of 1970" to 1790.
revision.text:
'''Deculturalization''' is the process by which an ethnic group is forced to abandon its language, culture, and customs. It is the destruction of the culture of a dominated group and its replacement by the culture of the dominating group.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Branch|first1=André J|title=Deculturalization|url=http://knowledge.sagepub.com/view/diversityineducation/n190.xml|website=SAGE knowledge|publisher=SAGE Publications, Inc|accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> Deculturalization is a slow process due to its extensive goal of fully replacing the subordinate ethnic group's culture, language, and customs. This term is often confused with [[Assimilation (sociology)|assimilation]] and [[acculturation]].
==Methods of Deculturalization== * [[Geographical segregation]] * Forbidding education to the dominated group * Forceful replacing of language * Superior culture's curriculum in schools * Instructors are from the dominant group * Avoiding the dominated group's culture in curriculum
==Deculturalization in the United States== '''African Americans''' The enslavement of African Americans during the 18th and 19th centuries in the United States is a form of deculturalization. [[Slavery in the United States]] made the African Americans dependent on their owners allowing for the owners to exploit them. The owners removed their African names, did not allow them to read, and did not allow them to practice their culture and language. Deculturalization of African Americans stems back to When the African American slaves were forbidden access to education due to fear of a slave revolt against the slaveholders.<ref>http://h637-books.wikispaces.com/Deculturalization+and+the+Struggle+for+Equality</ref> A series of court cases occurred in the United States helping deculturalization of African Americans as wells as there were cases that went against deculturalization. For example, the addition of the [[14th Amendment to the United States Constitution]], the [[Dred Scott v. Sandford]] decision, [[Brown v. Board of Education]], [[Plessy v. Ferguson]], and countless others.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://prezi.com/ukhxfexpakmq/deculturalization-of-education/|title=Deculturalization of Education|publisher=}}</ref> After the [[Civil War (United States)]] segregated education continued and was a struggle to integrate fully and completely. While integration was achieved, the textbooks that the African American students learn from are bias and contain material from the dominant, Anglo-American culture.
'''Latin Americans''' The deculturalization of Latinos can refer back to the Mexican–American War and [[The Treaty Of Guadalupe Hidalgo]]. Once the United States won California, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona, Nevada, Utah, and parts of Wyoming and Colorado Mexicans who were living in these areas were removed from their lands. Their identity in the United States changed constantly from Mexican to White and vice versa until the word Hispanic was created to refer to these Mexican Americans. By simply using the word Hispanic to refer to the Mexican Americans and later the Latin-American immigrants refers to the conqueror's culture-the Spanish culture. Latin@ in the United States also had segregated schooling.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/latino/latinothemestudy/education.htm|title=Demanding their Rights: The Latino Struggle for Educational Access and Equity|publisher=}}</ref> In schools they were given second-hand material from the wealthy, Anglo schools. When Latinos were being integrated, they as well as the African Americans, were being taught from bias, Anglo-cultured, Anglo-praising textbooks. Latinos did have a win to have bilingual education.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.civilrights.org/resources/civilrights101/desegregation.html|title=School Desegregation and Equal Educational Opportunity|publisher=}}</ref> While they were allowed to have bilinugal education, the primary, enforced language is the English one. In some schools Latinos were corporally punished for speaking Spanish in the classroom. In some Universities, Latinos were also forced to take many speech classes in order to remove the accents of the Latinos when they spoke English.<ref>http://wolfweb.unr.edu/homepage/calabj/282/how%20to%20tame%20wild%20tongue.pdf</ref> While that is not seen evidently in schools anymore, the education system continues to enforce English, Anglo-American customs, culture and language as the dominant one.
'''Asian Americans''' Asian Americans began to be deculturalized by not being allowed to be naturalized, the Chinese-Exclusion Act, Japanese Internment, forbidding land ownership, and enforcing the Anglo-culture onto them. The [[Naturalization Act of 1790]] did not allow for the Chinese along with other Asians to become naturalized, because the naturalization process was limited only to the Anglo community in the United States.<ref name="ecaasu.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.ecaasu.org/site/important-dates-in-asian-american-history/|title=Important Dates in Asian American History - East Coast Asian American Student Union|publisher=}}</ref> In terms of schooling, in some cases Asian Americans were denied an education entirely. It was not until the 1900s when Asian Americans were allowed to receive an education through the implementation of certain provisions. In 1855, the Chan Yong case fortified that the Chinese are not "white" therefore ineligible for citizenship due to the Naturalization Act of 1790.<ref>http://academic.evergreen.edu/curricular/mit2005/Winter/History/RacismTimelin2.htm</ref> Also, in 1922, the court case Ozawa v. United States, the Japanese man understood he was not allowed to be naturalized due to the former act, but asked for the Japanese to be considered white, but was denied the request.<ref name="ecaasu.org"/> The Ozawa v. United States shows how some Asians would rather refer to themselves as white than as Japanese or their individual ethnic group, because of the advantages that being "white" bring. The enforced Anglo-American culture upon the Asians and using them during the Cold War as a model minority that the United States is not racist, it is the individual's fault allows for deculturalization to be successful. [[Jade Snow Wong]] is a Chinese-American writer who was used by the American government to travel to the Asian world and show how an Asian can succeed in America.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.academia.edu/1790878/_Americas_Chinese_Anti-Communism_Citizenship_and_Cultural_Diplomacy_During_the_Cold_War|title="America's Chinese": Anti-Communism, Citizenship, and Cultural Diplomacy During the Cold War|publisher=}}</ref>
'''Pre-Americans''' Once the first settlement in Jamestown 1607 occurred, the Pre-American deculturalization process began. When the English came to America they looked to the Native Americans as "pagans" and "savages". Native Americans believed that the land was not property, a thing to be claimed and owned. Once the English settlers arrived this was one of the major culture difference that needed to be extinguished. The idea of private property and ownership was enforced upon the Native Americans. While even those who accepted it, because they understood the consequences, their lands were taken away. They wanted to impose the traditional "Christian" nuclear family as well among the Native Americans. In order to gain success the colonists made Native American Educational Programs. Christian missionaries such as John Eliot learned the Native American language in order to convert them into Christianity began the segregation among the "pagans" and the "holy".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://prezi.com/11onrwncpstw/deculturalization-theory/|title=Deculturalization Theory|publisher=}}</ref> The Native Americans were exploited. There was a cultural genocide and simply genocide against the Native Americans. From the Trail of Tears to the appropriation of their designs in order to gain capital, corporate gains.

revision.text:
'''Commuter couples''' are a subset of [[Two-body problem (career)|dual-career couples]] who [[Living apart together|live apart]] in separate residences while both partners pursue careers.<ref name=Bunker1992>Bunker, B. B., Zubek, J. M., Vanderslice, V. J., & Rice, R. W. (1992). Quality of life in dual-career families: Commuting versus single-residence couples. Journal of Marriage and the Family, 399-407.</ref>
Gilbert and Rachlin address the difference between dual-earner families and dual-[[career]] families, distinguishing that dual-earner couples are those in which both spouses are earning for the family, but one or both of them consider their occupational involvement as a job. Jobs are unlike careers in that they do not require extensive training or commitment. In dual-earner couples, one spouse's work is generally considered secondary. Dual-career couples are families in which "both heads of household pursue careers and at the same time maintain a family life together".<ref name="Rapoport">Rapoport, R., Rapoport, R. N., & Bumstead, J. M. (Eds.). (1978). Working couples. New York: Harper & Row.</ref> Both have high degrees of commitment to their careers, and neither partner's career is thought to be more important than that of the other.<ref>Gilbert, L. A., & Rachlin, V. (1987). Mental health and psychological functioning of dual-career families. The Counseling Psychologist, 15(1), 7-49.</ref>
== Historical background ==
=== Statistics ===
In the United States, statistics from as early as 1989 report that 53% of married households were dual-earner couples. By 1996, the percent of dual-earner couples grew to 61%. According to data from 1989, approximately 7 million employees (15% to 20% of all dual-earner marriages) were classified as dual-career couples.<ref>Reed, C. M., & Bruce, W. M. (1993). Dual-career couples in the public sector: A survey of personnel policies and practices. Public Personnel Management.</ref> By 2003, U.S. workers take more than 400 million long-distance business trips (i.e., trips over 50 miles) each year.<ref>the U.S. Bureau of Transportation Statistics, 2003.</ref> Commuter marriages are on the rise, with recent estimates indicating that as many as 3 million Americans reside in different locations from their spouses.<ref>Bergen, K. M., Kirby, E., & McBride, M. C. (2007). "How do you get two houses cleaned?": Accomplishing family caregiving in commuter marriages. Journal of Family Communication, 7, 287-307.</ref>
=== Formation of commuter couples ===
The increase in women’s career opportunities also increases the problems of couples pursuing two careers in the same place, and can cause conflict regarding which spouse’s career should take precedence.<ref name=Anderson1992>Anderson, E. A. (1992). Decision-making style: Impact on satisfaction of the commuter couples' lifestyle. Journal of Family and Economic Issues, 13(1), 5-21.</ref> One major concern for dual-career couples is finding employment in the same geographic location. One partner usually compromises by taking a less desirable job so that the other can take a position that might further his or her career. However, if this compromise cannot be reached, the option of commuting can be the result, where both spouses enjoy highly desirable jobs at the sacrifice of maintaining separate residences.<ref name=Anderson1993>Anderson, E. A., & Spruill, J. W. (1993). "The dual-career commuter family: A lifestyle on the move". ''Marriage & Family Review'', 19(1-2), 131-147.</ref>
In the definition of dual-career commuter couples, the work pursued by each member of the couple requires 1) a high degree of commitment and special training with increasing degrees of responsibility (this includes students pursuing an advanced educational degree) and 2) that the couple maintain homes in separate geographic locations. Traveling sales or business workers, [[military personnel]], [[migrant worker]]s, and construction and trade workers who leave home for various lengths of time are not included in the definition. When couples share a home and one or both members [[commuting|commute]] long distances to work each day or couples [[immigration|immigrating]] at separate times, they are also not included in this definition.<ref name=Rapoport/><ref name=Gerstel1984>Gerstel, N., & Gross, H. E. (1984). Commuter marriages: A study of work and family. New York: Guilford.</ref>
The dyad of commuter couples is typically composed of the "commuter", who moves to a secondary residence for work, and the "noncommuter", who stays at the primary residence.<ref name=Bunker1992/> Other terms for the lifestyle are married-singles, commuter marriages, commuter families, commuter lifestyle, and commuter relationships.
=== Characteristics ===
Research reveals that most commuter couples have a high level of education and that both partners have [[professional]] or executive careers. Most are between the ages of 25 to 65, the mean age being mid- to late thirties. Forty to 50% of commuter couples have children, and more than 50% have been married for more than 9 years.<ref name=Anderson1993/> Most of commuter couples are with advanced degrees and are heavily involved in their careers.<ref>van der Klis, M., & Mulder, C. H. (2008). Beyond the trailing spouse: the commuter partnership as an alternative to family migration. Journal of Housing and the Built Environment, 23(1), 1-19.</ref> The most attractive factor of a job for commuter couples is the job-education match.<ref>Jackson, A. P., Brown, R. P., & Patterson-Stewart, K. E. (2000). African Americans in Dual-Career Commuter Marriages: An Investigation of Their Experiences. The Family Journal, 8, 22-36.</ref>
=== Advantages ===
Advantages of the commuting lifestyle are identified as 1) increased career opportunities, 2) professional autonomy, 3) increased independence, 4) increased appreciation of time together, 5) decreased focus on disagreements, and 6) decreased frequency of arguments.<ref name=Groves1991>Groves, M. M., & Horm-Wingerd, D. M. (1991). Commuter marriages: Personal, family and career issues. Sociology and social research, 75(4), 212-217.</ref><ref name=Magnuson1999>Magnuson, S., & Norem, K. (1999). Challenges for higher education couples in commuter marriages: Insights for couples and counselors who work with them. The Family Journal, 7(2), 125-134.</ref><ref name=Winfield1985>Winfield, F. E. (1985). Commuter marriage: Living together apart. New York: Columbia University Press.</ref>
=== Disadvantages ===
Disadvantages of being commuting couples are 1) financial problems; 2) [[loneliness]]; 3) lack of personal and professional support system due to a lack of time to build and maintain these relationships; 4) negative attitudes from friends, family, coworkers, and society; 5) increased tension in marriage and the family; 6) decreased satisfaction with sex life; 7) missed important family moments and day-to-day experiences; and 8) lack of social life, hobbies, and individual projects.<ref name=Groves1991/><ref name=Magnuson1999/><ref name=Winfield1985/><ref name=Jackson2000>Jackson, A. P., Brown, R. P., & Patterson-Stewart, K. E. (2000). African Americans in dual-career commuter marriages: An investigation of their experiences. The Family Journal, 8(1), 22-36.</ref>
== Contributing factors ==
=== Role conflict ===
There has been inconsistent evidence in relation to [[role conflict]] in dual-career commuter couples. Role conflict, according to Biddle, is “the concurrent appearance of two or more incompatible expectations for the behavior of a person”, and when a person experiences role conflict, it can have negative effects on multiple aspects of their lives, including decreased [[job performance]] and decreased [[organizational commitment|commitment to an organization]].<ref>Biddle, B. J. (1986). Recent development in role theory. Annual Review of Sociology, 67-92.</ref> In contrast to that definition, findings have shown that many commuters find their lifestyle beneficial in that it allows them to pursue their careers without having to deal with daily family distractions, and also gives them a sense of autonomy. This ability to compartmentalize the roles the individual plays may lead to more work [[life satisfaction]], supported by findings that commuter couples generally had more work life satisfaction than dual-career couples in a single residence.<ref name=Bunker1992/> However, there are still challenges faced by commuter couples in their different roles. It would seem that such great compartmentalization can lead some individuals to struggle with balancing both their work and family roles and the responsibilities for each;<ref name=Jackson2000/> almost half of commuter couples studied by Anderson reported that they rarely felt that they had a good [[Work-family balance|balance between job and family]]. Also, families who are commuters are thought to become more competent in their performance of all family-related tasks, suggesting that there is a less traditional [[division of labor]] between the husband and wife.<ref name=Anderson1993/> However, Anderson and Spruill found that even in commuter couples, most traditional household tasks were still performed by women, while tasks such as household maintenance and lawn-mowing were performed by men.<ref name=Anderson1993/> These findings suggest that commuter couples may still be relatively traditional in their role divisions from a [[gender role|gender]] perspective.
=== Social comparison ===
According to Festinger (1954) and [[Social comparison theory|Social Comparison Theory]], when there is no “objective” assessment for one’s abilities or opinions, one will compare themselves to others who are seen to be similar. It is also said that when others have a difference in abilities or opinions, one who is comparing themselves will almost always move their idea of what abilities or opinions are appropriate closer to the comparison others’.<ref>Festinger, L. (1954). A theory of social comparison processes. Human relations, 7(2), 117-140.</ref> In line with this theory, it makes sense that commuter couples would try to compare themselves to other married couples, but it will often pose problems for them because their relationships do differ in many ways. When commuter couples compare themselves to “traditional marriages”, it can cause them a lot of discomfort.<ref name=Gross1980>Gross, H. E. (1980). Dual-career couples who live apart: Two types. Journal of Marriage and the Family, 567-576.</ref> This is also true for society’s expectations of a commuter couple; if society compares them to “traditional couples”, they refrain from addressing important aspects of the relationship, and consequently lack a solid understanding. It was found that partners who felt that their peers thought that the commuting lifestyle was the beginning of a [[divorce]] experienced more [[stress (psychological)|stress]].<ref name=Jackson2000/>
=== Adjusting versus established couples ===
"Adjusting" couples are generally younger with few or no children, and they experience the separation earlier in their marriage. It seems that younger wives generally struggle more with the guilt that their husbands are disadvantaged in some way, and young husbands tend to feel a sense of loss in comparison to a traditional husband. These couples often experience more stress over the conflict of whose career is “more important” than the stress of being apart.
"Established" couples are generally older, have been married longer, and have children. With these couples, much of the stress comes from childcare. Generally, husbands will feel some resentment in the increase in responsibilities for the children, while the wives feel guilty about their lessened involvement in their children’s lives.<ref name=Gross1980/>
== Becoming a commuter couple ==
=== Attachment theory and perceived relationship quality ===
==== [[Attachment theory]] ====
In important romantic relationships, attachment refers to strong emotional bonding and the feeling of being secure.<ref>Bowlby, J. (1988). A secure base. New York: Basic.</ref> To maintain the security feelings, individuals stay in a comfortable range of proximity to their partner.<ref>Bowlby, J. (1969). Attachment and Loss: Vol. I: Attachment. New York, Basic Books.</ref> Under certain circumstances, even separation due to planned travel evokes concerns of the partner’s inaccessibility.<ref>Bowlby, J. (1973). Attachment and loss: Vol. II: Separation. New York: Basic Books.</ref> This inaccessibility may be associated with [[anxiety]], loneliness, and yearning for the partner. Through psychological (e.g., internal representation), symbolic (e.g., pictures), or physical proximity gaining accessibility, individuals calm down and restore security.
Three different attachment styles are identified by attachment researchers:<ref name=Mikulincer2007>Mikulincer, M., & Shaver, P. R. (2007). Attachment in adulthood: Structure, dynamics, and change. New York: Guilford.</ref> secure, avoidant, and anxiety attached. Those who are securely attached have positive views of the self and their partner, and are confident when seeking proximity to the partner. Avoidant individuals, with two subtypes, generally suppress desires of seeking for partners. Specifically, dismissing-avoidant individuals have a positive self-worth, but have a negative view of the partner, and prefer low emotional involvement. Fearful-avoidants have negative views of both the self and the partner and fear rejection. In contrast, individuals with anxiety attachment styles are hyperactive, continuously seeking and attempting to maintain partner proximity. Those who have anxious attachment styles have negative self-views, and the partner is considered essential to self-worth but insufficiently accessible. The Relationship Questionnaire by Bartholomew and Horowitz (1991) <ref>Bartholomew, K., & Horowitz, L. M. (1991). Attachment styles among young adults: A test of a four-category model. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 61, 226–244.</ref> and Experience in Close Relationship Scale by Brennan, Clark, and Shaver (1998) <ref>Brennan, K. A., Clark, C. L., & Shaver, P. R. (1998). Self-report measurement of adult attach- ment: An integrative overview.
In J. A. Simpson & W. S. Rholes (Eds.), Attachment theory and close relationships (pp. 46–76). New York: Guilford.</ref> are two commonly used measurements for attachment style. The Relationship Questionnaire assess attachment style by crossing the positive or negative view of self and partner. This questionnaire provides the categorical data, that means to categorize participants into four attachment styles without any scores. The Experience in Close Relationship Scale on the other hand, measures on a seven-point scale. People with lower scores are toward the attachment avoidance end, and people with higher scores are more likely to be attachment anxious style. This scale provides quantitative information about attachment style. Though the two scales can be used separately, they make up the categorical and interval part for each other. Thus, it is recommended to use both of them.<ref name=Pistole2010>Pistole, M. C., Roberts, A. & Chapman, M. L. (2010). Attachment, relationship maintenance, and stress in long distance and geographically close romantic relationships. Journal of Social and Personal Relationships, 27(4), 535-552.</ref> The combination of both scales have been proven valid in measuring attachment styles.<ref>Levy, K. N., Blatt, S. J., & Shaver, P. R. (1998). Attachment styles and parental representations. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 74(2), 407.</ref>
==== Perceived long-distance relationship quality ====
Secure attachment is related to positive relationship qualities (e.g., satisfaction; commitment).<ref name=Mikulincer2007/> Although it may seem counter-intuitive, [[long-distance relationships]] between securely attached individuals are perceived to be similar in relationship quality to relationships of securely attached individuals who are geographically close. Avoidant and anxious attachment style individuals who are involved in long-distance relationships perceive their relationship as lower quality than avoidant and anxious individuals in geographically close relationships. Commuter couples’ relationship quality are expected to differ based on the individuals’ attachment styles.<ref name=Pistole2010/> Recently, research found that commuter couples who meet on a monthly base (i.e., meet more than once a month) relationship quality was influenced by the separation.<ref>Van der Klis, M. & Karsten, L. (2009). Commuting partners, dual residences and the meaning of home. Journal of Environmental Psychology, 29, 235-245.</ref>
==== Decision-making processes ==== Some studies report that many couples do not go through an evaluation of the commuting lifestyle before they engage in it.<ref name=Anderson1992/><ref name=Anderson1993/><ref name=Gerstel1984/> Although the dual-career commuter couples are generally a highly educated and sophisticated group of people, the majority of the couples studied did not use a systematic [[decision-making]] process. The commuter couples did not collect information, talk to other commuting couples, or review other alternatives in making their decision to commute. Instead, the couples simply accepted that commuting was necessary and then discussed what the details of the impending separation would entail. In addition, two thirds of the couples made no plans to reevaluate the effectiveness of their decision to commute.<ref name=Anderson1992/><ref name=Anderson1993/> Despite these findings, there are couples who do go through a decision-making process. They are reported to have higher relationship satisfaction than those who did not go through a systematic decision-making process.<ref name=Anderson1992/>
== Practical implications == For the individual, there are a few suggestions to be made in regards to becoming a dual-career couple based on implications of past research. First, the [[division of labor]] should be discussed and made clear to both spouses, so it each individual’s expectations are apparent. The stability of the relationship should also be considered, as well as the possible reactions each individual might have in response to societal views. The expenses of traveling and each spouse’s history of being alone (i.e., their attachment styles) should be considered as well.<ref name=Magnuson1999/> Finally, couples should consider discussing the decision with other commuter couples to gain first-hand knowledge.<ref name=Anderson1993/> Organization, frequent communication, and rituals have been found to be three of the most important aspects of successfully maintaining a commuting lifestyle.<ref>Rotter, J. C., Barnett, D. E., & Fawcett, M. L. (1998). On the road again: Dual-career commuter relationships. The Family Journal, 6(1), 46-48.</ref> Weekly organized meetings can provide an opportunity for the couple to practice communication, improve organization, take care of household responsibilities, and keep in touch about past and future events.<ref>Bettner, B. L., & Lew, A. (1992). Raising kids who can: Using family meetings to nurture responsible, cooperative, caring, and happy children. New York: Harper Perennial.</ref><ref>Gerhart-Brooks, D. R., & Lyle, R. R. (1999). The family meeting: Facilitating dialogue with divorced families. Journal of Family Psychotherapy, 10(2), 77-82.</ref> Developing a set of rituals and schedules can help commuter couples ease the stress of departing and reuniting with each other.<ref>Johnson, S. E. (1987). Weaving the Threads: Equalizing Professional and Personal Demands Faced by Commuting Career Couples. Journal of the National Association of Women Deans, Administrators, and Counselors, 50(2), 3-10.</ref> Rituals such as daily phone calls, sharing dinner while talking on the phone, regular dependable visitation times, a predictable routine for reuniting and departing, special dinner dates for their first nights together, and leaving intimate messages and signs of affection have been found to be helpful for many commuter couples.<ref name=Magnuson1999/><ref name=Jackson2000/> These rituals help the couple establish a shared history that they can draw on during lonely moments.
== See also == *[[Attachment theory|Attachment Theory]] *[[Social comparison theory|Social Comparison Theory]] *[[Work-life balance|Work-life Balance]] *[[Long-distance relationship]]

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category Vermont State Senators to [[:Category:Vermont state senators]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 September 17]].
revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder | name = Edna Beard | image = Edna L. Beard (Vermont state legislator).jpg | caption = From the November 9, 1922 edition of ''The Bethel Courier'' newspaper (Bethel, VT) | office1 = Member of the [[Vermont Senate]] from [[Orange County, Vermont|Orange County]] | term_start1 = 1923 | term_end1 = 1925 | predecessor1 = John C. Sherburne | successor1 = Frederick H. Bickford | office2 = Member of the [[Vermont House of Representatives]] from the Town of [[Orange, Vermont|Orange]] | term_start2 = 1921 | term_end2 = 1923 | predecessor2 = Sherman Chamberlain | successor2 = Charles Colby | birth_date = {{Birth date|1877|07|25}} | birth_place = [[Chenoa, Illinois]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1928|09|18|1877|07|25}} | death_place = [[Orange, Vermont]] | resting_place = Orange Center Cemetery, Orange, Vermont | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | parents = Royal Edson Beard (1845-1912)
Flora (Curtiss) Beard (1849-1920) | education = [[Spaulding High School (Barre, Vermont)|Spaulding High School]] , [[Barre (city), Vermont|Barre, Vermont]] | occupation = School teacher and administrator
Town treasurer }} '''Edna Louisa Beard''' (July 25, 1877 – September 18, 1928) was the first woman legislator in [[Vermont]]; she was the first woman elected to the [[Vermont House of Representatives]], and the first woman elected to the [[Vermont Senate]].{{cite web| author=Edna Louisa Beard |url=http://womenshistory.vermont.gov/?TabId=61&personID=40 |title=Person Detail |publisher=Womenshistory.vermont.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-09-07}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vermonttoday.com/century/mostinflu/ebeard.html |title=Edna Beard |publisher=Vermonttoday.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-07}} A native of [[Illinois]], her parents were from [[Orange, Vermont]], and returned there in the early 1880s. Beard was raised and educated in Orange, graduated from [[Spaulding High School (Barre, Vermont)|Spaulding High School]] in [[Barre (city), Vermont|Barre]], and became a school teacher and administrator. She also served in local offices including town treasurer, and operated a dairy farm in partnership with one of her brothers. In 1920, the Constitution's Nineteenth Amendment made it possible for women to vote in statewide and national elections. Beard ran for the Republican nomination to represent Orange in the Vermont House of Representatives. She lost, and subsequently filed to run as a third party candidate. 40 women in Orange registered to vote between the primary and general elections, and enough supported her to tip the scales for Beard, who won the seat and became Vermont's first woman state legislator. She served one term, 1921 to 1923, and in 1922 was a successful candidate for the State Senate, becoming the first woman to serve in that body. She left politics in 1924 because of ill health, but remained active on her farm and in her church. Beard never married or had children. She died in Orange, and was buried at Orange Center Cemetery. ==Early life== Beard was born in [[Chenoa, Illinois]], the daughter of Royal Edson Beard (1845-1912) and Flora (Curtiss) Beard.{{cite news |date=November 9, 1922 |title=Orange Sends Woman to Senate |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/355351612/ |work=The Bethel Courier |location=Bethel, VT |page=4 |subscription=yes |via=[[Newspapers.com]] |ref={{sfnRef|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"}}}} Her family was originally from [[Orange, Vermont]], and they moved back to Orange in 1883.{{cite book|last1=Duffy|first1=John J.|last2=Hand|first2=Samuel B.|last3=Orth|first3=Ralph H.|title=The Vermont Encyclopedia|date=2003|publisher=University Press of New England|page=51|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uTBCXqOou0YC&pg=PA51&lpg=PA51 |ref={{sfnRef|''The Vermont Encyclopedia''}}}} She was educated in Orange, and graduated from [[Barre (city), Vermont|Barre]]'s [[Spaulding High School (Barre, Vermont)|Spaulding High School]] in 1896.{{sfn|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"|page=4}} Beard received her qualification as a teacher, and taught at several local area schools.{{sfn|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"|page=4}} She was both a teacher and superintendent of the Orange town schools beginning in 1906.{{sfn|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"|page=4}} She also served on the school board, was the town's assistant postmaster, and spent 16 years as town treasurer (1912-1928), after having succeeded to the office following the death of her father, who was the incumbent.{{sfn|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"|page=4}} Beard never married or had children, and she resided on a dairy farm she operated in partnership with her brother Frank.{{sfn|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"|page=4}} ==Political career== ===Vermont House=== In 1920, passage of the [[Nineteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution]] enabled women to vote in state and federal elections in Vermont. Beard ran for the [[Vermont House of Representatives]], and lost the Republican primary by six votes to Burt L. Richardson. Beard decided to run in the general election on the "Citizen's Party" line. Between the primary and general elections, 40 women in Orange registered to vote for the first time; in November, Beard defeated Richardson by 38 votes, and became the first woman elected to the Vermont House of Representatives.{{cite web|url=http://www.vpr.net/episode/33224/vermont-women-edna-beard/ |title=Vermont Women: Edna Beard |publisher=VPR |date= |accessdate=2013-09-07}} She was given the first choice of seats in the House, and, as reported by the ''[[Rutland Herald]]'', "She chose seat no 146, and for a long time no man had the courage to select seat no. 145, which adjoined hers. The seat stood vacant for over an hour until Horatio Luce of Pomfret took the dare of his fellow members and sat down beside Miss Beard amid a storm of laughter and applause." Her first bill in the Vermont House of Representatives, Act 218, was signed into law. It provided $2 a week child support for women whose husbands were "incapacitated by an incurable disease." Her [[maiden speech]] in the House was to second the renomination of Judge [[Stanley C. Wilson]] to the Vermont Superior Court, which contemporary news accounts indicated was received with "hearty applause."{{sfn|''The Vermont Encyclopedia''|page=4}} ===Vermont Senate=== In 1922 she was elected to Orange County's seat in the [[Vermont Senate]], and was the first woman to serve in that body.{{sfn|"Orange Sends Woman to Senate"|page=4}} She served one term, 1923 to 1925 and held a leadership role as chairwoman of the Senate Library Committee.{{sfn|''The Vermont Encyclopedia''|page=4}} Her first successful bill as Senator made it possible for county sheriffs to hire women as deputies. ==Later life== She was urged by supporters to enter the race for [[Lieutenant Governor of Vermont|lieutenant governor]] in 1924, but left politics because she was in ill health.{{sfn|''The Vermont Encyclopedia''|page=4}} She was active in her local Congregational church, including teaching Sunday school, singing in the choir, and serving as its clerk, and remained involved with the church until her death.{{sfn|''The Vermont Encyclopedia''|page=4}} ==Death and burial== Beard died in Orange on September 18, 1928.{{cite news |date=September 19, 1928 |title=Pioneer Woman Senator, Orange Official, Dies |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/197367354/ |work=[[Burlington Free Press]] |location=Burlington, VT |page=5 |subscription=yes |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} She was buried in the Beard family plot at Orange Center Cemetery in Orange.{{cite news |date=September 22, 1928 |title=Funeral of Miss Edna L. Beard |url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/197371496/ |work=[[Burlington Free Press]] |location=Burlington, VT |page=5 |subscription=yes |via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} ==Legacy== A portrait of Edna Beard by artist Ruth Mould is on display at the [[Vermont State House]].{{cite web|author=Oct. 23, 2016, 6:55 am |url=https://vtdigger.org/2016/10/23/vermonts-first-female-lawmaker-helped-women-claim-stake-statehouse/ |title=Then again: Vermont's first female lawmaker helped women claim a stake in the Statehouse |publisher=VTDigger |date=2016-10-16 |accessdate=2016-10-23}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Findagrave|14006373}} *{{cite news|title=Beard Family Papers|url=http://vermonthistory.org/documents/findaid/beard.pdf|publisher=Vermont Historical Society|date=1831–1945}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Beard, Edna}} [[Category:Women state legislators in Vermont]] [[Category:Members of the Vermont House of Representatives]] [[Category:Vermont state senators]] [[Category:1877 births]] [[Category:1928 deaths]] [[Category:People from Barre, Vermont]] [[Category:Vermont Republicans]] [[Category:People from Chenoa, Illinois]] [[Category:People from Orange, Vermont]] [[Category:20th-century American educators]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:20th-century American women politicians]] [[Category:American women educators]] [[Category:Educators from Illinois]] [[Category:Educators from Vermont]] [[Category:Deaths from cerebrovascular disease]] [[Category:Burials in Vermont]]

revision.comment: /* Get Me Roger Stone */
revision.text:
'''Fredrik Stanton''' is an American author and filmmaker.
==Biography== Stanton was a publisher for the ''[[Columbia Daily Spectator]]'' while at [[Columbia University]]. He has served as an election monitor in [[Armenia]], the [[Georgia (country)|Republic of Georgia]], [[Bosnia]], [[Kosovo]] and [[Azerbaijan]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fredrikstanton.com/bio.html |title=Fredrik Stanton |first=|last=|publisher=FredriSstanton.com |year=2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref>
==Works==
===''Great Negotiations''=== {{main|Great Negotiations: Agreements that Changed the Modern World}} Stanton's book ''Great Negotiations: Agreements that Changed the Modern World'' was published in 2010.<ref>{{cite book |title=Great Negotiations: Agreements that Changed the Modern World |last=Stanton |first=Fredrik |year=2010 |publisher=Westholme Publishing |location=Yardley, Pennsylvania |isbn=978-1-59416-099-8 |page=|pages=|url=}}<!--|accessdate=20 October 2011--></ref> The book was noted as unusual for focusing on negotiating content and the diplomatic process, rather than the direct major policy results or the diplomatic developments which resulted from the negotiations discussed therein.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unc.edu/depts/diplomat/item/2010/0103/book/book_mattox_negotiations.html |title=Great Negotiations: Agreements That Changed the Modern World |first=Henry |last=Mattox |work=unc.edu |date=1 March 2010 |accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref>
The book presents the negotiations in a story-like format that "reads like fiction" in order to "appeal to both casual historians and those more conversant in international relations and foreign policy."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogcritics.org/books/article/book-review-great-negotiations-agreements-that/ |title=Book Review: Great Negotiations: Agreements that Changed the Modern World by Fredrik Stanton - Blogcritics Books |first=|last=Emm|work=[[Blogcritics]] |year=2011|accessdate=20 October 2011}}</ref> The book has been considered as a learning tool.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Sebenius | first1 = J. K. | title = What Can We Learn from Great Negotiations? | doi = 10.1111/j.1571-9979.2011.00306.x | journal = Negotiation Journal | volume = 27 | issue = 2 | pages = 251–256 | year = 2011 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref>
===Uprising=== ''Uprising'' is a documentary about the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. Stanton was director, writer, and producer of the film.<ref>{{cite journal|authors=Claire McCurdy and John Lyman|title=Interview with Fredrik Stanton, director of Uprising|date=January 20, 2013|url=http://www.internationalpolicydigest.org/2013/01/20/interview-with-fredrik-stanton-director-of-uprising/}}</ref><ref name="beiruitinternationalfilmfest">{{cite web |url=http://www.beirutfilmfestival.org/portfolio/uprising/ |title=Films: ''Uprising'' |date=October 4, 2012 |publisher=[[Beirut International Film Festival]] |accessdate=January 9, 2013 |archivedate=January 10, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6DZJg1CmK?url=http://alexandriafilm.org/2012/11/05/alexandria-film-festival-2012-saturdays-and-sundays-schedules/ |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> The film includes amateur footage of the protests.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Menken|first=Robin|title=Uprising, a film by Fredrik Stanton|journal=Cinema Without Borders|date=2013-01-27|url=http://cinemawithoutborders.com/reviews/3288-uprising-fredrik-stanton.html}}</ref> [[The Hollywood Reporter]]'s review stated that the film's presentation was straightforward and informative.<ref>{{cite journal|last=DeFore|first=John|title=Uprising: Film Review|journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=January 5, 2013|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/uprising-film-review-408906}}</ref>
The film premiered at the [[Beirut International Film Festival]], held October 3—11, 2012.<ref name="beiruitinternationalfilmfest" />
=== ''Get Me Roger Stone'' === Stanton was a producer for ''[[Get Me Roger Stone]]'', a 2017 American [[documentary film]] exploring the career of political strategist and lobbyist [[Roger Stone]]. The film premiered at the [[Tribeca Film Festival]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/04/24/get-me-roger-stone-tribeca-film-festival/|title=Essential, Staggering 'Get Me Roger Stone' Rocks Tribeca Film Festival|date=2017-04-24|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en-US}}</ref> and has since been available worldwide on Netflix.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ew.com/movies/2017/03/29/get-me-roger-stone-trailer-trump-netflix/|title=Meet the Man Who Made Trump a Political Figure in 'Get Me Roger Stone'|date=2017-03-29|work=EW.com|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en-US}}</ref> It garnered critical acclaim and Oscar buzz.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/oscars-a-crowded-field-doc-foreign-contenders-has-begun-emerge-1019549|title=Oscars: A Crowded Field of Doc and Foreign Contenders Has Begun to Emerge|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2017-09-16|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.fredrikstanton.com}} * [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5092931/?ref_=fn_al_nm_2 "Fredrik Stanton"] on [[IMDb]] * {{cite web | url =http://blogcritics.org/books/article/an-interview-with-fredrik-stanton-author/ | title =An Interview With Fredrik Stanton, Author of ''Great Negotiations'' | first=Mandy | last =Southgate | publisher =Blogcritics.org | date =May 24, 2010 | accessdate =June 15, 2013}} * {{cite web | url =http://bigthink.com/fredrikstanton | title =Fredrik Stanton | publisher =BigThink.com | accessdate =June 15, 2013}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Stanton, Fredrik}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:Political science educators]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Frost Entomological Museum | alt = | map_type = | map_caption = | map_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|40.803706|-77.862041|display=inline}} | established = 1969 | location = [[Penn State University]], [[University Park, PA]], [[Pennsylvania]] | type = Natural History Museum | collection = 2 million specimens | website = https://sites.psu.edu/frost }} The '''Frost Entomological Museum''' is an active research institution, associated with the [[Pennsylvania State University]]'s flagship campus in [[University Park, PA]]. The museum houses a research collection, estimated at 2 million <ref>{{cite web|title=Insect Holdings|url=http://ento.psu.edu/facilities/frost/holdings|website=The Frost Entomological Museum at Penn State|publisher=Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences|accessdate=30 July 2015}}</ref> arthropod specimens, and a public exhibition and educational space. Although the museum was founded in 1969, much of the collection dates to the early 1900s and even the late 1800s. [[File:Frost museum pond with goose.jpg|thumb|upright=1.3|Ten acre pond, near the museum]] The research collection provides a record of the [[insect biodiversity]] of the [[Commonwealth of Pennsylvania]] and the eastern and southeastern United States. Major collection holdings include: * [[Aphididae]] - The John O. Pepper aphid collection consists of over 32,000 mounted specimens, representing at least 800<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Carl|first1=W.|title=John O. Pepper|journal=American Entomologist|date=1996|volume=42|issue=2|page=126|url=http://ae.oxfordjournals.org/content/ae/42/2/126.1.full.pdf}} </ref> species. The collection is especially strong in aphids from central Pennsylvania. * [[Anoplura]] - The K. C. Kim collection of sucking lice comprises more than 15,000 slide-mounts and represents approximately 300 species. * [[Odonata]] - The George H. and Alice F. Beatty Collection includes more than 60,000 dragonfly and damselfly specimens, collected from the 1940s through the 1970s. More than 1,000 species are represented, and half of the specimens were collected in Mexico.
Other notable collections, which reflect the interests of the museum’s namesake, Dr. [[Stuart W. Frost]], include [[leaf miner]]s, light-trapped insects,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Frost|first1=S.W.|title=Insects Taken in Light Traps at the Archbold Biological Station, Highlands County, Florida|journal=The Florida Entomologist|date=1964|volume=47|issue=2|pages=129–161|jstor=3493289|doi=10.2307/3493289|url=http://journals.fcla.edu/flaent/article/view/56135}}</ref> and arthropods of the [[Archbold Biological Station]].
== References == <references />
== External References == * [http://www.psu.edu/Penn State University] * [http://ento.psu.edu/ Penn State University Department of Entomology] * [http://ento.psu.edu/facilities/frost/ The Frost Entomological Museum]
[[Category:Pennsylvania State University]] [[Category:Museums in Centre County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Natural history museums in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Research museums in the United States]] [[Category:University museums in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Entomological organisations]] [[Category:1969 establishments in Pennsylvania]]
