revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox university | logo = [[File:Logo FuseNet Association (png).png]] | name = FuseNet Association | affiliations = The European Fusion Education Network | established = 2008 | chairman = prof.dr. N.J. (Niek) Lopes Cardozo | website = http://www.fusenet.eu }} {{Clear left}} '''FuseNet''' is an organization that unites, coordinates and sponsors European educational efforts in the field of [[nuclear fusion]] in order to increase, enhance, and broaden fusion training and education activities in [[Europe]].
== The FP7 Project == The FuseNet project exists of the establishment of a European Fusion Education Network (FuseNet) for education in fusion science and technology. The purpose of FuseNet is to coordinate and facilitate fusion education, to share best practices, to jointly develop educational tools, to organize educational events. The members of FuseNet have jointly established academic criteria for the award of European Fusion Doctorate and Master Certificates. These criteria are set to stimulate a high level of fusion education throughout Europe.
The FuseNet project started in October 2008 as a Coordination and Support Action under the [[seventh Framework Programme]], with financial support of the [[European Commission]]. The project consists of eleven focused work packages, with a total budget of 2 Million Euro. The project runs until October 1, 2013 and is bringing together a broad representation from the European fusion community with 36 participants from 18 countries, of which 22 Universities and 14 Euratom Associations.
The project consists of four groups of coordination actions: the establishment and running of the FuseNet network; development of individual learning opportunities and common educational goals; development of educational materials and hands-on experiments; and funding of joint educational activities.
== The Association == The FuseNet Association is an independent legal entity that was founded in December 2010 to form the sustainable continuation of the activities started by the equally named FuseNet project. The association provides a platform for the coordination of European fusion education activities, the initiation, development and implementation of new EU-wide actions, and for the exchange and dissemination of fusion education information. All European organizations that are active in the field of fusion education and research are welcome to join the association. FuseNet is the umbrella organization and single voice for the training and education of the next generation fusion engineers and scientists. FuseNet is recognized as such by the European Commission.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.fusenet.eu FuseNet Website] * [http://fusenet.eu/members FuseNet Members] * [http://fusenet.eu/events FuseNet Events]
[[Category:Nuclear fusion| ]] [[Category:Science education]]

revision.text:
{{update|date=February 2012}} '''[[Higher education]] in [[China]]''' centers on a system of 2,000 universities and colleges, with more than six million students.<ref>Fuzeng, Yu. [http://www.internationaleducationmedia.com/china/index.htm China: Universities Colleges and Schools.] International Education Media.</ref> The system includes Bachelors, Masters and Doctoral degrees, as well as non-degree programs, and is also open to foreign students.
The [[Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China]] (MOE) is the government authority for all matters pertaining to education and language. The MOE notes that higher education in China has played a significant part in economic growth, scientific progress and social development in the country "by bringing up large scale of advanced talents and experts for the construction of socialist modernization."<ref name="Higher Education in China">Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China. [http://www.moe.edu.cn/english/higher_h.htm Higher Education in China.] Beijing, PRC.</ref>
China is also a major destination for international students,<ref name=USNEWS>{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/top-world-universities/articles/2013/10/08/explore-the-worlds-top-universities?page=2 |title=Explore the World's Top Universities |last=Sheehy |first=Kelsey |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |date=October 8, 2013 |quote=Asia is among the fastest growing destinations for international students, and foreign enrollment at universities in Indonesia and South Korea have more than doubled since 2005, the agency reports. China continues to be the most popular destination in the region, though, ranking third among countries that host the most international students, IIE reports. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024162032/http://www.usnews.com/education/top-world-universities/articles/2013/10/08/explore-the-worlds-top-universities?page=2 |archivedate=October 24, 2014 |df= }}</ref> being the most popular country in Asia for international students, and the third most popular in the world.<ref name=USNEWS/> China is on track to overtake the United Kingdom as the second most popular country for international students by 2020. <ref>{{cite news|last1=China's higher education|title=China to overtake UK as a study abroad destination - China - Chinadaily.com.cn|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2016-09/17/content_26811371.htm|work=www.chinadaily.com.cn|date=17 September 2016}}</ref>
== History == {{See also|History of education in China}}
The traditional Chinese education system is based on [[Legalism (Chinese philosophy)|legalist]] and [[Confucianism|Confucian]] ideals. The teaching of [[Confucius]] has shaped the overall Chinese mindset for the past 2500 years.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Zhang|first1=Dongmei|title=The situation of Chinese students in Germany: an intercultural perspective}}</ref> But, other outside forces have played a large role in the nation's educational development. The [[First Opium War]] of 1840, for example, opened China to the rest of the world. As a result, Chinese intellectuals discovered the numerous western advances in science and technology. This new information greatly impacted the higher education system and curriculum.
A number of institutions lay claim to being the first university in China. [[Peking University]] is the first formally established modern national university of China. It was founded as '''Imperial Capital University''' ({{zh|c=京師大學堂}}) in 1898 in [[Beijing]] as a replacement of the ancient '''[[Guozijian]]''' ({{zh|c=國子監}}), the national central institute of learning in China's traditional educational system. Meanwhile, [[Wuhan University]] also claimed that its predecessor '''Ziqiang Institute''' ({{lang|zh-hant|自強學堂}}) was the first modern higher education institution in China. On November 29, 1893, [[Zhang Zhidong]] submitted his memorial to [[Guangxu Emperor]] to request for approval to set up an institution designed for training students specializing in foreign languages, mathematics, science and business. After Ziqiang was founded in [[Wuchang District|Wuchang]], not only courses in foreign languages was taught, courses in science (chemical and mining courses starting from 1896) and business (business course starting from the very beginning) were also developed at the school.<ref name="自强学堂（简介）">{{cite web| url=http://edu.gmw.cn/2012-12/06/content_5931078.htm| title=自强学堂（简介）| accessdate=February 12, 2013| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130403173448/http://edu.gmw.cn/2012-12/06/content_5931078.htm| archivedate=April 3, 2013| df=}}</ref> Later, although the school officially changed its name to '''Foreign Languages Institute''' ({{lang|zh-hant|方言學堂}}) in 1902, the school still offered courses in science and business.<ref name="自强学堂（简介）"/> In China, there had been some earlier schools specializing in foreign languages learning, such as '''Schools of Combined Learning''' in [[Beijing]] ({{lang|zh-hant|京師同文館}}, founded in 1862<ref group=remark>In 1902, School of Combined Learning in Beijing was merged with Imperial Capital University, now Peking University. However, Peking University never claims 1862 as its year founded. Neither does Peking University claim the year of establishing the [[Guozijian]], which can date back more than one thousand years. [[Hunan University]], with a similar history with Peking, often traced its history back to a school established in 976 A.D, thus giving this university a thousand years of history. See {{cite web |url=http://www.hnu.edu.cn/html/hudagaikuang/xuexiaojianjie/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150307204933/http://www.hnu.edu.cn/html/hudagaikuang/xuexiaojianjie/ |archivedate=2015-03-07 |df= }}.</ref>), in [[Shanghai]] ({{lang|zh-hant|上海同文館/上海廣方言館}}, founded in 1863), and in [[Guangzhou]] ({{lang|zh-hant|廣州同文館}}), founded in 1864, but few provided courses in other fields, which hardly qualified as modern education institutions. Some argued that [[Wuhan University]] can only traced its history back to 1913, when the '''National Wuchang Higher Normal College''' ({{lang|zh-hant|國立武昌高等師範學校}}) was established, but [[Wuhan University]] officially recognized its establishment as in 1893, relying on the abundance of historical documentation and the experts' endorsement.<ref name = "武大回应120年校史有史实依据 校庆活动不会改">{{cite web | author = | title = 武大回应120年校史有史实依据 校庆活动不会改 | publisher = 武汉晚报 | date = 2012-12-07 | url = http://news.xinhuanet.com/edu/2012-12/07/c_124061529.htm}}</ref> In 1895, [[Sheng Xuanhuai]] ({{zh|c=盛宣懷}}) submitted a [[Official Communications of the Chinese Empire#Memorials|memorial]] to [[Guangxu Emperor]] to request for approval to set up a modern higher education institution in [[Tianjin]]. After approval on October 2, 1895, '''Peiyang Western Study School''' ({{zh|c=天津北洋西學學堂}}) was founded by him and American educator [[Charles Daniel Tenney]] ({{zh|c=丁家立}}) and later developed to '''Peiyang University''' ({{zh|c=北洋大學堂}}). In 1896, [[Sheng Xuanhuai]] ({{zh|c=盛宣懷}}) delivered his new memorials to [[Guangxu Emperor]] to make suggestion that two official modern higher education institutions should be established in [[Beijing]] and [[Shanghai]]. In the same year, he founded '''Nanyang Public School''' ({{zh|南洋公學}}) in [[Shanghai]] by an imperial edict issued by [[Guangxu Emperor]]. The institution initially included elementary school, secondary school, college, and a normal school. Later the institution changed its name to '''[[Shanghai Jiao Tong University|Jiao Tong University]]''' (also known as '''Chiao Tung University''', {{zh|交通大學}}). In the 1930s, the university was well known in the world as the "Eastern [[MIT]]"<ref>[http://zhiyuan.sjtu.edu.cn/History.aspx ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722053106/http://zhiyuan.sjtu.edu.cn/History.aspx |date=July 22, 2011 }}</ref><ref>[http://zhiyuan.sjtu.edu.cn/Pages.aspx?Index=10 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330133706/http://zhiyuan.sjtu.edu.cn/Pages.aspx?Index=10 |date=March 30, 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.qstheory.cn/kj/jy/201112/t20111212_129227.htm |title=践行钱学森教育思想 造就拔尖创新人才_教育视点_求是理论网 |publisher=Qstheory.cn |date= |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref> due to its reputation of nurturing top engineers and scientists. In the 1950s, part of this university was moved to [[Xi'an]], an ancient capital city in [[northwest China]], and was established as [[Xi'an Jiaotong University]]; the part of the university remaining in [[Shanghai]] was renamed [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]]. These two universities have developed independently since then. [[Tianjin University]] celebrated its 100th anniversary in 1995, followed by [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University|Jiao Tong University]] (both in [[Shanghai]] and [[Xi'an]]) in 1996. Other leading universities, such as [[Zhejiang University]] (1897), [[Peking University]] (1898), [[Nanjing University]] (1902), [[Central China Normal University]] (1903), [[Fudan University]] (1905)，[[Tongji University]] (1907) and [[Tsinghua University]] (1911) also recently celebrated their hundredth anniversaries, one after another.
[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] influence in the early 1950s brought all higher education under government leadership. Research was separated from teaching. The government also introduced a central plan for a nationally unified instruction system, i.e. texts, syllabi, etc. The impact of this shift can still be seen today. Chinese higher education continues its struggle with excessive departmentalisation, segmentation, and overspecialisation in particular.
From 1967 to 1976, China’s [[Cultural Revolution]] took another toll on higher education, which was devastated more than any other sector of the country. The enrollment of postsecondary students can be used as example to illustrate the impacts. The number dropped from 674,400 to 47,800. This has had a major impact on education in the 21st century. The decline in educational quality was profound.
In 1977, Deng Xiaoping made the decision of resuming the [[National Higher Education Entrance Examination]] ([[Gao Kao]]), having profound impact on Chinese higher education in history. From the 1980s on, Chinese higher education has undergone a series of reforms that have slowly brought improvement. The government found that schools lacked the flexibility and autonomy to provide education according to the needs of the society. Structural reform of higher education consists of five parts: *reforms of education provision *management *investment *recruitment and job-placement *inner-institute management—the most difficult.<ref name="Higher Education in China"/> The reforms aim to provide higher education institutions more autonomy and the ability to better meet the needs of students. Instead of micromanagement, the state aims to provide general planning.
The [[Provisional Regulations Concerning the Management of Institutions of Higher Learning]], promulgated by the State Council in 1986, led to a number of changes in administration and adjusted educational opportunity, direction and content. Reform allowed universities and colleges to: * choose their own teaching plans and curricula * to accept projects from or cooperate with other socialist establishments for scientific research and technical development in setting up "combines" involving teaching, scientific research, and production * to suggest appointments and removals of vice presidents and other staff members; * to take charge of the distribution of capital construction investment and funds allocated by the state * to be responsible for the development of international exchanges by using their own funds.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}}
Reforms picked up the pace in 2000, with the state aiming to complete the reform of 200 universities operating under China's ministries and start 15 university-based scientific technology parks.<ref>[http://www.internationaleducationmedia.com/china/index.htm China to Accelerate Higher Education Reform.] People's Daily Online. 27 January 2000.</ref>
==Present day== In 2002, there were slightly over 2000 higher education institutions in PRC. Close to 1400 were regular higher education institutions ([[HEIs]]). A little more than 600 were higher education institutions for adults. Combined enrollment in 2002 was 11,256,800. Of this close to 40 percent were new recruits. Total graduate student enrollment was 501,000.<ref name="Higher Education in China"/> The number of graduates from Chinese higher educational institutions increased from 1 million per year in 2000 to 7 million per year in 2010.<ref>Caron, Christina. “China and Canada: Economic Linkages, Migration, and the Canadian Labour Market.” ''Canada-China Human Capital Dialogue''. Conference held at Ottawa, November 28, 2012.</ref>
In 2005, there were about 4,000 Chinese institutions. Student enrollment increased to 15 million, with rapid growth that was expected to peak in 2008. However, the higher education system does not meet the needs of 85 percent of the college-age population.<ref name="acenet.edu">Porter, Susan. [http://www.acenet.edu/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Home&CONTENTID=11822&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm Higher Education in China: The Next Super Power is Coming of Age.] American Council on Education. 2005.</ref>
Since 1998, 10 universities have been targeted by the Chinese government to become “world-class” — including Peking and Tsinghua universities. To achieve that goal, the government promised to increase the education allocation in the national budget by 1 percent a year for each of the five years following 1998. When CPC General secretary Chinese president Jiang Zemin attended the 100th anniversary ceremony at Peking University (Beida) in 1998 and the 90th anniversary ceremony at Tsinghua University in 2001, he emphasized this ambitious goal of advancing several of China's higher education institutions into the top tier of universities worldwide in the next several decades.
In the meantime, China has received education aid from UNESCO and many other international organizations and sources, including the World Bank, which loaned China $14.7 billion for educational development.
Since 2007, China has become the sixth largest country in hosting international students. The top ten countries with students studying in China include South Korea, Japan, USA, Vietnam, Thailand, Russia, India, Indonesia, France and Pakistan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinanews.com.cn/edu/kong/news/2008/09-02/1367538.shtml |title=中国成第六大留学目的地 上年外国学生约20万名 |publisher=Chinanews.com.cn |date= |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinaedunet.com/news/liuxue/2008/9/content_150885.shtml |title=中国成第六大留学目的地[图]—中国教育网_新闻资讯_出国留学 |publisher=Chinaedunet.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111031929/http://www.chinaedunet.com/news/liuxue/2008/9/content_150885.shtml |archivedate=2013-11-11 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chinanews.com/edu/kong/news/2008/09-02/1367538.shtml |title=中国成第六大留学目的地 上年外国学生约20万名 |publisher=Chinanews.com |date= |accessdate=2013-11-11}}</ref> The number of international students studying in China often ranges around 200,000.
In spring 2007 China planned to conduct a national evaluation of its universities. The results of this evaluation would be used to support the next major planned policy initiative. The last substantial national evaluation of universities was in 1994. That evaluation resulted in the 'massification' of higher education with a renewed emphasis on elite institutions and education through initiatives like [[Project 985]] in the late 1990s and the [[Thousand Talents Program (China)|Thousand Talents Program]] which was launched in 2008.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.conferenceboard.ca/e-library/abstract.aspx?did=7819|title=The Thousand Talents Program: Lessons From China About Faculty Recruitment and Retention|website=www.conferenceboard.ca|access-date=2016-03-16}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} Since 2010, in some of the elite institutions, there has been an attempt at introducing some aspects of an American-style liberal arts curriculum for selected students.<ref>Karin Fischer, "[http://chronicle.com/article/Bucking-Cultural-Norms-Asia/130667/?sid=gn cultural norms, Asia tries liberal arts]" ''Chronicle of Higher Education'' February 5, 2012</ref>
According to data from 2015 of the [[People's Republic of China Ministry of Education]], there were 2,845 Chinese National Higher Institutions, including 2,553 National General Colleges and Universities and 292 [[Adult Higher Institutions]].<ref name="ReferenceA">"2015 National College List" ''People's Republic of China Ministry of Education'' May 21, 2015</ref> The number of enrolled college students including undergraduate students, master and PhD students was 23.91 million in 2012.<ref>"2012 College Students statistics" ''People's Republic of China Ministry of Education'' May 01, 2013</ref> From 2010 to 2015, the Chinese graduates continued to increase dramatically with almost 7.5 million new graduates entering the job market in 2015.<ref>"2015 Chinese College Graduates Employment Report" ''People's Republic of China Ministry of Education'' July 20, 2015</ref> Investment in education accounted for about 4% of total [[GDP]] in China in 2015.<ref name="chinaeducenter.com">[http://www.chinaeducenter.com/en/cedu.php "China Education" ''China Education Center Ltd'']</ref> The Chinese government has been more concerned about education, particularly higher education, in the last decades.
International students have enrolled in over 775 higher education institutions in China.<ref name="chinaeducenter.com"/> Until 2014, there were more than 377,000 foreign students from 203 countries or regions study in China.<ref>"2014 Statistics of Foreign Students in China " ''People's Republic of China Ministry of Education'' March 08, 2015</ref>
Although numbers of students have been increasing there are some serious concerns about the quality of education they are receiving and the skills they have at graduation. One study estimates that only 1.2 million of 15.7 million university graduates (or 7.6%) have skills that are valued by international markets for human capital.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mckinsey.com/global-themes/china/addressing-chinas-looming-talent-shortage|title=Addressing China's looming talent shortage|website=McKinsey & Company|access-date=2016-03-16}}</ref> In other words, the vast majority of students educated in Chinese universities do not have adequate skills to compete in anything but the most local Chinese industries.
==Admission process== A student's score in the [[National Higher Education Entrance Examination]] (Gaokao) is the primary consideration used for admission into universities in China. Regional education development imbalance leads to the different treatment of students from different regions. Enrollment rules in China are based on the scores on the Gaokao, but a given university's minimum score threshold varies depending on the [[Provinces of China|province]] an applicant is from and the degree of competition in applicants from the province. The more you have more top universities in a region, the better chances its students will be enrolled into a top university.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} The university admission quotes are not based on the area's population but the university’s enrollment plan. In some populous provinces, the competition is extremely fierce, while, in some areas with more institutions, such as [[Beijing]] or [[Shanghai]], access to a prestigious university is more attainable.
==Types of colleges and universities== In China, according to ownership-based categories of HEIs, the higher education can be divided into two categories---State-owned or government-owned HEIs, including [[Regular HEIs]], [[Independent Institutions]], [[Higher Vocational Colleges]], [[Adult HEIs]], and non-government or [[private universities]] <ref>{{cite book|authors=Zhu, HongZhen and Lou Shiyan|title=Development and Reform of Higher Education in China|publisher=Woodhead Publishing Limited |isbn=9781843346395|date=2011|pages=41–42}}</ref> Due to the long-time influence by [[Soviet Union]] and late development of [[private universities]], it has deeply rooted in Chinese heart that government-owned is much better than private ones.<ref>{{cite book|authors=Zhu, HongZhen and Lou Shiyan|title=Development and Reform of Higher Education in China|publisher=Woodhead Publishing Limited |isbn=9781843346395|date=2011|pages=1–9 }}</ref> Regular HEIs is the cornerstone in China’s higher education, while private universities development could not be ignored.<ref>{{cite report|title=2015 National College List|publisher=People's Republic of China Ministry of Education|date=21 May 2015}}</ref>
According to the latest data(2015) of [[People's Republic of China Ministry of Education]], total number of Chinese National Higher Institutions is 2845, including 2,553 National General Colleges and Universities and 292 Adult Higher Institutions.<ref name="ReferenceA"/> Government-owned HEIs are likely to receive more policy and finance support from official level.
Compared with state-owned universities, private universities’ development is in an awkward position. Different with private universities in Western world, China’s private education is a complement to public universities to meet the needs for those who failed in their college entrance examination and who could not afford the tuition fees to study abroad. Due to the large population, [[Chinese public universities]] are impossible to satisfy everyone’s needs. Under this condition, private universities of China come into being. The advantages of their professional setting that more in line with market requirements could not make up for the lack of financial funds and students. Actually, these two factors are equal. The source of funds for them depends largely on students’ tuition fees <ref>{{cite journal|authors=Zhou, Guoping and Xie,Zuoyu|title=Bankruptcy Analysis of China’s Private Universities|journal=XiaMen University Press|date=12 May 2006|pages=46–53}}</ref>
Except of competition from public universities and other [[sino-foreign cooperative private institution]], the most deadly weakness is that Chinese officials deny acknowledging their degree. In [[Private Education Promotion Law of the People’s Republic of China]], it clearly indicates that “Private university degree is that national recognition of the non national education series, belonging to private colleges awarded diplomas”.<ref name="360doc.com">{{cite act |title=Private Education Promotion Law of the People’s Republic of China |type=Education Act |number=IV |language=Chinese |date=28 Dec 2002 ||articletype=Education |url=http://www.360doc.com/content/13/1205/13/7499155_334668953.shtml |accessdate=1 Sep 2003}}</ref>
Though followed by “The educated in Private colleges enjoy the same level and rights in further education, employment, social welfare, and participation in advanced selection with the educated public schools” ,<ref name="360doc.com"/> it can hardly compensate the flaw that the degree belonging to only private colleges awarded diplomas, but no acknowledgement by officials.
===C9 League=== The [[C9 League]] (simplified Chinese: 九校联盟; traditional Chinese: 九校聯盟) is an official alliance of nine elite and prestigious universities in mainland China, initiated by the Chinese Central Government through Project 985 to promote the development and reputation of Higher education in China. Together they account for 3% of the country's researchers but receive 10% of national research expenditures.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storyCode=415193&sectioncode=26 |title=Eastern stars: Universities of China's C9 League excel in select fields}}</ref> [[People's Daily]], an official newspaper of the Chinese Communist Party, refers to the C9 League as ''China's Ivy League.''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://en.people.cn/203691/7822275.html |title=China's Ivy League: C9 League |access-date=17 Apr 2018 |website= People's Daily}}</ref>
This group of 9 elite universities includes [[Fudan University]], [[Harbin Institute of Technology]], [[Nanjing University]], [[Peking University]], [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]], [[Tsinghua University]], [[University of Science and Technology of China]], [[Xi'an Jiaotong University]], and [[Zhejiang University]].
Many other lists of elite Chinese universities exists. The C9 League dominates in terms of faculty recruitment, with disproportionate numbers of faculty who receive China's top two academic awards: the [[Changjiang Scholars Program|Changjiang (Yangtze River) Scholar award]] and the [[Thousand Talents Program (China)|Thousand Talents Professorship]].
==Challenges==
China exhibits a great need for better regulation as well as more academic qualifications, teaching experience, and understanding of social changes and technology. To achieve success, the state realizes that the impacts of the Cultural Revolution on education must be reversed. To this end, top universities now function as centers of excellence that serve as a model for all other institutes. A helpful model involved "twinning" of poorer institutes with model institutes to provide equipment, curricula, and faculty development.
There is also an issue of funding and equity. Although academic praise reforms for moving the higher education sector from a unified, centralized and closed system to one that allows openness and diversification, they understand that decentralization and semi-privatization has led to further inequity in educational opportunity. [[Graduate unemployment]] rates are also a growing concern.
There is growing concern about the mindset of students produced by Chinese institutions, where cheating is widespread and tolerated.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kreutzmann|first1=Rasmus|title=Up to 90% of Chinese Exchange Students Have Hired Essay Ghostwriters|url=https://jitterymonks.com/report-90-chinese-exchange-students-purchasing-essays-online/|website=The Jittery Monks|accessdate=21 March 2018}}</ref> Many corporations feel the quality of [[Rote learning|rote memorization]] instilled in Chinese students serves as a detriment to creative thinking and the lack of real-world experience during the formative years negatively impacts students' ability to adapt to the global business environment easily. These issues will need to be addressed in the coming years if China aims to continue its drive for excellence.<ref>[http://www.economist.com/business/displaystory.cfm?story_id=E1_GRSRPJS Wach Out, India: China is way behind India in the business of outsourced services, but it has now started to catch up.] The Economist. 4 May 2006.</ref>
Unemployment rates are quite high among Chinese graduates. Because of expansion of universities in China last decades, more students had access to receive higher education. With continuous graduates’ entry into employment market, graduate unemployment is highlighted. China’s recent upsurge in graduate unemployment has specific causes relating to economic development, education policy-making, and reforms in the economy as well as in higher education.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Bai|first1=Liming|title=Graduate Unemployment: Dilemmas and Challenges in China's Move to Mass Higher Education|journal=Cambridge University Press on behalf of School of Oriental and African Studies |date=Mar 2006|pages=128–144}}</ref>
==International students== With China’s rising national strength and popularity of Chinese in the world, China as a study destination attracts thousands of foreign students abroad and the number of foreign students continues to grow rapidly in recent years. According to 2014 data from Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China, there are more than 377,054 foreign students studies in all the 31 provinces in China, with an increase of 5.77% over the same period last year.<ref name="moe.edu.cn">"2014 Statistics of Foreign Students in China " ''People's Republic of China Ministry of Education'' [http://www.moe.edu.cn/publicfiles/business/htmlfiles/moe/s5987/201503/184959.html] March 08, 2015</ref> In 2015, a record breaking 397,635 international students went to China, solidifying its position as the third most popular destination country for overseas students.<ref>"China's Rapid Rise As An Academic Destination" ''Student.com'' [https://www.student.com/articles/chinas-rapid-rise-academic-destination/] September 12, 2016</ref> While US and the UK attracted nearly one-third of all globally mobile students, their leadership is under threat in the "Third Wave" of political turbulence and intense competition from English-medium Instruction or English-taught Programs in countries like China and Continental Europe.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Choudaha|first=Rahul|date=March 2017|title=Three waves of international student mobility (1999-2020)|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B4RmnCsexL7ZckFpR1FXVFFQZ2M/view|journal=Studies in Higher Education|volume=|pages=|doi=10.1080/03075079.2017.1293872|via=}}</ref>
The largest source of foreign students comes from Asia, accounting almost 60% of the total, followed by Europe 18%, Africa 11% respectively.<ref name="moe.edu.cn"/> For individual country, the top three countries of origins are South Korea (62,923), United States (24,203) and Thailand (21,296).<ref name="moe.edu.cn"/> Only 10% of foreign students receive Chinese Government Scholarship and the rest 90% are self-funded.<ref name="moe.edu.cn"/>
On the other side, more Chinese wealthy families are more likely to send their kids abroad to receive higher education. Free academic atmosphere, high-quality teaching quality and new way to cultivate talents---all these advantages contribute to the flood of Chinese students arriving in United States, United Kingdom, Germany and other developed countries. Chinese students have been the largest foreign group in USA since 2010, with 157,588 arriving between 2010 and 2011.<ref name="moe.edu.cn"/> The same situation happened in United Kingdom and Germany. Western education will likely remain the leading choice for Chinese students due to its cross-disciplinary fields and development of critical thinking.<ref>"90% Of China’s Super-Rich Want To Send Children Abroad" ''International Business Times'' [http://www.ibtimes.com/90-china%E2%80%99s-super-rich-want-send-children-abroad-434838] April 7, 2012</ref>
China has a strong demand for postsecondary education, to the extent that its university system currently cannot keep pace with demand. Consequently, universities in the United States, Europe and Australia play a significant role by partnering with Chinese universities, aggressively recruiting Chinese students for study in their host countries, increasing the number of students they send to study in China, and adding to their presence on the mainland, either through official foreign campuses or extensions. Australia, Hong Kong, and other Asian countries are already making strides into this market.
Partnering can be economically salubrious, either if the scholars choose to stay in the host country or return to the mainland. Most Chinese students who go abroad are among the best and brightest from their home country. Thus, if they choose to stay, they can benefit the economy of their host country when they gain employment and become members of their new communities. If they leave, they may maintain the contacts and connections they may have established, and also leave a positive impression on their hosts.<ref>Dynes, Robert. [http://www.universityofcalifornia.edu/president/speeches/101705foreignstudents.pdf UC Foreign Graduate Students: Why A World-Class University Needs the World’s Best Minds.] University of California Office of the President. 17 October 2005.</ref>
==Funding== Compared with [[commonwealth countries]]’ tuition, tuition of China’s higher education is relatively inexpensive. Nevertheless, the Chinese per capita income is much lower than western countries, so there are still some students from rural and mountainous areas facing funding problems. Chinese government has taken some measures to ensure the smooth enrollment of this group, like students loans, part-time jobs within campus, etc. It seldom has the news that some college students discontinue studies because of lacking of tuition or living cost.
Considering institution funding, it varies dramatically among different universities. In order to adapt to the fierce global competition in education, [[Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China]] initiated [[Project 211]] in 90s aiming at strengthening about 100 institutions of higher education and key disciplinary areas as a national priority for the 21st century.<ref name="ReferenceB">[http://www.chinaeducenter.com/en/cedu/ceduproject211.php "Project 211 and 985" ''China Education Center Ltd'']</ref> On May 4, 1998, President [[Jiang Zemin]] declared that “China must have a number of first-rate universities of international advanced lever”, so [[Project 985]] was launched.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The total number of [[Project 985]] is 39 and all of them belong to [[211 project]] at the same time.<ref name="ReferenceB"/> The initial aim is to promote China’s educational competitiveness and establishment of a number of leading disciplines in the world.
Meanwhile, it is also the beginning to widen the gap and cause the imbalanced distribution of scientific research funds between 211 project universities and common public universities. Within the project, it is not only a glory but also hints numerous tangible benefits. The majority of public universities’ development lies to all levels of government funds. Entry in this project means you will gain more research funds. According to another data from Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China, from 2009 to 2013, the total government research funding for 39 985-Project institutions is 13.9 billion RMB, with 73 211-Project Institutions approximately 5.1 billion RMB and rest of 670 common undergraduate colleges only 7.9 billion RMB. .<ref name="ReferenceB"/>
The majority of Chinese universities are state-owned universities. The financial support from government level, in most circumstances, decides one university’s development. The imbalanced distribution of scientific research funds will deepen the gap among universities.
<sub>'''''Remark:'''''</sub>{{Reflist|group=remark}}
==See also== *[[Academic ranks in China]] *[[Project 985]] *[[Project 211]] *[[C9 League]] *[[Academic Ranking of World Universities]] compiled by [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]] *[[Ant Tribe|Ant Tribes, college graduates challenges launching their career]] *[[CERNET]] *[[College and university rankings]] *[[Education in China]] *[[History of science and technology in China]] *[[List of universities in China]] *[[THES - QS World University Rankings]] compiled by [[Times Higher Education]]/[[Quacquarelli Symonds]] between 2004 and 2009 *[[Thousand Talents Program (China)|Thousand Talents Program]] *[[Changjiang Scholars Program|Changjiang (Yangtze River) Scholar award]] *[[QS World University Rankings]] published by [[U.S. News & World Report]] since 2010
==Notes and references== {{reflist|2}}
==Further reading== *Agelasto Michael and Bob Adamson (eds). ''Higher Education in Post-Mao China''. Hong Kong University Press, 1998. {{ISBN|962-209-450-3}} *Hayhoe, Ruth . ''China's Universities and the Open Door''. Armonk, N.Y.: M.E. Sharpe, 1989. xii, 249 p.p. {{ISBN|087332501X}}. On the early stages of reform in higher education. *Hayhoe, Ruth. ''China's Universities, 1895-1995 : A Century of Cultural Conflict''. New York: Garland Pub., Garland Reference Library of Social Science, 1996. xxv, 299pp. {{ISBN|0815318596}}. The competing models of education before and after 1949. * Li Mei . "Cross-border flows of students for higher education: Push–pull factors and motivations of mainland Chinese students in Hong Kong and Macau". ''Higher Education'', 2007 * Rui Yang. Third Delight: The internationalization of higher education in China. Routledge, 2002. * Zha Qiang (Ed.) (2013). Education in China. Educational History, Models, and Initiatives. Gt Barrington, MA: Berkshire Publishing *Zhou Ji, Minister of the Ministry of Education. ''Higher Education in China''. Cengage Learning; 1st edition (July 30, 2005) {{ISBN|981-254-364-3}} *[http://www.moe.edu.cn/english/higher_h.htm Higher Education In China] - Ministry of Education *[http://english.china.com/zh_cn/education/educational_system/11020788/20040902/11861359.html Higher education in China] *[http://www.acenet.edu/AM/Template.cfm?Section=Insights&TEMPLATE=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&CONTENTID=11822 Higher Education in China: The Next Super Power is Coming of Age] *[https://ideas.repec.org/p/eab/develo/185.html Higher Education in China - A Growth Paradox?] *[http://www.che.de/downloads/Higher_Education_in_China_AP97.pdf Higher Education in China in light of massification and demographic change] *[http://www.higher-edge.com/docs/APR2003.China.pdf China’s impressive strides in higher education] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/education/7098561.stm China's bid for world domination] *[http://www.voxeu.org/index.php?q=node/1066 China’s higher education transformation and its global implications] *[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=91104628 Higher education in China faces competition] *[http://www.ericdigests.org/2003-2/china.html China's Vocational Universities. ERIC Digest.] by Ding, Anning
==External links== *[http://www.hie.edu.cn/ China Higher Education Network] - Higher education reform and development *[http://en.moe.gov.cn/ Ministry of Education The People's Republic of China] *[http://www.chsi.com.cn/about_en/02.shtml China Higher-education Student Information and Career Center] (CHESICC) *[http://www.chinaeducationblog.com/ The China Education Blog] - Topical issues blog for China's education sector *[http://www.che.de/downloads/Higher_Education_in_China_AP97.pdf] - Higher Education in China in the light of massification and demographic change *[http://www.agelastos.com/turmoil/ University in Turmoil: The Political Economy of Shenzhen University] by Michael Agelasto (1998) {{ISBN|962-86141-1-8}} *[http://www.agelastos.com/disengagement/ Educational Disengagement: Undermining Academic Quality at a Chinese University] by Michael Agelasto (1998) {{ISBN|962-86141-2-6}}

revision.comment: Added AZLoop to the list of competition teams
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2016}} [[File:Hyperloop pod competition tube.jpg|thumb|Hyperloop pod competition]] The '''Hyperloop Pod Competition''' is a competition sponsored by [[SpaceX]] in 2015–2018 where a number of student and non-student teams are participating to design—and for some, build—a [[scale model|subscale]] [[prototype]] transport vehicle to demonstrate technical feasibility of various aspects of<!-- the test track tube is not an exact scale replica of the alpha-level Hyperloop ''en toto''; but it will have a number of characteristics to allow many aspects of that particular Hyperloop technology to be tested, as various teams vary their design approaches. --> the [[Hyperloop]] concept. The competitions have been open to participants globally, although all competitions and judging has occurred in the United States.
For the 2017 competition, a Bloomberg journalist reported that entrants were required to hand over rights for SpaceX to use any of their technology in the future without compensation,<ref name=bloomberg20180918> {{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-18/in-elon-musk-s-hyperloop-contests-students-main-goal-is-scoring-a-job |title=In Elon Musk’s Hyperloop Contests, Students’ Main Goal Is Scoring a Job |last=McBride |first=Sarah |work=Bloomberg |date=18 September 2017 |access-date=22 December 2017 |quote=''Winners of last month’s contest received no prizes, and all entrants were required to hand over rights for SpaceX to use any of their technology in the future without compensation.''}}</ref> but no requirement to this effect is found in the competition rules.<ref name=sxcomp2rules20160831/><ref name=sxcomp3rules20170905/>
A fourth year of competition has been announced for summer 2019.<ref name=sx20180215> {{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/hyperloop |title=The Official SpaceX Hyperloop Pod Competition |work=SpaceX Hyperloop website |date=15 February 2015 |accessdate=22 February 2018 |quote=The 2018 Hyperloop Pod Competition will take place on July 22, 2018. }}</ref>
== Overview == There were three judging phases in the 2015–2017 competition: a design competition that was held in January 2016, and two on-track competitions—27–29 January 2017,<ref name=bi20170127/><ref name=fitTest20161104/> and, Competition Weekend II, 25–27 August 2017.<ref name=geekwire20170827/> The on-track portion of the competition is run on the ''SpaceX Hyperloop test track''—or ''Hypertube''—a mile-long, partial-[[vacuum]], {{convert|72.0|in|m|sp=us|order=flip|adj=on}}-diameter steel tube purpose-built in [[Hawthorne, California]] for the competition.<ref name="uw20160108" />
30 of the 115 teams that submitted designs in January 2016 were selected to build hardware to compete on a sponsored Hyperloop test track in January 2017.<ref name="verge20160130" /><ref name="inverse20160203" /> There were more than 1,000 applicants at earlier stages of the competition.<ref name="fortune20160131" /> The first competition completed in January 2017<!-- with how many teams competing? -->. Delft Hyperloop from the [[Technical University of Delft]] won the first overall prize. [[WARR Hyperloop]], from the [[Technical University of Munich]] won top honors. In April 2017, 24 teams were selected to compete in Competition Weekend II held in August; WARR Hyperloop won top honors with a {{convert|201|mph|km/h|order=flip}} top speed in the mile-long test track.<ref name=geekwire20170827/>
In August 2018, 18 teams competed in the main competition with top speed as the only judged criteria; two additional teams competed in the levitation sub-competition. WARR Hyperloop again won to honors in the main competition, beating its own record with a 467 km/h (290 mph) run; UCSB Hyperloop was the only team to be able to compete in the levitation sub-competition, thus automatically winning. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/7/28/17622770/spacex-hyperloop-pod-race-2018-elon-musk|title=SpaceX’s hyperloop race was all about ‘maximum speed’ (and celebrating Elon Musk)|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-07-30}}</ref>
It was announced during Competition III that Competition IV was confirmed to take place in summer 2019.
== History ==
The outline of the original [[Hyperloop]] concept was made public in August 2013 by the release of a preliminary—or alpha level—design document by [[Elon Musk]], with substantial design assistance from an informal group of engineers at both [[Tesla Motors]] and [[SpaceX]] who worked on the conceptual foundation and modelling of Hyperloop. The preliminary design called for a {{convert|90|-|132|in|m|sp=us|order=flip|sigfig=2|adj=mid|-diameter}} steel tube, operating in partial [[vacuum]] (nearly airless), utilizing pressurized vehicle "pods" to carry passengers or cargo that would ride on an air cushion driven by [[linear induction motor]]s and [[air compressor]]s.<ref name="gm20130822" /> The alpha design included a notional<!-- the word here is "notional", not national; please do not change it to national --> route running from the [[Los Angeles]] region to the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], paralleling the [[Interstate 5 in California|Interstate 5]] corridor for most of its length, so that preliminary economic analysis might be done on the concept.<ref name="alphaSpacex201308" /> Responses to the design paper release included: "a flash of brilliance" and "hypercool"<ref name="sjmn20130813Editorial">{{cite news |last=Mercury News Editorial |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/opinion/ci_23854572/mercury-news-editorial-elon-musks-hyperloop-is-hypercool |title=Mercury News editorial: Elon Musk's Hyperloop is hypercool |work=San Jose Mercury News |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=3 February 2016 }}</ref> to "nothing new here"<ref name="gm20130822">{{cite web |url=http://www.gizmag.com/hyperloop-musk-analysis/28672/ |title=Beyond the hype of Hyperloop: An analysis of Elon Musk's proposed transit system |last=Dodson|first=Brian |work=Gizmag.com |date=22 August 2013 |accessdate=3 February 2016 }}</ref> to "hype", "another science-fiction dream," and "completely impractical."<ref name="sjmn20130813wolverton">{{cite news |last=Wolverton|first=Troy |url=http://www.mercurynews.com/troy-wolverton/ci_23856460/wolverton-elon-musks-hyperloop-hype-ignores-practical-problems |title=Wolverton: Elon Musk's Hyperloop hype ignores practical problems |work=San Jose Mercury News |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=3 February 2016 }}</ref>
Within days of the 2013 announcement, discussions concluded that building a successful Hyperloop subscale demonstration project could reduce the political impediments while improving cost estimates; Musk suggested that he could choose to become personally involved in building a demonstration prototype of the Hyperloop concept, including funding the development effort.<ref name="gm20130813">{{cite news |url=http://www.gizmag.com/musk-developing-hyperloop-demonstrator/28684/ |title=Musk announces plans to build Hyperloop demonstrator |work=Gizmag.com |date=13 August 2013 |accessdate=14 August 2013}}</ref><ref name="economist20130817">{{cite news |url=https://www.economist.com/news/science-and-technology/21583588-elon-musk-electric-car-entrepreneur-and-proponent-private-colonies-mars |title=The Future of Transport: No loopy idea |newspaper=The Economist |volume=Print edition |date=17 August 2013 |accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref>
On 15 June 2015, SpaceX announced that they would sponsor a Hyperloop pod design competition, and would build a {{convert|1|mi|km|adj=mid|-long}} [[scale model|subscale]] test track near SpaceX's headquarters in [[Hawthorne, California|Hawthorne]], California, for the competitive event. The competition could be held as early as June 2016.<ref name="nbc20150615">{{cite news |last1=Boyle|first1=Alan |title=Elon Musk's SpaceX Plans Hyperloop Pod Races at California HQ in 2016 |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/elon-musks-spacex-plans-hyperloop-pod-races-california-hq-2016-n375386 |accessdate=15 June 2015 |agency=NBC |date=15 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="spacex-competition201506">{{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/spacex_hyperloop_pod_competition.pdf |title=Spacex Hyperloop Pod Competition |publisher=SpaceX |date=June 2015 |accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> SpaceX stated in their announcement, "Neither SpaceX nor [[Elon Musk]] is affiliated with any Hyperloop companies. While we are not developing a commercial Hyperloop ourselves, we are interested in helping to accelerate development of a functional Hyperloop [[prototype]]."<ref name="spacex-hyperloop201506">{{cite web |title=Hyperloop |url=http://www.spacex.com/hyperloop |website=SpaceX |publisher=Space Exploration Technologies |accessdate=15 June 2015}}</ref> More than 700 teams had submitted preliminary applications by July.<ref name="binsider20150623">{{cite news |last1=Thompson|first1=Cadie |title=More than 700 people have signed up to help Elon Musk build a Hyperloop prototype |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/elon-musks-hyperloop-pod-competition-has-more-than-700-applicants-2015-6 |date=23 June 2015 |accessdate=28 June 2015 |work=Business Insider}}</ref>
Detailed competition rules were released for the first competition in August 2015, with revisions in October.<ref name="rules20151020">{{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/2015_10_20_hyperloop_competition_rules.pdf |title=Hyperloop Competition Rules, v2.0 |publisher=SpaceX |date=20 October 2015 |accessdate=1 November 2015}}</ref><!-- Rev 2.0 rules released in November; some editor replaced the Rev 1.0 release citation in the [[Hyperloop]] article a long time ago. --> Formal ''Intent to Compete'' submissions were due 15 September 2015 with SpaceX intending to release the detailed tube and technical specification by October 2015<ref name="tamu201510" /> but became available somewhat later.<ref name="uw20160108">{{cite web|title=SpaceX Hyperloop Test-Track Specification |url=https://badgerloop.com/documents/TubeSpecs.pdf |edition=4.0 |publisher=SpaceX |date=8 January 2016 |accessdate=2 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170215070801/https://www.badgerloop.com/documents/TubeSpecs.pdf |archivedate=15 February 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> A preliminary design briefing was held in November 2015,<ref name="gw20151215" /> and {{asof|2015|10|lc=y}}, ''Final Design Packages'' were due on 13 January 2016. A ''Design Weekend'' was held at [[Texas A&M University]] on 29–30 January 2016 for all invited entrants. The selected pods will compete at the ''SpaceX Hyperloop Test Track'' in January 2017.<ref name="tamu201510">{{cite web|title=SpaceX Design Weekend at Texas A&M University |url=http://engineering.tamu.edu/hyperloop |website=Dwight Look College of Engineering, Texax A&M |publisher=Texas A&M University |accessdate=1 November 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912042548/http://engineering.tamu.edu/hyperloop |archivedate=12 September 2015 }}</ref>
More than 120 student engineering teams were selected from the preliminary design briefing presentations in November to submit final design packages in January 2016. The designs were released to public view prior to the end of January 2016, and selected teams were invited to build hardware and compete in time trials, planned for mid-2016 at the time.<ref name="gw20151215">{{cite news |url=http://www.geekwire.com/2015/124-teams-sign-up-for-spacex-founder-elon-musks-hyperloop-pod-race/ |title=More than 120 teams picked for SpaceX founder Elon Musk's Hyperloop contest |work=Geekwire.com |first=Alan |last=Boyle |date=15 December 2015 |accessdate=16 December 2015}}</ref>
SpaceX announced in January 2016 that they had engaged a [[Los Angeles]]-based, [[Fortune 500|Fortune-500]], [[Engineering Design and Construction|engineering design and construction]] firm [[AECOM]] to build the Hyperloop test track.<ref name="verge20160126">{{cite news |last=Hawkins|first=Andrew J. |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/26/10834742/hyperloop-test-track-aecom-construction-firm-deal |title=Elon Musk's Hyperloop is getting a helping hand from serious construction experts |work=The Verge |date=26 January 2016 |accessdate=1 February 2016 }}</ref>
At a 29–30 January 2016 meeting at Texas A&M University, hosted by the College of Engineering, the designs from the approximately 120 worldwide teams were reviewed and judged. 30<!-- 22 in the verge20160130 source, plus 8 more in the inverse20160203 source a few days later, q.v. --> teams were selected to go forward and build prototype Hyperloop pods for the competition later in the year.<ref name="verge20160130">{{cite news |last=Hawkins|first=Andrew J. |url=https://www.theverge.com/2016/1/30/10877442/elon-musk-spacex-hyperloop-competition-awards |title=MIT wins SpaceX’s Hyperloop competition, and Elon Musk made a cameo |work=The Verge |date=30 January 2016 |accessdate=31 January 2016 }}</ref><ref name="inverse20160203">{{cite news |last1=Klein|first1=JoAnna |title=Eight New Teams Added to Hyperloop Competition This Summer |url=https://www.inverse.com/article/11020-e-new-teams-added-to-hyperloop-competition-this-summer |work=Inverse |date=3 February 2016 |accessdate=15 February 2016}}</ref>
On 30 January 2016, Musk announced that, due to the level of sophistication of the pod designs as well as design issues with economical design approaches to building the test track, "given this level of enthusiasm, there is no question we are going to have another Hyperloop competition."<ref name="musk201601330">{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ab2VVp1GfmA |title=Elon Musk speaks at the Hyperloop Pod Award Ceremony |people=Elon Musk |time=13:25–14:20 }}</ref> Further information came in August 2016: the team sign-up deadline would be 30 September 2016 to compete in the second pod competition sometime in 2017.<ref>{{cite press release |url=https://twitter.com/Hyperloop/status/771096110807080960 |title=Sign up for our second student Hyperloop competition by Sept 30 to race your pods in 2017 |publisher=SpaceX |via=Twitter |date=31 August 2016 |access-date=1 September 2016}}</ref>
In the event, the mid-2016 competition schedule was delayed to January 2017. [[TechCrunch]] published a photograph of the pod competition test track still under construction in September 2016.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/09/02/heres-a-first-look-at-the-spacex-hyperloop-test-track/ |title=Here’s a first look at the SpaceX Hyperloop test track |first=Darrell |last=Etherington |work=[[TechCrunch]] |date=2 September 2016 |accessdate=15 September 2016}}</ref> Competition teams visited the track for fit checks and vacuum/track tests during the first week of November, and a video was released.<ref name=fitTest20161104>{{cite press release |url=https://twitter.com/Hyperloop/status/794591020843339778 |title=This week student Hyperloop teams visited @SpaceX for vacuum/track tests. See you at Competition Weekend, Jan 27-29! |publisher=SpaceX |via=Twitter |date=4 November 2016 |access-date=9 January 2017}}</ref>
The on-track portion of the competition finally got underway on 27 January 2017.<ref name=bi20170127/><!-- with how many teams competing? -->. [[WARR Hyperloop]], from the [[Technical University of Munich]] won top honors.
In April 2017, 24 teams were selected to compete in ''Competition Weekend II.'' Held in August 2017, WARR Hyperloop won top honors once again, this time with a {{convert|201|mph|km/h|order=flip}} top speed in the mile-long test track.<ref name=geekwire20170827/>
In September 2017, SpaceX announced that they would sponsor another competition in the third quarter of 2018.<ref name=sxhyperloop20170910> {{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/hyperloop |title=SpaceX Hyperloop website |date=10 September 2017 |publisher=SpaceX |access-date=11 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910053512/http://www.spacex.com/hyperloop |archivedate=10 September 2017}}</ref> As with the ''Competition Weekend II'' in 2017, only student teams may enter the competition, and the "competition will be judged solely on one criteria: maximum speed with successful deceleration (i.e. without crashing)."<ref name=sxhloop2018rules-20170905/> Unlike the two test track competitions in 2017 however, all pods must be self-propelled. SpaceX will not provide an external pusher-vehicle as they did provide to facilitate student team pod testing in both the January and August 2017 competitions. Ultra-small pods will not be allowed this time, with minimum pod length set at {{convert|5|ft|m|order=flip}}. There will be an additional sub-competition with up to three qualifying teams allowed to take part in a ''Levitation Sub-Competition'' that will require non-wheeled pod [[levitation]] and will be tested on an external (non-vacuum) test track. The pods will need to translate at least {{convert|75|feet}} down the track, stop, reverse, and translate back to the original position, all while levitating the entire duration. Fastest full cycle wins the levitation sub-competition.<ref name=sxhloop2018rules-20170905> {{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/2018_hyperloop_competition_rules.pdf |title=2018 SpaceX Hyperloop Pod Competition Rules and Requirements : Revision 1.0 |date=5 September 2017 |publisher=SpaceX |access-date=11 September 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170910053526/http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/2018_hyperloop_competition_rules.pdf |archivedate=10 September 2017}}</ref> The 2018 competition will take place 22 July 2018.<ref name="sx20180623">{{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/hyperloop |title=SpaceX Hyperloop |publisher=SpaceX |accessdate=2018-06-23 |quote=The 2018 Hyperloop Pod Competition will take place on July 22, 2018. ... Based on these successes, SpaceX has moved forward with the third installment: the 2018 Hyperloop Pod Competition. The competition will focus on a single criterion—maximum speed. Additionally, all Pods must be self-propelled. }}</ref>
{{asof|2018}}, Steve Davis—who joined SpaceX as employee no. 9 in 2003,<ref name=musk20180517/>{{rp|43:40}} and is current project leader for [[The Boring Company]]—has been the operations manager for the Hyperloop Pod Competition since inception.<ref name=musk20180517> {{cite AV media | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AwX9G38vdCE |people=Elon Musk, Steve Davis |title=The Boring Company Information Session |medium=video |location=Leo Baeck Temple, Los Angeles, California |publisher=The Boring Company |via=YouTube |accessdate=20 May 2018 }}</ref>{{rp|26:50}}
== Technical overview ==
Each competition has taken place on a {{convert|1|km|mi|adj=mid|-long}}, {{convert|6|ft|m|sp=us|sigfig=2|order=flip|adj=mid|-diameter}} test track built in southern California.<ref name="nbc20150615" /><ref name="verge20160126" /> Test pods may not carry any human or animal, and are to be used solely to develop new technologies and subsystems for effecting higher-velocity tube transport systems.<ref name="wsj20151130">{{cite news |last=Chee|first=Alexander |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-race-to-create-elon-musks-hyperloop-heats-up-1448899356 |title=The Race to Create Elon Musk’s Hyperloop Heats Up |work=[[Wall Street Journal]] |date=30 November 2015 |accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref> The track will facilitate pod test runs where each pod is [[accelerate]]d, achieves a top measured speed that is reported in real-time, and then [[Acceleration|decelerate]]s by [[braking]], ostensibly before the end of the test track. There will be a [[Runaway truck ramp|crash pit]] after the end of the track to absorb the [[kinetic energy|energy]] of any test pods that fail to come to a stop in the test track tube.<ref name="fortune20160131">{{cite news |last=Morris|first=David Z. |url=http://fortune.com/2016/01/31/mit-wins-hyperloop-competition-and-elon-musk-drops-in/ |title=MIT Wins Hyperloop Competition, And Elon Musk Drops In |work=Fortune |date=31 January 2016 |accessdate=1 February 2016 }}</ref><ref name="musk201601330" />
=== Test track ===
The '''SpaceX Hyperloop test track'''<!-- Bolded per [[WP:MOS]]/[[WP:MOSBOLD]] since this term is redirected to here. --> — or ''Hypertube''<ref name="uw20160108" /> — was designed in 2015 and was constructed in 2016, reaching its full length of one mile by October 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://electrek.co/2016/10/06/spacex-hyperloop-test-track-is-up-hawthorne/ |title=SpaceX’s 1-mile Hyperloop test track is now up along its HQ and Tesla’s Design Studio |first=Fred |last=Lambert |work=Electrek |date=6 October 2016 |accessdate=15 October 2016}}</ref> The test track itself is also a prototype, where SpaceX anticipates learning from the design, build process and evaluates how to apply automated construction techniques to future Hyperloop tracks.<ref name="musk201601330" />
[[File:HPC Hypertube Rev4- 20160108-withEnLabels.png|thumb|Cross section of the ''Hypertube'' test track used in the Hyperloop pod competitions.]]
The design of the pod test track varies significantly from the Hyperloop tube design shown in the initial alpha-level Hyperloop design concept document released in 2013.<ref name="alphaSpacex201308">{{cite web |url=http://www.spacex.com/sites/spacex/files/hyperloop_alpha-20130812.pdf |title=Hyperloop Alpha |first=Elon|last=Musk |work=SpaceX |date=12 August 2013 |accessdate=2 February 2016 }}</ref> The Hypertube test track is designed to enable competitors who implement a wide array of designs and build pods that will test a variety of [[subsystem|subsystem technologies]] that are important to new vehicle transport systems. This will include [[Hyperloop]]-specific pods—with air-bearing suspension and low-pressure compressor designs—as well as wheeled vehicle and magnetic levitation rail designs that will support a wide array of vehicle technologies to be tested. Some pods are expected to test only particular subsystems rather than a full Hyperloop-capable pod vehicle design; as well, many pods will have no on-pod compressor to prevent the high-speed [[Kantrowitz limit|choked-flow]] problem, very unlike the Hyperloop alpha design.<ref name="uw20160108" />
Multiple systems will be allowed for [[propulsion]] and for [[levitation]]/[[Suspension (vehicle)|suspension]] of various team pods. Three explicit suspension types are called out: [[wheel]]s, [[air bearing]]s, and [[magnetic levitation]]. [[Vehicle propulsion|Pod propulsion]] may be ''On-pod''—as envisioned in the alpha Hyperloop design—or for the Hypertube test track, may use a SpaceX-provided ''Pusher'' to accelerate pods up to speed in the first 15 percent of track length, or even be unique (team-specific) ''Off-pod'' propulsion systems that would need to be integrated into the Hypertube for that Pod's specific test run.<ref name="uw20160108" />
==== Specifications ====
The test track specifications {{asof|2016|01|lc=y}} include:<ref name="uw20160108" /> * Outer diameter: {{convert|72.0|in|m|sp=us|order=flip}}<ref name="uw20160108" /> (vs. approximately {{convert|90|-|132|in|m|sp=us|order=flip|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} for the tube in the initial alpha Hyperloop design document<!-- 7ft4in to 10ft10in inner diameters plus 2 x 0.8in to 1.0in wall thickness envisioned -->)<ref name="alphaSpacex201308" /> * Inner diameter: {{convert|70.6|in|m|sp=us|order=flip}} * Wall thickness: {{convert|0.70|in|mm|sp=us|order=flip}}<ref name="uw20160108" /> (vs. {{convert|0.80|-|1.0|in|mm|sp=us|order=flip|sigfig=2|abbr=on}} for the tube in the initial alpha Hyperloop design)<ref name="alphaSpacex201308" /> * Length: {{convert|1|mi|km|sp=us|order=flip}} (approximate) * Materials ** Tube: [[ASTM]] [[1018 steel|A1018 Grade 36 carbon steel]] ** Rail: [[6061 aluminium alloy|Aluminum 6061-T6]] ** Subtrack: AA1370-50<ref>[http://www.matweb.com/search/datasheettext.aspx?matid=8811 1370 Aluminum], MatWeb.</ref> [[Aluminum alloy]] for electrical applications ** {{convert|48.0|in|m|sp=us|order=flip|sigfig=2|abbr=on|adj=mid|-wide}} [[Concrete]] base inside the tube to support wheeled-vehicle pods * Subtrack thickness: {{convert|1.0|in|mm|sp=us|order=flip}} for first and last {{convert|200|ft|m|sp=us|order=flip}}; {{convert|0.5|in|mm|sp=us|order=flip}} for remainder of tube * Internal pressure: {{convert|0.02|-|14.7|psi|sigfig=2|lk=on|order=flip}} (competitors may select tube operating pressure "in order to support various types of [[propulsion system]]s, [[Air compressor|compressor]]s (if applicable), and [[outer mold line]]s" * [[Vacuum pump|Pumpdown]] time is expected to be as long as 30 minutes to reach the minimum pressure rating. * Thermal control system: none provided in the Hypertube. Tube temperature is expected to vary based on time of day and weather, and competitors will need to design their pods accordingly, mitigating [[Thermal management (electronics)|thermal hotspots]] during pumpdown and test runs. * Braking system: the only Hypertube-provided braking is the emergency foam pit at the end of the mile-long tube. Pods are expected to provide their own pod-specific [[braking system]], one that will [[Reaction (physics)|react]] force to the Hypertube by one of four methods: either against the steel tube, or concrete base, or aluminum subtrack, or central rail. Tube requirements limit [[friction]] braking against the subtrack or rail to specified limits. * Power: none provided on the test track during testing; 240[[AC voltage|V<sub>AC</sub>]]/50[[Ampere|A]] and 120V<sub>AC</sub>/15A power provided in the pod waiting area up through the pre-launch phase within the tube * Communications: SpaceX will provide a standard Network Access Panel (NAP) device (approximately {{convert|10|x|8|x|1.5|in|mm|sp=us|order=flip|sigfig=2|abbr=on}}) for mounting on each pod which will communicate to the in-tube [[802.11g|network]] via two, redundant, 1–25 GHz, [[blade antenna|wave blade antennas]]. The NAP will also record [[temperature]], [[acceleration]], [[vibration]] and [[Shock (mechanics)|shock]] of each pod in real time during each test run. * Navigation aids: The tube will include a series of circumferential [[Retroreflective sheeting|reflective stripes]] applied to the inner circumference of the tube, located on the top of the tube, to be used for [[Optical sensing|optical pod navigation]], and in particular, awareness of the last {{convert|1000|ft|m|sp=us|order=flip}} of the tube so pod braking may be safely effected.
=== Vehicle pods ===
Three variations of exterior design are currently being explored for vehicle pods. One pod design uses [[air bearings]]; this design relies on a system to create a bed of air for the pod to glide upon and is the basis of Elon Musk’s original Hyperloop idea.<ref name="alphaSpacex201308" /> Another pod design uses [[magnetic levitation]]; this design was used by the winner of the “Best Overall Design Award” [[Michigan Institute of Aviation and Technology|MIT]].<ref name=":0" /> The third design uses high speed wheels for speeds under 100 mph and air bearings for higher speeds.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> This design was used by [[University of Colorado, Denver|University of Colorado, Denver's]] Hyperlynx team.
The inside design of the pods vary by team. Some of the teams are solely building pods designed for cargo transport. Other teams designed pods to transport passengers, while other designs would allow adjustments to be made to the pod to allow both, while MIT's team's initial design did not have room for a passenger or cargo and solely relied on the engineering of the pod.<ref>{{Cite news | url = http://news.nationalgeographic.com/energy/2016/02/160223-Elon-Musk-Hyperloop-for-Sonic-Tubular-Travel-Gets-Real/ | title = Elon Musk’s Hyperloop Idea for Sonic Tubular Travel Gets Real | first = Wendy | last = Koch | website = National Geographic | date = 23 February 2016 | access-date = 26 February 2016 }}</ref> The University of Colorado, Denver's team incorporated a removable capsule that allows it to be exchanged for a cargo hold or passenger space.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> [[New York University|New York University's]] team has created a vehicle that only allows cargo transportation.<ref name="nyuse20160210" />
== Competition I (January 2016 and January 2017) ==
