{{Redirect|Virginia Commonwealth|the Commonwealth of Virginia|Virginia}} {{Redirect|VCU|other uses|VCU (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox university | name = Virginia Commonwealth University | native_name = | image_name = VCU_Seal_sans_logotype.svg | image_size = 150px | latin_name = | motto = Make it real | established = 1968 | type = [[Public university|Public]] | endowment = US$ 1.843 billion{{cite web|title=U.S. and Canadian Institutions Listed by Fiscal Year 2017 Endowment Market Value and Change in Endowment Market Value from FY 2016 to FY 2017|url= https://www.nacubo.org/-/media/Nacubo/Documents/EndowmentFiles/2017-Endowment-Market-Values.ashx?la=en&hash=E71088CDC05C76FCA30072DA109F91BBC10B0290 |work=2017 NACUBO-Commonfund Study of Endowments|publisher=National Association of College and University Business Officers|accessdate=23 August 2015|page=3|format=PDF}} | staff = 11,252http://www.opds.vcu.edu/media/decision-support/factandfigures/facts-cards/FactsCardOPDSWeb14-15.pdf | faculty = 3,279{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/about/facts-and-rankings.html|title=Facts and rankings|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} | president = [[Michael Rao]] | provost = Gail Hackett | rector = William M. Ginther[http://www.president.vcu.edu/board/index.html Board of Visitors] - VCU Office of the President | students = 31,242 | undergrad = 24,051 | postgrad = 7,191 | city = [[Richmond, Virginia|Richmond]] | state = [[Virginia]] | country = U.S. | free = ''[[The Commonwealth Times]]'' | free_label = Newspaper | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]]
{{convert|150|acre|m2}} | colors = [[Black (colour)|Black]] and [[Gold (colour)|Gold]] {{color box|#000000}} {{color box|#FFBA00}} | nickname = [[VCU Rams|Rams]] | athletics = [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] – [[Atlantic 10 Conference|A-10]] | sports = 17 varsity teams | mascot = Rodney the Ram | affiliations = [[Oak Ridge Associated Universities|ORAU]]
[[Association of Public and Land-Grant Universities|APLU]]
[[Southeastern Universities Research Association|SURA]]
[[Coalition of Urban and Metropolitan Universities|CUMU]]
[[Urban 13]]/[[Great Cities' Universities|GCU]] | website = [http://www.vcu.edu/ www.vcu.edu] | coor = {{coord|37.546615|-77.453255|display=inline,title|type:edu}} | footnotes = All enrollment figures are as of Fall 2014 | logo = [[File:VCU typeface.svg|125px]] }} '''Virginia Commonwealth University''' ('''VCU''') is a [[public education|public]] [[research university]] located in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. MCV was founded in 1838 as the medical department of [[Hampden–Sydney College]], becoming the [[Medical College of Virginia]] in 1854. In 1968, the [[Virginia General Assembly]] merged MCV with the [[Richmond Professional Institute]], founded in 1917, to create Virginia Commonwealth University.{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/about/history.php|title=Leadership|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} In 2018, more than 31,000 students pursue 217 degree and certificate programs through VCU's 11 schools and three colleges. The VCU Health System supports the university's health care education, research and patient care mission. With a record $270.3 million in sponsored research funding in the fiscal year 2014–15, VCU is designated as "R1: Doctoral University - Highest Research Activity" by the [[Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education]].{{cite web | url=http://www.opds.vcu.edu/media/decision-support/factandfigures/facts-cards/FactsCard2015-16OPDS.pdf | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207055326/http://www.opds.vcu.edu/media/decision-support/factandfigures/facts-cards/FactsCard2015-16OPDS.pdf | dead-url=yes | archive-date=2016-02-07 | title=2015–2016 VCU Fact Card }}{{cite web|url=http://carnegieclassifications.iu.edu/lookup/view_institution.php?unit_id=234030|title=Carnegie Foundation Classifications|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} A broad array of university-approved centers and institutes of excellence, involving faculty from multiple disciplines in public policy, biotechnology and health care discoveries, supports the university's research mission. Twenty-eight graduate and first-professional programs are ranked by ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' as among the best in the country.{{cite web|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools|title=Best Graduate Schools|work=US News & World Report|accessdate=29 May 2015}} VCU's athletic teams compete in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] and are collectively known as the [[VCU Rams]]. They are members of the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]]. The VCU campus includes historic buildings such as the [[Ginter House]], now used by the school's [[provost (education)|provost]]. ==History== {{main|History of Virginia Commonwealth University}} {{further|List of presidents of Virginia Commonwealth University}} ===Beginnings=== [[File:Egyptian Building.JPG|thumb|350px|left|[[Egyptian Building]] of the Medical College of Virginia (1845), Richmond, Virginia]] Although officially created with the merger of the [[Richmond Professional Institute]] (RPI) and [[Medical College of Virginia]] (MCV) in 1968, VCU's history began in 1838 when the Medical Department of Hampden-Sydney College opened in Richmond. In 1844, it moved into its first permanent home, the [[Egyptian Building]]. In 1854, the Medical Department of Hampden–Sydney College received an independent charter from the [[Virginia General Assembly]] and became the ''[[Medical College of Virginia]]'' (MCV). A few years later in 1860, MCV conveyed all its property to the Commonwealth of Virginia and becomes a state institution in exchange for $30,000. In 1893, the College of Physicians and Surgeons, later University College of Medicine, was established by [[Hunter Holmes McGuire]] just three blocks away from MCV. In 1912, McGuire Hall opened as the new home of the University College of Medicine. The following year, MCV and UCM merged through the efforts of George Ben Johnston and Stuart McGuire. MCV acquired the Memorial Hospital as a result of the merger. Richmond Professional Institute traces its roots back to 1917, when it began as the Richmond School of Social Work and Public Health. In 1925, it became the Richmond division of [[The College of William & Mary]]. In 1939, this division became the [[Richmond Professional Institute]] of The College of William & Mary" (RPI). In 1947, the MCV Foundation was incorporated, and in 1962 RPI separated from William & Mary to become an independent state institution. Then in 1968, state legislation (Wayne Commission Report) merged MCV and RPI to become Virginia Commonwealth University. VCU claims 1838 as its founding date on its official seal and on promotional materials.{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/about/history.php |title=Leadership – Virginia Commonwealth University |publisher=Vcu.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16}} ===Recent history=== In 2013, VCU was awarded a $62 million federal grant to oversee a national research consortium of universities, hospitals and clinics to study what happens to service members and veterans who suffer mild traumatic brain injuries or concussions.{{cite web|author=Monday, August 12, 2013 12:00 am |url=http://www.timesdispatch.com/news/latest-news/vcu-gets-million-to-study-military-brain-injuries/article_6f21ae78-02a2-11e3-bcae-0019bb30f31a.html |title=VCU to lead major study of concussions - Richmond Times-Dispatch: Latest News |publisher=Timesdispatch.com |date=2013-08-12 |accessdate=2014-08-16}}{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2013/08/10/fact-sheet-obama-administration-s-work-honor-our-military-families-and-v |title=Fact Sheet: The Obama Administration's Work to Honor Our Military Families and Veterans | The White House |publisher=Whitehouse.gov |date=2013-08-10 |accessdate=2014-08-16}} In 2010, VCU received a $20 million National Institutes of Health grant to join a nationwide consortium of research institutions working to turn laboratory discoveries into treatments for patients.Buckley, Anne. (2011-01-27) [http://www.news.vcu.edu/news/Carnegie_Foundation_Upgrades_VCU_to_Research_University_Very VCU News]. News.vcu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. The Clinical and Translational Science Award made VCU the only academic health center in Virginia to join the prestigious CTSA network. In 2011, The Carnegie Foundation elevated Virginia Commonwealth University to "Very High Research Activity," with over 255 million in sponsored research. In 2009, [[Michael Rao]] was appointed the fifth president of VCU and continues in his tenure to focus on VCU's growth as a premier public research university. In 2018, a series of [[VCUarts adjunct workers' protests|protests by adjunct faculty]] were held at VCU, over low pay and no benefits.{{cite web|last1=Mattingly|first1=Justin|title=VCU adjunct arts professors, community protest low wages|url=http://www.richmond.com/news/vcu-adjunct-arts-professors-community-protest-low-wages/article_1e7c52ad-bf82-5635-9f41-297596b5739e.html|website=[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|publisher=[[Berkshire Hathaway]]|accessdate=May 7, 2018|date=December 8, 2017}}{{cite web|last1=Pauly|first1=Megan|title=VCU Adjunct Arts Professors Rally For Higher Pay|url=http://ideastations.org/radio/news/vcu-adjunct-arts-professors-rally-higher-pay|website=[[WCVE-FM]]|publisher=[[Commonwealth Public Broadcasting Corporation]]|accessdate=May 10, 2018|date=December 8, 2017}} Ahead of the 2018-19 budget, $4.2 million was allocated to increase adjunct faculty funding from $800 to $1,000 per credit hour, about $1,000 less than what the coalition was demanding.{{cite web|last1=Mattingly|first1=Justin|title=VCU raises tuition 6.4 percent for 2018-19|url=http://www.richmond.com/news/local/education/vcu-raises-tuition-percent-for/article_82ccbd62-c828-5fa5-99f8-d52ae50ed6c3.html|website=[[The Richmond Times-Dispatch]]|accessdate=May 13, 2018|date=May 11, 2018}} === Expansion at VCU === Warren W. Brandt served as the first president of VCU. During his tenure, 32 degree programs were added, and the School of Allied Health Professions and the School of Community Services were established. In addition, more than $20 million of new construction was completed or initiated on both campuses, including the [[James Branch Cabell]] Library, Rhoads Hall, the School of Business building, the Larrick Student Center and a large addition to Sanger Hall. In the 1980s, and under the leadership of VCU President Edmund Ackell, a major overhaul of the university's governance system and administrative structure was initiated. Dr. Ackell lead the administration in instituting a new system for both short-range and long-range university planning; establishing faculty convocation and a new set of faculty tenure and promotion guidelines; and establishing greater access to the community by supporting the use of the university's research and educational resources to meet social needs. [[Eugene Trani]] became the president of VCU in 1990. During his tenure VCU became one of the largest universities in Virginia, growing from an enrollment of 21,764 in 1990, to 32,284 at the time of his retirement. VCU was the state's first university to enroll over 30,000 students.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.vcu.edu/news/VCU_states_largest_fouryear_public_institution|title=VCU News|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} Under Dr. Trani's leadership VCU and the VCU Health System undertook more than $2.2 billion in capital construction and renovation projects.{{cite web|url=http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2009/apr/19/tran19_20090418-221302-ar-46006/|title=VCU's Trani helped transform school, city and lives - Articles/Archives - Richmond Times-Dispatch|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130204114941/http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2009/apr/19/tran19_20090418-221302-ar-46006/|archivedate=2013-02-04|df=}} In February 2006, VCU established VCU 2020 Vision for Excellence, a strategic plan to continue to fulfill VCU's mission as a leading urban research institution for the 21st century and develop more than $1 billion in new academic, medical, recreation, student housing, and parking facilities on VCU's Monroe Park and MCV Campuses.{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/cie/strategic/strategicplan.html|title=Planning and Decision Support|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.vcu.edu/news.aspx?v=detail&nid=102|title=VCU master site plan sets vision for major research institution and collegiate community}}{{cite web|url=http://www.fmd.vcu.edu/masterplan.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060901072434/http://www.fmd.vcu.edu/masterplan.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2006-09-01|title=VCU - Facilities Management|publisher=}} ====VCU Quest for Distinction==== Quest for Distinction, the university's strategic plan, was launched by Dr. Rao in 2011. It sets priorities of academic excellence, research that enhances the quality of life, human health and well-being, and ongoing contribution to the economic vitality and cultural richness of the community.{{cite web|url=http://www.future.vcu.edu/|title=Virginia Commonwealth University Quest for Distinction|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024081457/http://www.future.vcu.edu/|archivedate=24 October 2012|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.future.vcu.edu/summary/index.html|title=Virginia Commonwealth University Quest for Distinction|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425083634/http://www.future.vcu.edu/summary/index.html|archive-date=25 April 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Specific initiatives include the continued recruitment of high-quality faculty and resource development aimed at enhancing the overall student experience. The latest master plan lays out over 3 billion dollars in new construction and renovations that would provide housing for an additional 1,300 students, increase parking for several thousand cars and build 3 million additional square feet of academic and research space.[http://www.timesdispatch.com/news/billion-vcu-aspirational-master-plan-approved/article_6933702a-ba66-5483-bd54-c781b4378f49.html VCU 'aspirational' plan calls for more academic space, housing - Richmond Times-Dispatch: News, Crime And Politics For The Richmond Metro Area]. Timesdispatch.com (2013-02-15). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. ==Campuses== Virginia Commonwealth University has two main campuses in [[Richmond, Va.]]: the Monroe Park Campus, located west of downtown Richmond, and the MCV Campus in the urban center. Additionally, VCU has a branch campus in [[Education City]], [[Doha]], [[Qatar]], along with numerous regional facilities. ===Monroe Park Campus=== [[File:VCU Snead Hall by Jeff Auth.JPG|thumb|right|350px|Snead Hall, Monroe Park campus]] Named after the city park, the 90.6-acre Monroe Park Campus took its name in June 2004, replacing the former name, the Academic Campus of VCU. The Monroe Park Campus houses most of VCU's general education facilities, and is situated on the eastern end of the [[Fan district]], a historic, late 19th-century neighborhood adjacent to downtown Richmond. Prior to the merger of the [[Richmond Professional Institute]] and the Medical College of Virginia, the campus was the home to the entire Richmond Professional Institute. Today, the campus has a mixture of modern and vintage buildings, with over 40 structures built before 1900. ===MCV Campus=== [[File:VCU Medical Science Building 2 by Jeff Auth.jpg|thumb|300px|upright|VCU Molecular Medicine Research Building (MMRB), MCV campus]] The 52.3-acre MCV Campus is home to the [[VCU Medical Center]]. This includes the Schools of Medicine, Dentistry, Pharmacy, Allied Health, Nursing, and the medical center, which is overseen by the VCU Health System Authority. The campus is also home to the [[VCU Massey Cancer Center|Massey Cancer Center]] (an [[NCI-designated Cancer Center]]) and the Children's Hospital of Richmond at VCU. The MCV Campus is an integral part of Richmond in the old [[Court End]] district. The neighborhood is located adjacent to the city's business and financial district near the [[Virginia State Capitol|state capitol]]. VCU's Health Sciences schools comprise the [[VCU School of Allied Health Professions|School of Allied Health Professions]], the [[Virginia Commonwealth University School of Dentistry|School of Dentistry]], the [[VCU School of Medicine|School of Medicine]], the [[VCU School of Nursing|School of Nursing]], and the School of Pharmacy. ===VCUarts Qatar=== {{Main|Virginia Commonwealth University - Qatar}} VCUarts Qatar is VCU School of the Arts' branch campus located in [[State of Qatar]].{{cite web|url = http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/deans-letter|title = INQUIRIES|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = }} VCUarts Qatar is the Qatar campus of the Virginia Commonwealth University School of the Arts in Richmond, Virginia. It was established in 1998 through a partnership with Qatar Foundation and was the first university to open its doors in Education City.[http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/at-a-glance At a glance : VCUQatar]. Qatar.vcu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. The contract was renewed in July 2012 and goes through July 2022. VCUarts Qatar provides students the opportunity to earn a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in Graphic Design, Interior Design, Fashion Design, Art History, or Painting and Printmaking and a Master of Fine Arts degree in Design Studies.{{cite web|url=http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/about-vcuqatar/overview-facts/inside-vcuqatar/ |title=VCUQatar|author=VCUQatar|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} As part of the contract, VCU is not allowed to open any other degree-granting arts or design programs in other Middle Eastern countries.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2015/12/06/the-education-city-contracts-a-case-study-from-vcu-in-qatar/|title=The Education City contracts: A case study from VCU in Qatar|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-06-10}} In addition to smart classrooms, the VCUarts Qatar campus is primarily composed of studios and workspaces for its art programs, an international gallery and a library. The campus also contains things needed for daily student life such as a café, prayer rooms, a student lounge, and a central hall which can be used for a variety of events.{{cite web|url=http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/about-vcuqatar/overview-facts/the-campus/|title=VCUQatar|author=VCUQatar|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} Through its programs, VCUarts Qatar's mission is to "develop the individual capacity to lead innovations in the creative and cultural professions in Qatar and the region."{{cite web|url=http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/about-vcuqatar/welcome-to-vcuqatar/vision-mission/|title=VCUQatar|author=VCUQatar|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} VCUarts Qatar is accredited by National Association of Schools of Art & Design, The Southern Association of Colleges and Schools and Council for Interior Design Accreditation. In 2010, VCUarts Qatar more than doubled its facilities through a major expansion project. The expansion has allowed for the integration of the university's undergraduate and graduate programs under one roof, the connection of the research and entrepreneurship offices with curricular programs, and the expansion of technical spaces to support all forms of visualization and research with a media lab, digital fabrication lab, printmaking studios, photography studio, an expanded library and the first materials library in the region. The campus is working alongside the [[Supreme Education Council]] and [[Qatar Foundation]] toward reaching the [[Qatar National Vision 2030]].{{cite web|url = http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/deans-letter|title = VCUQ Dean's Letter|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = }} In 2015, VCUarts Qatar has 63 Faculty representing for 15 different nationalities. The number of students is 361 Students representing 41 nationalities which shows its diversity. So far VCUarts Qatar has 620 Alumni representing 33 nationalities.{{cite web|url = http://www.qatar.vcu.edu/at-a-glance|title = VCUQatar at glance|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = }} VCU received about $42 million in 2014 to operate the campus.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2015/12/06/dohas-education-city-by-the-numbers-enrollment-diplomas-faculty-finances/|title=Doha’s Education City by the numbers: Enrollment, diplomas, faculty, finances|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-06-10}} A portion of this is a management fee, which in previous years was $3.4 million, allowing the campus to profit off of the campus. VCU is not the only US campus in Education City, and it, along with the other universities, are the subject of criticism of their implicit acceptance of Qatar's sponsorship of terrorism and egregious human rights violations.{{cite web| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/education/in-qatars-education-city-us-colleges-are-building-an-academic-oasis/2015/12/06/6b538702-8e01-11e5-ae1f-af46b7df8483_story.html|title=In Qatar's Education City, U.S. colleges are building an academic oasis|website=Washington Post|access-date=2016-06-10}}{{cite web|url=http://gulfnewsjournal.com/stories/510718132-are-american-universities-funding-extremists-education|title=Are American universities funding extremists' education?|last=Nakano|first=Hanna|website=gulfnewsjournal.com|access-date=2016-06-10}}{{cite web|url=http://gulfnewsjournal.com/stories/510712102-advocate-questions-motive-behind-qatar-s-financial-ties-to-u-s-colleges|title=Advocate questions motive behind Qatar's financial ties to U.S. colleges|last=Reports|first=Gulf News Journal|website=gulfnewsjournal.com|access-date=2016-06-10}} ===VCU satellite and research locations=== * Virginia Bio-Technology Research Park was incorporated in May 1992 as a joint initiative of Virginia Commonwealth University (VCU), the City of Richmond and the Commonwealth of Virginia. The research park is home to more than 60 life science companies, research institutes and state/federal labs, employing more than 2,200 scientists, engineers and researchers.[http://vabiotech.com/about/about-the-park/ About the Park • Virginia BioTechnology Research Park • The new East Coast center for biosciences] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121218030739/http://vabiotech.com/about/about-the-park/ |date=2012-12-18 }}. Vabiotech.com. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. * Inger and Walter Rice Center for Environmental Life Sciences is located on 494 acres along the [[James River]]. The center has a primary focus of research on the science and policy of large rivers and their fringing riparian and wetland landscapes.[http://www.vcu.edu/rice/about/ VCU Rice Center – About the center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110927234242/http://www.vcu.edu/rice/about/ |date=2011-09-27 }}. Vcu.edu (2013-04-23). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. * VCU Medical Center at Stony Point, in southwestern Richmond[http://www.vcuhealth.org/?id=154&sid=1 Stony Point - Virginia Commonwealth University Health System]. Vcuhealth.org. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. * VCU School of Medicine Inova Campus[http://www.medschool.vcu.edu/inova/ Inova Campus - VCU School of Medicine]. Medschool.vcu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. * VCU School of Pharmacy Inova Campus[https://web.archive.org/web/20100829153505/http://www.pharmacy.vcu.edu/inova/ Inova Campus welcomes you!]. Pharmacy.vcu.edu (2012-10-18). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. * VCU School of Pharmacy University of Virginia Division[http://www.virginia.edu/uvatoday/newsRelease.php?id=16967 VCU School of Pharmacy to Open U.Va. Satellite Campus | UVA Today] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120805183448/http://www.virginia.edu/uvatoday/newsRelease.php?id=16967 |date=2012-08-05 }}. Virginia.edu (2012-01-03). Retrieved on 2013-08-21.{{cite web|title=VCU School of Pharmacy University of Virginia Division|url=http://www.pharmacy.vcu.edu/programs/pharmd/Satellite_campuses/uva/|website=VCU School of Pharmacy|publisher=VCU|accessdate=24 March 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150317004404/http://www.pharmacy.vcu.edu/programs/pharmd/satellite_campuses/uva/|archive-date=17 March 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Academics== ===Schools=== *College of Humanities & Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.has.vcu.edu/|title=HAS|work=HAS|accessdate=29 May 2015}} **Robertson School of Media and Culture {{cite web|url=http://masscomm.vcu.edu/|title=Robertson School|work=Robertson School|accessdate=29 May 2015}} **School of World Studies{{cite web|url=http://www.has.vcu.edu/wld|title=VCU School of World Studies|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[L. Douglas Wilder School of Government and Public Affairs]]{{cite web|url=http://www.has.vcu.edu/gov|title=HAS " The Impact of Recent US Government Actions on the College of Humanities & Sciences|work=HAS|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of Allied Health Professions|School of Allied Health Professions]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sahp.vcu.edu|title=Allied Health Professions|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of the Arts|School of the Arts]]{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/arts/|title=VCUarts Homepage|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of Business|School of Business]]{{cite web|url=http://www.business.vcu.edu|title=VCU School of Business - Home|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[Virginia Commonwealth University School of Dentistry|School of Dentistry]]{{cite web|url=http://www.dentistry.vcu.edu/|title=VCU School of Dentistry|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of Education|School of Education]]{{cite web|url=http://www.soe.vcu.edu/|title=VCU School of Education|work=VCU School of Education|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of Engineering|College of Engineering]]{{cite web|url=http://www.egr.vcu.edu/|title=VCU School of Engineering - Virginia Commonwealth University|work=VCU School of Engineering - Richmond, Virginia|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of Medicine|School of Medicine]]{{cite web|url=http://www.medschool.vcu.edu|title=Virginia Commonwealth University School of Medicine|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[VCU School of Nursing|School of Nursing]]{{cite web|url=http://www.nursing.vcu.edu|title=Virginia Commonwealth University School of Nursing|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *[[School of Pharmacy]]{{cite web|url=http://www.pharmacy.vcu.edu|title=VCU School of Pharmacy|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *School of Social Work{{cite web|url=http://www.socialwork.vcu.edu/|title=Virginia Commonwealth University School of Social Work|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *University College{{cite web|url=http://uc.vcu.edu/|title=University College - Curricular Innovation and Interdisciplinary Studies|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} *VCU Graduate School{{cite web|url=http://www.graduate.vcu.edu/|title=Graduate School |publisher=}} *VCU Honors College{{cite web|url=http://www.honors.vcu.edu/|title=Honors College |publisher=}} *VCU Life Sciences{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/lifesci/|title=Virginia Commonwealth University Life Sciences|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ===Programs=== VCU offers [[Bachelor's degree|Baccalaureate]], [[Master's degree|Master's]] and [[Doctorate|Doctoral]] [[academic degree|degrees]], as well as Professional and Certificate courses.A [http://research.schev.edu/degreeinventory/inventory_1.asp?lbinst='234030' complete degree inventory] is available from the Web site of the [[State Council of Higher Education for Virginia]]. Seventy-nine of VCU's programs are unique to Virginia, such as the Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness major in the L. Douglas Wilder School of Government and Public Affairs, as well as the Real Estate and Urban Land Development degree in VCU's School of Business. The university also offers a wide range of study options with 225 certificate, undergraduate, graduate, professional and doctoral degrees in the arts, sciences and humanities. The university's medical campus provides students with several opportunities for postgraduate study. Under the Guaranteed Admission Program,[http://www.honors.vcu.edu/guaranteed/index.html VCU Honors College – Guaranteed Admission Program] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121013025748/http://www.honors.vcu.edu/guaranteed/index.html |date=2012-10-13 }}. Honors.vcu.edu (2013-05-14). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. select incoming undergraduates who maintain a high academic standard are guaranteed a spot in a number of professional health science programs. ====VCU Living-Learning programs==== VCU's Academic Scholars Program in Real Environments (ASPiRE),[http://aspire.vcu.edu/ ASPiRE]. Aspire.vcu.edu (2013-02-16). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. combines the living-learning experience with community engagement. Launched in fall 2012, VCU ASPiRE links students with their community and with each other through a coordinated educational and service-learning curriculum and living experience.[http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2012/aug/25/tdmet01-new-vcu-dorm-is-home-to-aspire-ar-2152318/ New VCU dorm is home to ASPIRE - Richmond Times-Dispatch: News, Crime And Politics For The Richmond Metro Area] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20130204194108/http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2012/aug/25/tdmet01-new-vcu-dorm-is-home-to-aspire-ar-2152318/ |date=2013-02-04 }}. .timesdispatch.com (2012-08-25). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. The VCU Honors College[http://www.honors.vcu.edu/ Virginia Commonwealth University Honors College]. Honors.vcu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. is available to students meeting specific SAT/ACT and GPA criteria. Through the Honors College eligible students are offered the Guaranteed Admission Program, which offers a variety of options for gaining early admission into the professional health science and graduate programs at VCU. In addition, the Honors College also offers students the ability to enroll in classes open only to honors students, live in honors-only residence halls, apply for scholarships only available to honors students, and participate in The Honors College Mentorship Program and other learning experiences that supplement general classroom study. VCU Globe prepares undergraduates to live and work in a global environment, expanding students' identities as global citizens through course work, co-curricular activities and the residential experience.{{cite web|url=http://www.global.vcu.edu/vcuglobe/|title=Global Education Office - Virginia Commonwealth University|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}} VCU LEAD is focused on developing graduates who can successfully lead professional and civic organizations at a local, national, and global level within their respective fields.{{cite web|url=http://students.vcu.edu/vculead/|title=VCU LEAD|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}} VCU Innovate is to spur a mindset and cross-disciplinary culture that enables students to pursue innovation and entrepreneurship efforts.{{cite web|url=http://www.davincicenter.vcu.edu/programs/vcuinnovatellp/|title=VCU Innovate Living-Learning Program - VCU da Vinci Center|publisher=|accessdate=12 February 2017}} ====Life Sciences==== VCU Life Sciences[http://www.vcu.edu/lifesci/ VCU Life Sciences]. Vcu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. comprises three units: the Center for the Study of Biological Complexity (CSBC), the Center for Environmental Studies (CES), and the Rice Center for Environmental Life Sciences.{{cite web|url=http://lifesciences.vcu.edu|title=Virginia Commonwealth University Life Sciences|website=lifesciences.vcu.edu|access-date=2016-12-06}} VCU Life Sciences offers an undergraduate and graduate programs as well as a PhD program in Integrated Life Sciences (ILS).{{cite web|url=http://lifesciences.vcu.edu/academic-programs/phd-in-integrative-life-sciences/|title=Ph.D. in Integrative Life Sciences – VCU Life Sciences|website=lifesciences.vcu.edu|access-date=2016-12-06}} Note that the Department of Biology{{cite web|url=http://biology.vcu.edu|title=Biology - Virginia Commonwealth University|website=biology.vcu.edu|access-date=2016-12-06}} is a separate unit independent of Life Sciences although there are numerous active interactions between the two. The highly interdisciplinary, systems-based program relies on hundreds of faculty members. With activities at the local, regional and national levels, VCU Life Sciences helps increase public literacy in the life sciences and provides an assessment of American public attitudes toward the field. ====VCU da Vinci Center==== [[File:VCU business engineering by Jeff Auth.JPG|thumb|350px|right|The da Vinci Center "Octagon", Monroe Park campus]] VCU schools of the Arts, Business, and Engineering have collaborated to create the VCU da Vinci Center for Innovation in Product Design and Development. Student teams from these schools take on a product development or design challenge posed by one of the Center's industry partners. Such cross-disciplinary educational opportunities prepare students for management roles in the global, technology-driven workplace of the 21st century.{{cite web|url=http://www.davincicenter.vcu.edu/|title=VCU da Vinci Center - Learn & Do Innovation|work=VCU da Vinci Center|accessdate=29 May 2015}} In addition to the current collaboration, the College of Humanities and Sciences[http://www.has.vcu.edu/ Virginia Commonwealth University College of Humanities and Sciences]. Has.vcu.edu (2013-07-29). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. joined the Center late in the Fall 2012 semester. The VCU da Vinci Center currently offers an Undergraduate Certificate and a master's degree in Product Innovation.[http://www.davincicenter.vcu.edu/ VCU da Vinci Center for Innovation]. Davincicenter.vcu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-21. The Masters of Product Innovation is the first of its kind in the [[United States]].[http://www.davincicenter.vcu.edu/uncategorized/introducing-our-master-of-product-innovation/ Introducing our Master of Product Innovation | VCU da Vinci Center] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130611063809/http://www.davincicenter.vcu.edu/uncategorized/introducing-our-master-of-product-innovation/ |date=2013-06-11 }}. Davincicenter.vcu.edu (2011-03-25). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. The center was recognized by a report presented to [[Barack Obama|President Obama]] as one of the 29 best programs to offer a STEM (science, technology, engineering, and math) degree.[http://www.commonwealthtimes.org/2012/12/05/da-vinci-center-recognized-as-top-innovative-program/ da Vinci Center recognized as top innovative program]. The Commonwealth Times (2012-12-05). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. It was the only program in Virginia to be included on the list. The VCU da Vinci Program also offers VCU Innovate Living Learning Program, which gives students the opportunity to live among their like-minded peers in an innovation-focused dorm building. Students earn a Certificate of Completion. ====VCU's International Partnership Universities Initiative==== VCU's International Partnership Universities Initiative provides faculty and students the opportunity for involvement and collaboration in an international and multicultural arena. Fifteen international Partnership Universities and VCU School in Qatar are strategically located in 11 countries.[http://www.international.vcu.edu/partnerships/universities/index.html VCU International Partnership Universities]. International.vcu.edu (2013-06-28). Retrieved on 2013-08-21. *[[Bauhaus University, Weimar]] (Germany) *[[Beijing Foreign Studies University]] (China) *[[Curtin University|Curtin University of Technology]] (Australia) *[[Fudan University]] (China) *[[Hadassah Medical Center]] (Israel) *[[Harris Manchester College, Oxford|Harris Manchester College]] (United Kingdom) *[[Indian Institutes of Technology|Indian Institute of Technology]] (India) *[[Oxford University]] (United Kingdom) *[[Post Graduate Institute of Medical Education and Research]] (India) *[[Moscow State University]] (Russia) *[[Saint Petersburg State University|St. Petersburg State University]] (Russia) *[[University of Córdoba (Spain)]] *[[University of Guadalajara]] (Mexico) *[[University of KwaZulu-Natal|University of KwaZulu–Natal]] (South Africa) *[[University of Messina]] (Italy) *[[University of São Paulo]] (Brazil) *[[University of the West of England]] (United Kingdom) ===Rankings and recognitions=== {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = 151–200 | ARWU_N = 69–89 | Forbes = 447 | QS_W = 451–500 | THES_W = | USNWR_NU = 156 | USNWR_W = 329 | Wamo_NU = 154{{cite web |title=2014 National Universities Rankings |date=n.d. |accessdate=May 27, 2015 |website=Washington Monthly |url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings-2014/national-universities-rank-all.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140828025627/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings-2014/national-universities-rank-all.php |archivedate=August 28, 2014 |df= }} }} According to the 2016 ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'', VCU is classified as a Tier 1 University with an overall National University rank of No. 156 and holds a rank of No. 84 among all public colleges and universities in the United States.{{cite web|url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/virginia-commonwealth-university-3735 |title=Virginia Commonwealth University | Best College | US News |publisher=Colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16}} The [[Academic Ranking of World Universities]] conducted in 2005 by the Institute of Higher Education at [[Shanghai Jiao Tong University]] ranks VCU in the top 100 universities in North & Latin America and one of the top 200 universities in the world.[http://ed.sjtu.edu.cn/rank/2005/ARWU2005TOP500list.htm Academic Ranking of World Universities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060718003242/http://ed.sjtu.edu.cn/rank/2005/ARWU2005TOP500list.htm |date=2006-07-18 }} Shanghai Jiao Tong University. Retrieved on 2007-05-04 Virginia Commonwealth University School of the Arts (VCUarts) is ranked the No. 1 public university school of arts and design in the country (#4 among public & private institutions) by ''U.S. News & World Report'' in 2015.[Out of Date] VCUarts is the only public university arts and design school in the country to ever be ranked this high in overall ranking. Indeed, the ''[[New York Times]]'' called it "that rare public research institution that has put the arts front and center".{{cite news|last1=Russell|first1=James S.|title=On Elite Campuses, an Arts Race|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/16/arts/design/on-elite-campuses-an-arts-race.html|work=New York Times|date=13 November 2014}} The [[VCU Brandcenter]], the School of Business' graduate program in advertising, has also been ranked first in the nation by ''[[Creativity Magazine]]'' and as one of the top 60 design schools in the world by ''[[BusinessWeek]]''.[http://www.news.vcu.edu/news.aspx?v=detail&nid=2239|VCU Adcenter Named Top Design School by Businessweek] Retrieved on 2007-11-18[Out of Date] [[File:VCU Fine Arts Building by Jeff Auth.JPG|thumb|350px|left|The Fine Arts Building, Monroe Park Campus]] VCU's [https://web.archive.org/web/20100107043101/http://www.had.vcu.edu/programs/msha/index.html Masters of Science in Health Administration] program was ranked second by Modern Healthcare. The University's Health System earned national Magnet nursing designation by the American Nurses Credentialing Center, and has twice been named one of the Solucient Top 100 Hospitals in the United States by Solucient Corporation. In research the school has been ranked as a top American university by Lombardi Program on Measuring University Performance and a top 100 university by the [[National Science Foundation]]. VCU Engineering, started in 1996 has seen tremendous growth and completely new facilities. William F. Goodwin, Chairman of the VCU School of Engineering Foundation Board of Trustees, has set an ambitious objective for the engineering program. He's aiming for "25 in 25" – a top 25 engineering-school rank within 25 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.egr.vcu.edu/enews/may2004/monroe.html|title=VCU Engineering - In the News|publisher=|access-date=2011-02-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091226222746/http://www.egr.vcu.edu/enews/may2004/monroe.html|archive-date=2009-12-26|dead-url=yes|df=}} {{as of|2014}}, U.S News & Report ranks the [[Biomedical Engineering]] program 58th, [[Computer Engineering]] program 84th, [[Electrical/Electronic/Communications Engineering]] 89th in the United States.[http://www.vcu.edu/ranking/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061128032808/http://www.vcu.edu/ranking/|date=November 28, 2006}} The School of Business currently ranks as the No. 51 part-time MBA program and No. 97 best undergraduate business program in the United States according to ''Bloomberg Businessweek'' and ''U.S. News & World Report'', respectively. According to the 2012 ''U.S. News & World Report'' [http://www.socialwork.vcu.edu VCU School of Social Work] is ranked 11{{cite web|url=http://grad-schools.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-graduate-schools/top-health-schools/social-work-rankings.html|title=U.S. News School of Social Work Ranking 2012|publisher=}} and the Public Affairs graduate program is currently ranked 53 in the nation.{{cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-graduate-schools/articles/2012/03/12/methodology-graduate-public-affairs-rankings.html|title=Methodology: Best Public Affairs Schools Rankings|author1=Sam Flanigan |author2=Robert Morse |work=US News & World Report|accessdate=29 May 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.vcu.edu/news/VCU_School_of_Business_PartTime_MBA_is_Nationally_Ranked|title=VCU News|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} The VCU SportsCenter is a graduate program offering a master's degree in Sports Leadership. [[David Maraghy]] co-founded and served as Executive Director of the program until 2002. It is currently directed by Nathan Tomasini. One of the program's elite events is known as Villa 7 which began as a forum where athletic directors could share ideas and meet with the country's elite assistant basketball coaches.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportleadership.vcu.edu/villa7/history.html|title=Villa 7 history – Center for Sport Leadership at VCU|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100124105714/http://www.sportleadership.vcu.edu/villa7/history.html|archivedate=2010-01-24|df=}} VCU is among the top 100 institutions according to the [[National Science Foundation]] rankings.{{cite web|url=http://www.president.vcu.edu/updates/20120402.html|title=Virginia Commonwealth University President's posts – Michael Rao, Ph.D.|work=Virginia Commonwealth University President's posts – Michael Rao, Ph.D.|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ====Faculty==== [[File:VCU commons.JPG|thumb|350px|right|VCU Student Commons, Monroe Park Campus]] In its history, one faculty member and one alumnus have won a [[Nobel Prize]]: '''[[Baruj Benacerraf]]''', an alumnus of the [[Medical College of Virginia]], was awarded the 1980 Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine, and [[John Fenn (chemist)|'''John Fenn''']], a professor in the College of Humanities & Sciences, was awarded the 2002 Nobel Prize in Chemistry. In the medical field, VCU has had four professors elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]' [[Institute of Medicine]], most recently '''Steven Woolf''' in 2001.{{cite web|url=http://www.news.vcu.edu/news.aspx?v=detail&nid=755|title=Virginia Commonwealth University News|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} Historically, notable faculty members include '''[[Charles-Édouard Brown-Séquard]]''', M.D., for whom [[Brown-Séquard syndrome]] is named. '''[[Hunter McGuire]]''', M.D., was the [[Confederate States of America|Confederate]] surgeon for General [[Thomas J. "Stonewall" Jackson]] before he founded the "University College of Medicine", which later merged with [[Medical College of Virginia]] where he became the Chairman of Surgery. The [[Hunter Holmes McGuire Veterans Administration Medical Center]] is named in his honor. '''Jennifer Johnson''''s (Professor of Sociology) work at the Department of Defense in the area of Social Network Analysis won her the 2006 [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Joint Distinguished Civilian Service Award]], which is the highest-ranking civilian service award given by the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Dr. Johnson was also awarded the 2004 Analyst of the Quarter by the Joint Warfare Analysis Center for her work on the Social Network Analysis Methodology Team. Also '''[[Gevork Minaskanian]]''', cofounder of Aderis Pharmaceuticals, developers of [[Rotigotine]], a [[dopamine agonist]] for treatment of [[Parkinson's disease]], teaches at VCU. The theatre department includes two-time [[Tony Award]] nominee, costume designer [[Toni-Leslie James]] , James's work on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] , film, and television is known internationally. Tony Award nominated scenic designer Scott Bradley recently joined the faculty. The department's new chair [[Sharon Ott]] received the 1997 [[Regional Theatre Tony Award]] on behalf of [[Berkeley Repertory Theatre]] . Broadway veterans Keith Byron Kirk, David Emerson Toney, David Leong, Neno Russell, and Bonnie McCoy are also teaching faculty for the department; film actor [[Bostin Christopher]] is also on the faculty. The VCU Counseling Psychology Graduate Program was ranked 3rd in the nation in the Faculty Scholarly Productivity Index in 2007.''The Chronicle of Higher Education''. January 12, 2007 The VCU Public Administration program in the L. Douglas Wilder School for Government and Public Affairs was ranked 9th in the nation by the Faculty Scholarly Productivity Index in 2007.{{cite web|url=http://chronicle.com/stats/productivity/page.php?year=2007&primary=3&bycat=Go&secondary=214|title=The Chronicle: Faculty Scholarly Productivity Index|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ===Libraries=== [[File:VCU James Branch Cabell Library-by Jay Paul.jpg|thumb|350px|right|James Branch Cabell Library, Monroe Park Campus. Photograph by Jay Paul.]] The [http://library.vcu.edu VCU Libraries] is one of the largest research libraries in Virginia. In 2018, VCU Libraries became the 125th member of the august Association of Research Libraries.{{cite web|last1=VCU Libraries News Release|title=VCU elected 125th member of Association of Research Libraries|url=https://www.library.vcu.edu/about/news/2017/vcu-elected-125th-member-of-association-of-research-libraries-.html|accessdate=9 February 2018}} The libraries hold more than 3 million volumes (including more than 665,000 electronic books) and extensive journal and database holdings. Collection strengths include the arts, behavioral sciences, business, chemistry, clinical medicine, education, health and life sciences, public affairs, and social work. The VCU Libraries hosts 2.5 million visitors each year. The [[James Branch Cabell]] Library supports the Monroe Park Campus. Its [http://www.library.vcu.edu/research/special-collections/cabell/ Special Collections and Archives department] houses one of the largest [[artist's book|book art]] collections in the Southeast and the fifth largest [[graphic novel]] and [[comic book]] collection in the United States. It also includes records of local organizations and papers of numerous Virginia writers, artists and social activists from Virginia's under-documented communities, and is the repository of the [[Eisner Award|Will Eisner Comic Industry Awards]]. In early 2016, VCU Libraries acquired a rare copy of [[All-Negro Comics]] No. 1.{{Cite web|url=https://www.news.vcu.edu/article/First_allblack_comic_book_added_to_VCU_Libraries_Comic_Arts_Collection|title=First all-black comic book added to VCU Libraries' Comic Arts Collection|last=McNeill|first=Brian|date=4 February 2016|website=VCU News|access-date=7 April 2017}} The [http://www.library.vcu.edu/about/libraries/tompkins-mccaw/ Tompkins–McCaw Library for the Health Sciences] on the MCV Campus has the largest medical collection in the state, with extensive journal collections dating back to the 19th century. Special collections maintain the papers of health care practitioners and the history of health care in Virginia. Its Medical Artifacts Collection has more than 6,000 instruments and equipment related to the history of health care in Virginia over the last 150 years. In March 2016, a 93,000-square-foot expansion of Cabell Library was dedicated.{{Cite web|url=http://www.styleweekly.com/richmond/architecture-review-vcus-new-cabell-library-is-a-bold-and-welcome-addition-to-richmond/Content?oid=2300553|title=Architecture Review: VCU's New Cabell Library Is a Bold and Welcome Addition to Richmond|last=Slipek|first=Edwin|date=15 March 2016|website=Style Weekly|access-date=7 April 2017}} The new space has allowed for the addition of 25 new study rooms, a graduate and faculty reading room, a silent reading room and "The Workshop," a multimedia production suite, a gaming suite, and a makerspace.{{Cite journal|last=Morehart|first=Phil|year=2016|title=2016 Library Design Showcase|url=https://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/2016/09/01/2016-library-design-showcase/|journal=American Libraries Magazine|volume=|pages=|via=}} Ninety percent of the new space is dedicated to student and researcher use rather than staff offices or book storage. The VCU Libraries offers electronic access to some of its special collections, including papers, images, and sound files relating to civil rights, Richmond architecture, civil war medicine, comic-book and cartooning arts, medical artifacts, and the history of VCU. Library initiatives have included the 2014 Freedom Now Project,{{cite web|title=Freedom Now|url=http://www.library.vcu.edu/research/special-collections/exhibits/freedom-now/|accessdate=24 March 2015}} which published civil rights protests in 1963 [[Prince Edward County, Virginia]] and invited citizens to come forward to help identify participants and tell these untold stories. In 2015, a 19th-century map overlaid with current geospacial data and Google maps allowed researchers and the public to explore the history and architecture of Richmond.{{cite web|title=Interactive map from 1889 reveals Richmond's rich architectural history|url=http://www.library.vcu.edu/about/news/2015/interactive-map-from-1889-reveals-richmonds-rich-architectural-history-.html|publisher=University News|accessdate=24 March 2015}} VCU Libraries maintains The Social Welfare History Project, an online resource documenting the history of social reform movements and social welfare. The Social Welfare History Image Portal, a companion site hosting primary source materials contributed by an eclectic group of partner institutions, supports research and promotes the use of archival materials related to social welfare history and reform movements.{{Cite web|url=https://news.vcu.edu/article/Project_shares_ephemera_from_womens_suffrage_temperance_civil|title=Project shares ephemera from women’s suffrage, temperance, civil rights and other social movements|last=McNeill|first=Brian|date=October 16, 2017|website=VCU News|access-date=February 14, 2017}} ==Student life== {|| style="text-align:center; font-size:80%; margin-left:2em; margin:auto; float:right; clear:right;" class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |- ! colspan="2" | Virginia Commonwealth University 2014 Admissions Statistics{{cite web|title=VCU Office of Planning and Decision Support Common Data Set 2014-15|url=http://www.opds.vcu.edu/media/decision-support/factandfigures/commondatasets/CDS2014-2015OPDSWebsiteVersion.pdf|website=opds.vcu.edu/}} |- |Applicants | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 15,126 |- |Acceptance Rate | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 68.9% |- |First Year Students | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 88% in state, 12% out of state |- |High School GPA | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 3.59 |- |Average SAT (1600 - {{as of|2012|lc=y}}) | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 1088 |- |Freshman Class Size | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 3,586 |- |Undergraduate Student-Faculty Ratio | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 17:1 |- |Freshman Retention Rate | style="text-align:center; background:white;"| 86.5% |} The student body consists of 57% female students and 42% male students.{{cite web| url=http://collegesearch.collegeboard.com/search/CollegeDetail.jsp?collegeId=580&profileId=0|title=College Search - Virginia Commonwealth University - VCU|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} Out-of-state students have increased to 15% as of the fall of 2011, and the remaining 85% of students are from Virginia. Demographically, the student body is 51% white, 15% African American, 12% Asian, 7% Hispanic, 6% International, less than 1% Native American and 8% Unknown. [[File:VCU Brandt Hall by Jeff Auth.jpg|thumb|left|Brandt Hall, Monroe Park Campus]] ===Residential life=== {{Main|Housing at Virginia Commonwealth University}} More than 79% of VCU freshmen live on campus. VCU's current residential hall capacity is around 6,200 students.{{Cite web|url=https://housing.vcu.edu/media/housing/documents/resource-general/VCU_Housing_Master_Plan_2014_FINAL-screen.pdf|title=2014 VCU Department of Residential Life and Housing Housing Master Plan|last=|first=|date=|website=housing.vcu.edu|access-date=}} Because of the prominent location within the city of Richmond, many upperclassmen live in student apartments located around the campus, specifically in [[Fan district|The Fan]], [[Oregon Hill]] or the [[Carver, Richmond, Virginia|Carver]] neighborhood, and are still able to walk or bike to their classes.{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/richmond/places.html#neighborhoods|title=Richmond|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130529215953/http://www.vcu.edu/richmond/places.html#neighborhoods|archive-date=29 May 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[File:VCU Shafer Dining Center by Jeff Auth.jpg|thumb|right|350px|Shafer Court Dining Center, Monroe Park campus]] ===Dining=== Dining Services at VCU is contracted to ARAMARK Higher Education.{{cite news|last1=Isaacs|first1=Sam|title=To Buy Local Food, Students Have to Eat Elsewhere|url=http://www.commonwealthtimes.org/2013/09/17/to-buy-local-food-students-have-to-eat-elsewhere/|accessdate=2 September 2016|work=The Commonwealth Times|date=17 September 2013}} Undergraduate students living in a dorm-style university residence hall are required to purchase a residential dining plan. VCU Dining Services offers a variety of plans that allow a specific number of "Swipes" and "Dining Dollars"{{Cite web |url=https://vcu.campusdish.com/-/media/Images/Aramark/Higher-Education/Eastern/VirginiaCommonwealth/Home/Ads/DiningBrochure2016-17_web.pdf |title=2016-2017 Dining Program : VCU Dine |website=vcu.campusdish.com |access-date=2017-02-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170213165445/https://vcu.campusdish.com/-/media/Images/Aramark/Higher-Education/Eastern/VirginiaCommonwealth/Home/Ads/DiningBrochure2016-17_web.pdf |archive-date=2017-02-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} to be used throughout a semester. All unused swipes and dining dollars are forfeited at the end of each semester. "Swipes" are described as the equivalent of one-meal. Swipes can be used to enter Shafer Court Dining Center, the buffet style dining hall, and through swipe exchanges at various VCU retail restaurants during specific times. "Dining Dollars" allow students the opportunity to purchase tax-free meals at any VCU retail restaurant. Commuter students, students living off campus, faculty, and staff have the option of purchasing a nonresidential dining plan. Many dining options are available at restaurants not affiliated with VCU within a short walking distance. Chipotle, Panera Bread, Domino's, Papa John's and Five Guys are some of the most popular ones.{{cite web|url=http://www.ugrad.vcu.edu/students/dining.html|title=VCU Office of Undergraduate Admissions – Dining|publisher=}} ===Activities=== ====Student organizations==== VCU has more than 500 registered student organizations in which students can be involved.{{cite web|title=Student life – VCU Undergraduate Admissions|url=https://www.ugrad.vcu.edu/why/studentlife/index.html|website=www.ugrad.vcu.edu|accessdate=2 September 2016}} VCU boasts a well-established net of ethnic and cultural, religious, recreational and special interest organizations. There are two student government associations at VCU, one for each campus. VCU is also an academic partner to the largest [[VCU French Film Festival|French Film Festival]] in the United States.http://www.frenchfilm.vcu.edu/history.html Founded in 1993, the total participation in 2012 has grown to more than 22,000 entries for the 27 films. ====Student media==== VCU offers many student-run media outlets that allow students to express themselves without censorship or administrative control. See more at www.vcustudentmedia.com. * Amendment - An annual literary journal that presents points of view outside mainstream culture, specializing in social progression through artistic expression. * ''[[The Commonwealth Times]]'' – An independent student-run and -written newspaper published once a week during the school year.{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthtimes.org/|title=The Commonwealth Times|work=The Commonwealth Times|accessdate=29 May 2015}} * ''Ink Magazine''http://issuu.com/ink_magazine – Multi-ethnic student news magazine published two times during the academic year, an publishes online year round. * "Poictesme" – An undergraduate student literary journal distributed every spring to the student body and surrounding community{{cite web|url=http://poictesme.com/|title=poictesme (pwa-tem)|work=poictesme (pwa-tem)|accessdate=29 May 2015}} * Potboiler Podcast Network - a network of podcasts.http://www.potboilervcu.com * ''Rams Review'' – A student-run sports media outlet{{cite web|url=http://www.ramsreview.com/|title=Rams Review - Multimedia VCU Student Sports Coverage|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} * [[WVCW]] – A student-run independent radio station at VCU{{cite web|url=http://wvcw.org/|title=WVCW - WVCW, Student Radio at VCU|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} * ''The Horn'' – An inactive student-run multimedia website about the local music scene in Richmond{{cite web|url=http://www.thehornrva.com/|title=The Horn RVA|work=The Horn RVA|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530003942/http://www.thehornrva.com/|archive-date=30 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ====Recreational sports==== Recreational Sports{{cite web|url=http://www.recsports.vcu.edu/ |title=Recreational Sports | Virginia Commonwealth University |publisher=Recsports.vcu.edu |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16}} offers facilities on both campuses. Opened in spring 2010, the newly renovated Cary Street Gym[http://www.recsports.vcu.edu/facilities/cary_st_complex.html/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090814152946/http://www.recsports.vcu.edu/facilities/cary_st_complex.html/|date=August 14, 2009}} includes the 18,000-square-foot fitness center, a rock climbing wall, two pools, racquetball and basketball courts, a track and an aerobics mezzanine. The MCV Campus Recreation and Aquatic Center provide space for basketball, volleyball, racquetball and other sports. A 25-meter, six-lane pool is available for lap swimming, water basketball and volleyball. Outing Rental Center offers equipment such as backpacks, sleeping bags, tents and canoes as well as books, maps, videos and trail guides at affordable rental rates. The VCU Outdoor Adventure Program[http://www.recsports.vcu.edu/outdoor_adventure.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090812133043/http://www.recsports.vcu.edu/outdoor_adventure.html|date=August 12, 2009}} provides a full schedule of day trips and weekend excursions focused on such outdoor activities as camping, kayaking, white-water rafting, canoeing and caving. ====Service learning==== Service learning at VCU is a course-based, credit-bearing educational experience in which students participate in an organized service activity that meets community-identified needs. More than 3,000 VCU students are enrolled in service learning at VCU. ====Greek system==== Virginia Commonwealth University hosts 36 international fraternities and sororities across four governing councils with over 1,700 students. Within the student body, a total of 6.3% of women join a sorority and 8% of men join a fraternity.[http://www.opds.vcu.edu/documents/CommonDataSet201112.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103093326/http://www.opds.vcu.edu/documents/CommonDataSet201112.pdf|date=November 3, 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://greeksatvcu.com/history|title=Virginia Commonwealth University, Fraternities and Sororities|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} VCU's fraternity and sorority community has grown particularly rapidly in the last few years. .{{cite web|url=http://www.commonwealthtimes.org/?p=4545|title=Greek housing could find home on Grace Street|work=The Commonwealth Times|accessdate=29 May 2015}} List of VCU's Fraternity and Sorority Chapters{{cite web|url=http://greeksatvcu.com/home|title=Virginia Commonwealth University, Fraternities and Sororities|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Interfraternity Council{{cite web |url=http://www.ifcvcu.com/index.php |title=Virginia Commonwealth University, IFC |publisher=Ifcvcu.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121153006/http://www.ifcvcu.com/index.php |archive-date=2009-11-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }} ! College Panhellenic Council{{cite web|url=http://cpcvcu.com/home|title=Virginia Commonwealth University, CPC|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530005157/http://cpcvcu.com/home|archive-date=2015-05-30|dead-url=yes|df=}} ! Multicultural Greek Council{{cite web|url=http://www.mgcvcu.com/|title=Virginia Commonwealth University, MGC|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} ! [[National Pan-Hellenic Council]]{{cite web|url=http://nphcvcu.com/home|title=Virginia Commonwealth University, NPHC|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530002738/http://nphcvcu.com/home|archive-date=2015-05-30|dead-url=yes|df=}} |- | [[Alpha Epsilon Pi]] – Epsilon Pi Chapter | [[Alpha Epsilon Phi]] – Beta Theta | [[alpha Kappa Delta Phi]] – VCU Colony | [[Alpha Phi Alpha]] – Theta Rho Chapter |- | [[Alpha Kappa Lambda]] – Beta Nu Chapter | [[Alpha Gamma Delta]] – Theta Nu | [[Delta Phi Omega]] – Kappa Chapter | [[Alpha Kappa Alpha]] – Theta Rho Chapter |- | [[Delta Chi]] – Virginia Commonwealth | [[Alpha Omicron Pi]] – Rho Beta | [[Kappa Phi Gamma]] – Theta Chapter | [[Delta Sigma Theta]] – Eta Tau Chapter |- | [[Kappa Delta Rho]] - Omega Alpha Chapter | [[Alpha Sigma Alpha]] – Epsilon Gamma | [[Lambda Phi Epsilon]] – VCU Alpha Sigma Chapter | [[Iota Phi Theta]] – Delta Delta Chapter |- | [[Lambda Chi Alpha]] – Pi Tau Chapter | [[Alpha Xi Delta]] – Iota Sigma Chapter | [[Lambda Theta Alpha]] – Zeta Alpha Chapter | [[Kappa Alpha Psi]] – Eta Xi Chapter |- | [[Phi Gamma Delta]] (FIJI) – Mu Pi Chapter | [[Phi Sigma Rho]] – Omega | [[Lambda Theta Phi]] – Interest Group |[[Omega Psi Phi]] - Phi Delta Chapter |- | [[Phi Kappa Sigma]] – Delta Upsilon | [[Sigma Sigma Sigma]] – Epsilon Sigma | [[Lambda Upsilon Lambda]] – Alpha Psi Chapter |[[Phi Beta Sigma]] - Delta Upsilon Chapter |- | [[Phi Mu Alpha Sinfonia]] – Rho Omega | [[Phi Mu]] – Lambda Gamma |[[Sigma Lambda Upsilon]] – Alpha Zeta Chapter |[[Sigma Gamma Rho]] - Epsilon Zeta Chapter |- | [[Pi Kappa Alpha]] – Lambda Chi | [[Zeta Tau Alpha]] – Lambda Eta Chapter | [[Theta Nu Xi]] – Alpha Kappa Chapter |[[Zeta Phi Beta]] - Eta Theta Chapter |- | [[Pi Lambda Phi]] – VA Omega Rho | | | |- | [[Phi Kappa Psi]] Virginia Eta Chapter | | | |- | [[Sigma Alpha Epsilon]] – Virginia Chi | | | |- | [[Sigma Phi Epsilon]] – Virginia Beta | | | |- | [[Theta Chi]] – Theta Xi | | | |- | [[Triangle Fraternity]] – VCU Chapter | | |- |[[Pi Kappa Phi]]- Epsilon Pi || |} ===Security=== VCU's police force consists of 99 sworn police officers and more than 200 security personnel.[https://www.police.vcu.edu/docs/CampusSafetyReport.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140825034100/https://www.police.vcu.edu/docs/CampusSafetyReport.pdf|date=August 25, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.news.vcu.edu/news/John_Venuti_Named_VCU_Police_Chief|title=VCU News|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} VCU also provides a free Security Escort service (RAM SAFE) to students and faculty to assist them in reaching their destination and have stationed more than 370 Emergency Reporting Telephone Systems in various areas throughout campus.{{cite web|url=http://www.vcu.edu/police/security.html|title=Security Escort Service - VCU Police|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205180005/http://www.vcu.edu/police/security.html|archive-date=5 February 2012|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Athletics== {{main|VCU Rams}} Having competed at the NCAA Division I level for little more than 30 years, Virginia Commonwealth University has sponsored a broad-based program of intercollegiate athletics. The VCU Rams have won in excess of 30 conference championships, participated in numerous NCAA post-season championship events, including a run to the Final Four in men's basketball in 2011, and had a number of All-Americans—both academic and athletic.[http://www.vcuathletics.com/history.php] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080906223317/http://www.vcuathletics.com/history.php|date=September 6, 2008}} VCU currently sponsors sixteen varsity teams in [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]] Division I play through the [[Atlantic 10 Conference]] (A10). VCU Men's tennis is one of the school's most successful programs. The team is coached by Paul Kostin who is one of five Division I coaches to reach the 900-victory mark. The Men's tennis team holds 12 CAA Championships, 18 NCAA tournament appearances, and 17 years of finishing in the top 25 rankings in the country.[http://www.vcuathletics.com/mte_coaches.php] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017075051/http://www.vcuathletics.com/mte_coaches.php|date=October 17, 2008}} In 2000, VCU men's tennis had its best season, finishing runner up to Stanford in the NCAA Finals Championship match. The team finished with a No. 9 ranking in the country.[http://www.vcuathletics.com/mte/mte_history.php] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081018035624/http://www.vcuathletics.com/mte/mte_history.php|date=October 18, 2008}} Also under coach Paul Kostin, VCU's women's tennis team has 3 CAA championships, 12 NCAA appearances, and 8 years in the top 25. [[VCU Rams baseball|VCU Baseball]] has won a total of 3 CAA Championships and has been to a total of 8 NCAA Regionals. VCU Baseball's head coach is Shawn Stiffler, and games are played at [[The Diamond (Richmond, Virginia)]]. Other intercollegiate sports include Men and Women's Basketball, Men and Women's Cross Country, Field Hockey, Golf, Men and Women's Soccer (played at [[Sports Backers Stadium]]), Men and Women's Track and Field, Volleyball, and Women's Lacrosse. VCU also has many student run club teams. These sports not sponsored by the university include coed & allgirl cheerleading, baseball, softball, men's{{cite web|url=http://www.studentorg.vcu.edu/mensrugbyvcu|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040217230849/http://www.studentorg.vcu.edu/mensrugbyvcu/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2004-02-17|title=Untitled Document|publisher=}} and women's{{cite web|url=http://www.studentorg.vcu.edu/WomensRugby/|title=RAM RUGBY|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} [[rugby union]], [[ice hockey]],{{cite web|url=http://www.vcuhockey.net|title=ヤザワランバーの2つのモデルハウス|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150530002651/http://www.vcuhockey.net/|archive-date=30 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[ultimate (sport)|ultimate]],{{cite web|url=http://www.studentorg.vcu.edu/frisbeevcu/home.html|title=VCU Ultimate: Beware of the biscuits|publisher=|accessdate=29 May 2015}} men's and women's [[lacrosse]], cycling, [[men's and women's crew]]{{cite web|url=http://www.crewteamatvcu.org/ |title=Home |publisher=Crew Team At VCU |date= |accessdate=2016-02-01}} and dodgeball. Previous club sports have also included wrestling and tennis. ===VCU Rams men's basketball=== {{main|VCU Rams men's basketball}} VCU reached the Final Four in the 2011 NCAA tournament. The team has won a total of 9 conference championships with the most recent coming in 2015, the team's first A10 championship win. The VCU Rams currently play at the [[Stuart C. Siegel Center]], where they hold the 11th highest Home Court winning percentage in Division I basketball with a winning percentage of .8579{{cite web|url=http://rpiratings.com/homecourtrec.html|title=RPIRatings.com|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813060308/http://rpiratings.com/homecourtrec.html|archivedate=2009-08-13|df=}} In the [[2011 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]], [[2010–11 VCU Rams men's basketball team|VCU]] qualified as an at-large bid, having to play in the newly formatted tournament's "First Four" against [[2010–11 USC Trojans men's basketball team|USC]]. The decision to allow VCU to participate in the tournament was widely criticized among pundits and the media.{{cite web|url=http://www.sportsgrid.com/ncaa-basketball/jay-bilas-calls-selections-of-uab/|title=Jay Bilas Calls Selections Of UAB, VCU "Indefensible" - SportsGrid|work=SportsGrid|accessdate=29 May 2015}} VCU defeated USC 59–46 in the "First Four" play-in game. VCU then went on to upset [[2010–11 Georgetown Hoyas men's basketball team|Georgetown]] 74–56 in the round of 64. The 11th-seeded VCU Rams then upset 3rd-seeded [[2010–11 Purdue Boilermakers men's basketball team|Purdue]] 94–76 to advance to the [[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship#Regional semifinals and finals|Sweet 16]] for the first time in school history. In the sweet sixteen, VCU defeated 10th-seeded [[2010–11 Florida State Seminoles men's basketball team|Florida State]] 72–71 on a last second bucket in overtime to advance to the [[Elite 8]] for the first time in school history. VCU beat the No. 1 seed [[2010–11 Kansas Jayhawks men's basketball team|Kansas]] in the Southwest Regional final by a score of 71–61. It was the Rams' first trip to the [[Final Four]]. Against [[2010–11 Butler Bulldogs men's basketball team|Butler]] in the Final Four, VCU lost 70–62. The [[2010–11 VCU Rams men's basketball team]] finished 6th in the ESPN/USA Today Coaches Poll at the end of the season.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/rankings/_/poll/2 |title=NCAA College Basketball Polls, College Basketball Rankings, NCAA Basketball Polls - ESPN |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16}} This was the highest ranking in VCU's history and the highest ranking of any team from the [[Colonial Athletic Association|CAA]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vcuathletics.com/sports/mbkb/2010-11/releases/20110405bzx9gm |title=RAMS FINISH THE SEASON RANKED SIXTH IN USA TODAY/ESPN TOP 25 POLL - VCU |publisher=Vcuathletics.com |date=2011-04-05 |accessdate=2014-08-16}} ===VCU Rams women's basketball=== Former WNBA player and Notre Dame's all-time leading scorer Beth Cunningham coaches the VCU Rams women's team. The VCU Rams Women's team enjoyed the most successful season in their history in the 2008–2009 season. The team finished the season with a mark of 26–7 overall and a 15–3 conference record. Notably the team was a perfect 16–0 at home. After finishing second in their conference the team headed to their first ever NCAA tournament game as the 10th seed, where the No. 7 seeded Rutgers eliminated them 57–51 on their home court.[http://www.vcuathletics.com/wbb/0809stats/teamcume.htm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090203083404/http://www.vcuathletics.com/wbb/0809stats/teamcume.htm|date=February 3, 2009}} In the 2009–2010 season Cunningham led the Rams to the NIT Sweet Sixteen where they were eliminated by Syracuse. ===Athletics Rivals=== [[File:Rowdy Rams.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Rowdy Rams (far back) spelling out "VIRGINIA COMMONWEALTH!"]] VCU's main rival is [[Old Dominion Monarchs|Old Dominion University]]. The "[[VCU-ODU basketball rivalry]]" is often regarded as the best college basketball rivalry in the Commonwealth of [[Virginia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.caahoops.com/2011/01/vcuodu-the-rivalry-is-just-different/|title=VCU/ODU: The Rivalry Is Just Different…|publisher=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119120344/http://www.caahoops.com/2011/01/vcuodu-the-rivalry-is-just-different/|archivedate=2012-01-19|df=}}[http://fdhub.net/odu-at-vcu-sold-out/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215040118/http://fdhub.net/odu-at-vcu-sold-out/|date=February 15, 2011}} The Rams' intra-city rivalry with [[Richmond Spiders|University of Richmond]] ("[[Black & Blue Classic]]"),{{cite web|url=http://www2.richmond.com/lifestyles/2010/dec/10/vcu-vs-ur-ar-705330/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101212194226/http://www2.richmond.com/lifestyles/2010/dec/10/vcu-vs-ur-ar-705330/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=12 December 2010|title=VCU vs. UR|work=Richmond.com|accessdate=29 May 2015}} is bound to heat up now that the two schools are playing in the same conference again for the first time since 2001.{{cite web |author=facebook |url=http://www2.timesdispatch.com/sports/2012/may/15/urs-miller-believes-vcus-move-10-benefits-both-sch-ar-1916412/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120518103546/http://www2.timesdispatch.com/sports/2012/may/15/urs-miller-believes-vcus-move-10-benefits-both-sch-ar-1916412/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-05-18 |title=UR's Miller believes VCU's move to A-10 benefits both schools - Richmond Times-Dispatch: Archive |publisher=timesdispatch.com |date=2012-05-15 |accessdate=2014-08-16 }} ===Rowdy Rams=== The Rowdy Rams is a student-run athletic support organization that focuses on VCU men's basketball, while also attending and supporting the university's 16 other varsity teams. The group began during the 2002–2003 basketball season when a group of VCU Pep Band members and other students began coordinating cheers together and taking road trips to away games. The following year, the Rowdy Rams procured funding from the SGA and sponsorship from VCU's Athletic Department, solidifying themselves as an official organization.{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/vcurowdyrams/about-us |title=About Us - VCU Rowdy Rams |publisher=Sites.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16}} The Rowdy Rams offer members priority seating to all VCU men's basketball home games, a discount card for local restaurants and businesses, a free T-shirt, and free bus trips to road games.{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/vcurowdyrams/team-roster-and-stats |title=Benefits - VCU Rowdy Rams |publisher=Sites.google.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16}} In April 2011, The Rowdy Rams followed the men's basketball team to Houston for the Final Four. Despite the team's upset by Butler University, the fan organization never regretted their trip. "Our Rowdy Rams came here in full force; the spirit was on the court; you could feel it all around the arena."{{cite web |author=facebook |url=http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2011/apr/03/tdmain14-vcu-fans-in-houston-experience-the-agony--ar-946560/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110406064051/http://www2.timesdispatch.com/news/2011/apr/03/tdmain14-vcu-fans-in-houston-experience-the-agony--ar-946560/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-04-06 |title=VCU fans in Houston experience the agony of defeat - Richmond Times-Dispatch: Richmond News, Crime & Politics |publisher=.timesdispatch.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-16 }} In May 2013, The Rowdy Rams won the annual Naismith Student Section of the Year award, which awards the most passionate student section in college basketball.{{cite web|author=March 7, 2013 AM • by Nathan Cushing |url=http://rvanews.com/news/rowdy-rams-named-student-section-of-the-year/85820 |title=Rowdy Rams named Student Section of the Year |publisher=RVANews |date=2013-03-27 |accessdate=2014-08-16}} ==Notable alumni== {{main|List of Virginia Commonwealth University alumni}} VCU has a total of 182,746 alumni with 60,534 alumni living in the Richmond Metro Area.[http://www.opds.vcu.edu/documents/factcard201112.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131103094216/http://www.opds.vcu.edu/documents/factcard201112.pdf|date=November 3, 2013}} ==See also== * [[Institute for Contemporary Art, Richmond]] * [[Virginia Commonwealth University - Qatar]] * [[VCU School of the Arts]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commonscat}} * {{Official website|http://www.vcu.edu}} * [http://www.vcuathletics.com VCU Athletics website] {{Virginia Commonwealth University}} {{Colleges and universities in Virginia}} {{Southeastern Universities Research Association}} {{Atlantic 10 Conference navbox}} [[Category:1838 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1838]] [[Category:Universities and colleges in Virginia]] [[Category:Public universities]] [[Category:Urban 13 universities]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1968]] [[Category:Virginia Commonwealth University| ]] [[Category:Art schools in Virginia]] [[Category:Education in Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:Universities and colleges accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Richmond, Virginia]]
